text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice, a young girl, follows a White Rabbit down a rabbit hole and falls into a whimsical, bizarre world called Wonderland.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: In the fairytale "Alice in DaSCHland," a curious young girl named Alice discovers a magical realm powered by DaSCH, a company that operates as a repository for research data in the humanities. This world is filled with technological wonders like talking robots, digital trees, and houses that change color. Guided by a robot named RabbIT, Alice explores various marvels, including a caf√© with size-altering tea and a library with books that speak. She meets the Queen of Hearts, an engineer who creates devices connecting emotions with digital data. Although Alice returns to her world with a token from DaSCHland, the experience leaves her inspired, reminding her that the realm of innovation and dreams, where research data in the humanities are brought to life, awaits her return.

In this new environment, Alice embarks on another adventure filled with enigmatic algorithms, unusual digital entities, and peculiar happenings, where she must adapt to the unpredictable nature of the data streams and the ever-evolving digital landscape.

resource.label: Alice in Wonderland - Chapter nan - Poem: ‚ÄúAll in the golden afternoon‚Äù

text-prop.name: :hasDescription

text.comment: The poem has no chapter number because it does not belong to the story itself. It was placed in the first Edition at the beginning of the Adventures of Alice in Wonderland.

text-prop.text: The poem "All in the Golden Afternoon" serves as a prologue to Lewis Carroll's "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland." It captures the whimsical and nostalgic essence of a summer's day spent boating on the river Thames with three young sisters. Carroll, personified as the "idle" storyteller, is coaxed into recounting a fantastical tale to amuse his companions. The narrative weaves together the enchanting atmosphere of the golden afternoon with the playful, imaginative spirit of the story to come. Through this prelude, Carroll sets the stage for the ensuing adventures in Wonderland, blending reality and fantasy in a harmonious and enchanting preamble.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: The poem "All in the Golden Afternoon" acts as a prelude to the journey through Alice's exploration of the digital realm in Alice in DaSCHland. It mirrors the transition from a peaceful, analog world into the bustling, ever-evolving stream of data and information. Just as a calm afternoon on the river evolves into a whimsical adventure, the poem captures the shift from reality to a space where algorithms and metadata weave together stories of their own. Through this introduction, the poem sets the stage for Alice's adventures in the digital landscape, blending the familiar with the fantastical in a seamless prelude.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
ALL in the golden afternoon Full leisurely we glide; For both our oars, with little skill, By little arms are plied, While little hands make vain pretence Our wanderings to guide.
Ah, cruel Three! In such an hour, Beneath such dreamy weather, To beg a tale of breath too weak To stir the tiniest feather! Yet what can one poor voice avail Against three tongues together?
Imperious Prima flashes forth Her edict ‚Äòto begin it‚Äô ‚Äì In gentler tone Secunda hopes ‚ÄòThere will be nonsense in it!‚Äô ‚Äì While Tertia interrupts the tale Not more than once a minute.
Anon, to sudden silence won, In fancy they pursue The dream-child moving through a land Of wonders wild and new, In friendly chat with bird or beast ‚Äì And half believe it true.
And ever, as the story drained The wells of fancy dry, And faintly strove that weary one To put the subject by, ‚ÄúThe rest next time -‚Äù ‚ÄúIt is next time!‚Äù The happy voices cry.
Thus grew the tale of Wonderland: Thus slowly, one by one, Its quaint events were hammered out ‚Äì And now the tale is done, And home we steer, a merry crew, Beneath the setting sun.
Alice! a childish story take, And with a gentle hand Lay it where Childhood‚Äôs dreams are twined In Memory‚Äôs mystic band, Like pilgrim‚Äôs wither‚Äôd wreath of flowers Pluck‚Äôd in a far-off land.

resource.label: Alice in Wonderland - Chapter 1 - Down the Rabbit-Hole

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice is sitting with her sister on the riverbank when, out of the blue, a White Rabbit appears. He is wearing a waistcoat and is busy taking a watch out of it, muttering to himself, 'Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!'. Alice can't help but feel intrigued, and follows him down his rabbit-hole.The rabbit-hole suddenly goes straight down, and Alice falls into it. She falls very slowly, and while she is talking to herself, she falls asleep. But then, out of the blue, she lands on a heap of sticks and dry leaves, and the fall is over.She sees the White Rabbit running in front of her through a long passage, and she just has to follow him.When she turns the corner, the Rabbit is gone, and Alice finds herself in a long, low hall with doors all around it.She tries them, but they are all locked.Then she comes upon a little three-legged table on which a little golden key lies. The key fits in a little door behind a curtain, and when she opens it, she is delighted to see that it leads into a small passage.At the end of the passage, Alice sees a beautiful garden she really wants to get into, but she is too big to fit through the door.When she goes back to the table, she finds a little bottle on it with the words 'Drink me' printed on the label.Alice drinks from it and starts shrinking until she is only ten inches high. She's finally got the right size to fit through the door, but it's still locked! She's left the little golden key on the table, but it's too high to reach. She starts crying, but then she sees a small glass box under the table. On the box is a cake with the words 'Eat me' written on it. She hopes that eating the cake will make her grow or shrink too, so she eats it.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: Alice was not your ordinary girl; she had a keen sense of adventure and a bright, inquisitive mind. One sunny afternoon, while wandering near the edge of her town, she stumbled upon a peculiar rabbit hole, shimmering with an array of colors that hinted at something magical beyond the ordinary.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank, and of having nothing to do: once or twice she had peeped into the book her sister was reading, but it had no pictures or conversations in it, ‚Äúand what is the use of a book,‚Äù thought Alice ‚Äúwithout pictures or conversations?‚Äù
So she was considering in her own mind (as well as she could, for the hot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid), whether the pleasure of making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up and picking the daisies, when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran close by her.
There was nothing so very remarkable in that; nor did Alice think it so very much out of the way to hear the Rabbit say to itself, ‚ÄúOh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!‚Äù (when she thought it over afterwards, it occurred to her that she ought to have wondered at this, but at the time it all seemed quite natural); but when the Rabbit actually took a watch out of its waistcoat-pocket, and looked at it, and then hurried on, Alice started to her feet, for it flashed across her mind that she had never before seen a rabbit with either a waistcoat-pocket, or a watch to take out of it, and burning with curiosity, she ran across the field after it, and fortunately was just in time to see it pop down a large rabbit-hole under the hedge.
In another moment down went Alice after it, never once considering how in the world she was to get out again.
The rabbit-hole went straight on like a tunnel for some way, and then dipped suddenly down, so suddenly that Alice had not a moment to think about stopping herself before she found herself falling down a very deep well.
Either the well was very deep, or she fell very slowly, for she had plenty of time as she went down to look about her and to wonder what was going to happen next. First, she tried to look down and make out what she was coming to, but it was too dark to see anything; then she looked at the sides of the well, and noticed that they were filled with cupboards and book-shelves; here and there she saw maps and pictures hung upon pegs. She took down a jar from one of the shelves as she passed; it was labelled ‚ÄúORANGE MARMALADE‚Äù, but to her great disappointment it was empty: she did not like to drop the jar for fear of killing somebody underneath, so managed to put it into one of the cupboards as she fell past it.
‚ÄúWell!‚Äù thought Alice to herself, ‚Äúafter such a fall as this, I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs! How brave they‚Äôll all think me at home! Why, I wouldn‚Äôt say anything about it, even if I fell off the top of the house!‚Äù (Which was very likely true.)
Down, down, down. Would the fall never come to an end? ‚ÄúI wonder how many miles I‚Äôve fallen by this time?‚Äù she said aloud. ‚ÄúI must be getting somewhere near the centre of the earth. Let me see: that would be four thousand miles down, I think‚Äî‚Äù (for, you see, Alice had learnt several things of this sort in her lessons in the schoolroom, and though this was not a very good opportunity for showing off her knowledge, as there was no one to listen to her, still it was good practice to say it over) ‚Äú‚Äîyes, that‚Äôs about the right distance‚Äîbut then I wonder what Latitude or Longitude I‚Äôve got to?‚Äù (Alice had no idea what Latitude was, or Longitude either, but thought they were nice grand words to say.)
Presently she began again. ‚ÄúI wonder if I shall fall right through the earth! How funny it‚Äôll seem to come out among the people that walk with their heads downward! The Antipathies, I think‚Äî‚Äù (she was rather glad there was no one listening, this time, as it didn‚Äôt sound at all the right word) ‚Äú‚Äîbut I shall have to ask them what the name of the country is, you know. Please, Ma‚Äôam, is this New Zealand or Australia?‚Äù (and she tried to curtsey as she spoke‚Äîfancy curtseying as you‚Äôre falling through the air! Do you think you could manage it?) ‚ÄúAnd what an ignorant little girl she‚Äôll think me for asking! No, it‚Äôll never do to ask: perhaps I shall see it written up somewhere.‚Äù
Down, down, down. There was nothing else to do, so Alice soon began talking again. ‚ÄúDinah‚Äôll miss me very much to-night, I should think!‚Äù (Dinah was the cat.) ‚ÄúI hope they‚Äôll remember her saucer of milk at tea-time. Dinah my dear! I wish you were down here with me! There are no mice in the air, I‚Äôm afraid, but you might catch a bat, and that‚Äôs very like a mouse, you know. But do cats eat bats, I wonder?‚Äù And here Alice began to get rather sleepy, and went on saying to herself, in a dreamy sort of way, ‚ÄúDo cats eat bats? Do cats eat bats?‚Äù and sometimes, ‚ÄúDo bats eat cats?‚Äù for, you see, as she couldn‚Äôt answer either question, it didn‚Äôt much matter which way she put it. She felt that she was dozing off, and had just begun to dream that she was walking hand in hand with Dinah, and saying to her very earnestly, ‚ÄúNow, Dinah, tell me the truth: did you ever eat a bat?‚Äù when suddenly, thump! thump! down she came upon a heap of sticks and dry leaves, and the fall was over.
Alice was not a bit hurt, and she jumped up on to her feet in a moment: she looked up, but it was all dark overhead; before her was another long passage, and the White Rabbit was still in sight, hurrying down it. There was not a moment to be lost: away went Alice like the wind, and was just in time to hear it say, as it turned a corner, ‚ÄúOh my ears and whiskers, how late it‚Äôs getting!‚Äù She was close behind it when she turned the corner, but the Rabbit was no longer to be seen: she found herself in a long, low hall, which was lit up by a row of lamps hanging from the roof.
There were doors all round the hall, but they were all locked; and when Alice had been all the way down one side and up the other, trying every door, she walked sadly down the middle, wondering how she was ever to get out again.
Suddenly she came upon a little three-legged table, all made of solid glass; there was nothing on it except a tiny golden key, and Alice‚Äôs first thought was that it might belong to one of the doors of the hall; but, alas! either the locks were too large, or the key was too small, but at any rate it would not open any of them. However, on the second time round, she came upon a low curtain she had not noticed before, and behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high: she tried the little golden key in the lock, and to her great delight it fitted!
Alice opened the door and found that it led into a small passage, not much larger than a rat-hole: she knelt down and looked along the passage into the loveliest garden you ever saw. How she longed to get out of that dark hall, and wander about among those beds of bright flowers and those cool fountains, but she could not even get her head through the doorway; ‚Äúand even if my head would go through,‚Äù thought poor Alice, ‚Äúit would be of very little use without my shoulders. Oh, how I wish I could shut up like a telescope! I think I could, if I only knew how to begin.‚Äù For, you see, so many out-of-the-way things had happened lately, that Alice had begun to think that very few things indeed were really impossible.
There seemed to be no use in waiting by the little door, so she went back to the table, half hoping she might find another key on it, or at any rate a book of rules for shutting people up like telescopes: this time she found a little bottle on it, (‚Äúwhich certainly was not here before,‚Äù said Alice,) and round the neck of the bottle was a paper label, with the words ‚ÄúDRINK ME,‚Äù beautifully printed on it in large letters.
It was all very well to say ‚ÄúDrink me,‚Äù but the wise little Alice was not going to do that in a hurry. ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôll look first,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúand see whether it‚Äôs marked ‚Äòpoison‚Äô or not‚Äù; for she had read several nice little histories about children who had got burnt, and eaten up by wild beasts and other unpleasant things, all because they would not remember the simple rules their friends had taught them: such as, that a red-hot poker will burn you if you hold it too long; and that if you cut your finger very deeply with a knife, it usually bleeds; and she had never forgotten that, if you drink much from a bottle marked ‚Äúpoison,‚Äù it is almost certain to disagree with you, sooner or later.
However, this bottle was not marked ‚Äúpoison,‚Äù so Alice ventured to taste it, and finding it very nice, (it had, in fact, a sort of mixed flavour of cherry-tart, custard, pine-apple, roast turkey, toffee, and hot buttered toast,) she very soon finished it off.
* * * * * * *
* * * * * *
* * * * * * *
‚ÄúWhat a curious feeling!‚Äù said Alice; ‚ÄúI must be shutting up like a telescope.‚Äù
And so it was indeed: she was now only ten inches high, and her face brightened up at the thought that she was now the right size for going through the little door into that lovely garden. First, however, she waited for a few minutes to see if she was going to shrink any further: she felt a little nervous about this; ‚Äúfor it might end, you know,‚Äù said Alice to herself, ‚Äúin my going out altogether, like a candle. I wonder what I should be like then?‚Äù And she tried to fancy what the flame of a candle is like after the candle is blown out, for she could not remember ever having seen such a thing.
After a while, finding that nothing more happened, she decided on going into the garden at once; but, alas for poor Alice! when she got to the door, she found she had forgotten the little golden key, and when she went back to the table for it, she found she could not possibly reach it: she could see it quite plainly through the glass, and she tried her best to climb up one of the legs of the table, but it was too slippery; and when she had tired herself out with trying, the poor little thing sat down and cried.
‚ÄúCome, there‚Äôs no use in crying like that!‚Äù said Alice to herself, rather sharply; ‚ÄúI advise you to leave off this minute!‚Äù She generally gave herself very good advice, (though she very seldom followed it), and sometimes she scolded herself so severely as to bring tears into her eyes; and once she remembered trying to box her own ears for having cheated herself in a game of croquet she was playing against herself, for this curious child was very fond of pretending to be two people. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs no use now,‚Äù thought poor Alice, ‚Äúto pretend to be two people! Why, there‚Äôs hardly enough of me left to make one respectable person!‚Äù
Soon her eye fell on a little glass box that was lying under the table: she opened it, and found in it a very small cake, on which the words ‚ÄúEAT ME‚Äù were beautifully marked in currants. ‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôll eat it,‚Äù said Alice, ‚Äúand if it makes me grow larger, I can reach the key; and if it makes me grow smaller, I can creep under the door; so either way I‚Äôll get into the garden, and I don‚Äôt care which happens!‚Äù
She ate a little bit, and said anxiously to herself, ‚ÄúWhich way? Which way?‚Äù, holding her hand on the top of her head to feel which way it was growing, and she was quite surprised to find that she remained the same size: to be sure, this generally happens when one eats cake, but Alice had got so much into the way of expecting nothing but out-of-the-way things to happen, that it seemed quite dull and stupid for life to go on in the common way.
So she set to work, and very soon finished off the cake.
* * * * * * *
* * * * * *
* * * * * * *

resource.label: Alice in Wonderland - Chapter 2 - The Pool of Tears

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice grows and grows until she's as big as the ceiling.Now she can get the key from the table, but she's too big to fit through the door, so she cries and makes a big puddle on the floor.The White Rabbit comes back, looking really nice and carrying a pair of white kid gloves and a big fan. Alice asks the rabbit for help, but the rabbit is so scared that he drops the gloves and fan and runs away.Alice picks them up and starts fanning herself while she wonders what has made this day so different from every other.She decides that she must have been changed into another girl in the night, as she can't remember her multiplication tables or geography correctly and isn't able to recite a poem properly.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: Compelled by her adventurous spirit, Alice leaned in closer to examine the hole. Suddenly, she found herself tumbling down into an extraordinary place called DaSCHland. This wasn't just any wonderland; it was a world powered by the innovative company DaSCH, known for its remarkable technology and whimsical inventions, and importantly, as a repository for research data in the humanities.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
‚ÄúCuriouser and curiouser!‚Äù cried Alice (she was so much surprised, that for the moment she quite forgot how to speak good English); ‚Äúnow I‚Äôm opening out like the largest telescope that ever was! Good-bye, feet!‚Äù (for when she looked down at her feet, they seemed to be almost out of sight, they were getting so far off). ‚ÄúOh, my poor little feet, I wonder who will put on your shoes and stockings for you now, dears? I‚Äôm sure I shan‚Äôt be able! I shall be a great deal too far off to trouble myself about you: you must manage the best way you can;‚Äîbut I must be kind to them,‚Äù thought Alice, ‚Äúor perhaps they won‚Äôt walk the way I want to go! Let me see: I‚Äôll give them a new pair of boots every Christmas.‚Äù
And she went on planning to herself how she would manage it. ‚ÄúThey must go by the carrier,‚Äù she thought; ‚Äúand how funny it‚Äôll seem, sending presents to one‚Äôs own feet! And how odd the directions will look! Alice‚Äôs Right Foot, Esq., Hearthrug, near the Fender, (with Alice‚Äôs love).
Oh dear, what nonsense I‚Äôm talking!‚Äù
Just then her head struck against the roof of the hall: in fact she was now more than nine feet high, and she at once took up the little golden key and hurried off to the garden door.
Poor Alice! It was as much as she could do, lying down on one side, to look through into the garden with one eye; but to get through was more hopeless than ever: she sat down and began to cry again.
‚ÄúYou ought to be ashamed of yourself,‚Äù said Alice, ‚Äúa great girl like you,‚Äù (she might well say this), ‚Äúto go on crying in this way! Stop this moment, I tell you!‚Äù But she went on all the same, shedding gallons of tears, until there was a large pool all round her, about four inches deep and reaching half down the hall.
After a time she heard a little pattering of feet in the distance, and she hastily dried her eyes to see what was coming. It was the White Rabbit returning, splendidly dressed, with a pair of white kid gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other: he came trotting along in a great hurry, muttering to himself as he came, ‚ÄúOh! the Duchess, the Duchess! Oh! won‚Äôt she be savage if I‚Äôve kept her waiting!‚Äù Alice felt so desperate that she was ready to ask help of any one; so, when the Rabbit came near her, she began, in a low, timid voice, ‚ÄúIf you please, sir‚Äî‚Äù The Rabbit started violently, dropped the white kid gloves and the fan, and skurried away into the darkness as hard as he could go.
Alice took up the fan and gloves, and, as the hall was very hot, she kept fanning herself all the time she went on talking: ‚ÄúDear, dear! How queer everything is to-day! And yesterday things went on just as usual. I wonder if I‚Äôve been changed in the night? Let me think: was I the same when I got up this morning? I almost think I can remember feeling a little different. But if I‚Äôm not the same, the next question is, Who in the world am I? Ah, that‚Äôs the great puzzle!‚Äù And she began thinking over all the children she knew that were of the same age as herself, to see if she could have been changed for any of them.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm not Ada,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúfor her hair goes in such long ringlets, and mine doesn‚Äôt go in ringlets at all; and I‚Äôm sure I can‚Äôt be Mabel, for I know all sorts of things, and she, oh! she knows such a very little! Besides, she‚Äôs she, and I‚Äôm I, and‚Äîoh dear, how puzzling it all is! I‚Äôll try if I know all the things I used to know. Let me see: four times five is twelve, and four times six is thirteen, and four times seven is‚Äîoh dear! I shall never get to twenty at that rate! However, the Multiplication Table doesn‚Äôt signify: let‚Äôs try Geography. London is the capital of Paris, and Paris is the capital of Rome, and Rome‚Äîno, that‚Äôs all wrong, I‚Äôm certain! I must have been changed for Mabel! I‚Äôll try and say ‚ÄòHow doth the little‚Äî‚Äô‚Äù and she crossed her hands on her lap as if she were saying lessons, and began to repeat it, but her voice sounded hoarse and strange, and the words did not come the same as they used to do:‚Äî
‚ÄúHow doth the little crocodile Improve his shining tail, And pour the waters of the Nile On every golden scale!
‚ÄúHow cheerfully he seems to grin, How neatly spread his claws, And welcome little fishes in With gently smiling jaws!‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure those are not the right words,‚Äù said poor Alice, and her eyes filled with tears again as she went on, ‚ÄúI must be Mabel after all, and I shall have to go and live in that poky little house, and have next to no toys to play with, and oh! ever so many lessons to learn! No, I‚Äôve made up my mind about it; if I‚Äôm Mabel, I‚Äôll stay down here! It‚Äôll be no use their putting their heads down and saying ‚ÄòCome up again, dear!‚Äô I shall only look up and say ‚ÄòWho am I then? Tell me that first, and then, if I like being that person, I‚Äôll come up: if not, I‚Äôll stay down here till I‚Äôm somebody else‚Äô‚Äîbut, oh dear!‚Äù cried Alice, with a sudden burst of tears, ‚ÄúI do wish they would put their heads down! I am so very tired of being all alone here!‚Äù
As she said this she looked down at her hands, and was surprised to see that she had put on one of the Rabbit‚Äôs little white kid gloves while she was talking. ‚ÄúHow can I have done that?‚Äù she thought. ‚ÄúI must be growing small again.‚Äù She got up and went to the table to measure herself by it, and found that, as nearly as she could guess, she was now about two feet high, and was going on shrinking rapidly: she soon found out that the cause of this was the fan she was holding, and she dropped it hastily, just in time to avoid shrinking away altogether.
‚ÄúThat was a narrow escape!‚Äù said Alice, a good deal frightened at the sudden change, but very glad to find herself still in existence; ‚Äúand now for the garden!‚Äù and she ran with all speed back to the little door: but, alas! the little door was shut again, and the little golden key was lying on the glass table as before, ‚Äúand things are worse than ever,‚Äù thought the poor child, ‚Äúfor I never was so small as this before, never! And I declare it‚Äôs too bad, that it is!‚Äù
As she said these words her foot slipped, and in another moment, splash! she was up to her chin in salt water. Her first idea was that she had somehow fallen into the sea, ‚Äúand in that case I can go back by railway,‚Äù she said to herself. (Alice had been to the seaside once in her life, and had come to the general conclusion, that wherever you go to on the English coast you find a number of bathing machines in the sea, some children digging in the sand with wooden spades, then a row of lodging houses, and behind them a railway station.) However, she soon made out that she was in the pool of tears which she had wept when she was nine feet high.
‚ÄúI wish I hadn‚Äôt cried so much!‚Äù said Alice, as she swam about, trying to find her way out. ‚ÄúI shall be punished for it now, I suppose, by being drowned in my own tears! That will be a queer thing, to be sure! However, everything is queer to-day.‚Äù
Just then she heard something splashing about in the pool a little way off, and she swam nearer to make out what it was: at first she thought it must be a walrus or hippopotamus, but then she remembered how small she was now, and she soon made out that it was only a mouse that had slipped in like herself.
‚ÄúWould it be of any use, now,‚Äù thought Alice, ‚Äúto speak to this mouse? Everything is so out-of-the-way down here, that I should think very likely it can talk: at any rate, there‚Äôs no harm in trying.‚Äù So she began: ‚ÄúO Mouse, do you know the way out of this pool? I am very tired of swimming about here, O Mouse!‚Äù (Alice thought this must be the right way of speaking to a mouse: she had never done such a thing before, but she remembered having seen in her brother‚Äôs Latin Grammar, ‚ÄúA mouse‚Äîof a mouse‚Äîto a mouse‚Äîa mouse‚ÄîO mouse!‚Äù) The Mouse looked at her rather inquisitively, and seemed to her to wink with one of its little eyes, but it said nothing.
‚ÄúPerhaps it doesn‚Äôt understand English,‚Äù thought Alice; ‚ÄúI daresay it‚Äôs a French mouse, come over with William the Conqueror.‚Äù (For, with all her knowledge of history, Alice had no very clear notion how long ago anything had happened.) So she began again: ‚ÄúO√π est ma chatte?‚Äù which was the first sentence in her French lesson-book. The Mouse gave a sudden leap out of the water, and seemed to quiver all over with fright. ‚ÄúOh, I beg your pardon!‚Äù cried Alice hastily, afraid that she had hurt the poor animal‚Äôs feelings. ‚ÄúI quite forgot you didn‚Äôt like cats.‚Äù
‚ÄúNot like cats!‚Äù cried the Mouse, in a shrill, passionate voice. ‚ÄúWould you like cats if you were me?‚Äù
‚ÄúWell, perhaps not,‚Äù said Alice in a soothing tone: ‚Äúdon‚Äôt be angry about it. And yet I wish I could show you our cat Dinah: I think you‚Äôd take a fancy to cats if you could only see her. She is such a dear quiet thing,‚Äù Alice went on, half to herself, as she swam lazily about in the pool, ‚Äúand she sits purring so nicely by the fire, licking her paws and washing her face‚Äîand she is such a nice soft thing to nurse‚Äîand she‚Äôs such a capital one for catching mice‚Äîoh, I beg your pardon!‚Äù cried Alice again, for this time the Mouse was bristling all over, and she felt certain it must be really offended. ‚ÄúWe won‚Äôt talk about her any more if you‚Äôd rather not.‚Äù
‚ÄúWe indeed!‚Äù cried the Mouse, who was trembling down to the end of his tail. ‚ÄúAs if I would talk on such a subject! Our family always hated cats: nasty, low, vulgar things! Don‚Äôt let me hear the name again!‚Äù
‚ÄúI won‚Äôt indeed!‚Äù said Alice, in a great hurry to change the subject of conversation. ‚ÄúAre you‚Äîare you fond‚Äîof‚Äîof dogs?‚Äù The Mouse did not answer, so Alice went on eagerly: ‚ÄúThere is such a nice little dog near our house I should like to show you! A little bright-eyed terrier, you know, with oh, such long curly brown hair! And it‚Äôll fetch things when you throw them, and it‚Äôll sit up and beg for its dinner, and all sorts of things‚ÄîI can‚Äôt remember half of them‚Äîand it belongs to a farmer, you know, and he says it‚Äôs so useful, it‚Äôs worth a hundred pounds! He says it kills all the rats and‚Äîoh dear!‚Äù cried Alice in a sorrowful tone, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid I‚Äôve offended it again!‚Äù For the Mouse was swimming away from her as hard as it could go, and making quite a commotion in the pool as it went.
So she called softly after it, ‚ÄúMouse dear! Do come back again, and we won‚Äôt talk about cats or dogs either, if you don‚Äôt like them!‚Äù When the Mouse heard this, it turned round and swam slowly back to her: its face was quite pale (with passion, Alice thought), and it said in a low trembling voice, ‚ÄúLet us get to the shore, and then I‚Äôll tell you my history, and you‚Äôll understand why it is I hate cats and dogs.‚Äù
It was high time to go, for the pool was getting quite crowded with the birds and animals that had fallen into it: there were a Duck and a Dodo, a Lory and an Eaglet, and several other curious creatures. Alice led the way, and the whole party swam to the shore.

resource.label: Alice in Wonderland - Chapter 3 - A Caucus-Race and a long Tale

text-prop.name: :hasName
text-prop.text: A Caucus-Race and a long Tale

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: As Alice landed softly on a bed of clouds, she was greeted by a talking robot named RabbIT. RabbIT, with its glowing red eyes and sleek silver body, was unlike any creature Alice had ever seen. "Welcome to DaSCHland," it beeped warmly. "Here, our dreams become realities, and our curiosities fuel our creations."

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
They were indeed a queer-looking party that assembled on the bank‚Äîthe birds with draggled feathers, the animals with their fur clinging close to them, and all dripping wet, cross, and uncomfortable.
The first question of course was, how to get dry again: they had a consultation about this, and after a few minutes it seemed quite natural to Alice to find herself talking familiarly with them, as if she had known them all her life. Indeed, she had quite a long argument with the Lory, who at last turned sulky, and would only say, ‚ÄúI am older than you, and must know better;‚Äù and this Alice would not allow without knowing how old it was, and, as the Lory positively refused to tell its age, there was no more to be said.
At last the Mouse, who seemed to be a person of authority among them, called out, ‚ÄúSit down, all of you, and listen to me! I‚Äôll soon make you dry enough!‚Äù They all sat down at once, in a large ring, with the Mouse in the middle. Alice kept her eyes anxiously fixed on it, for she felt sure she would catch a bad cold if she did not get dry very soon.
‚ÄúAhem!‚Äù said the Mouse with an important air, ‚Äúare you all ready? This is the driest thing I know. Silence all round, if you please! ‚ÄòWilliam the Conqueror, whose cause was favoured by the pope, was soon submitted to by the English, who wanted leaders, and had been of late much accustomed to usurpation and conquest. Edwin and Morcar, the earls of Mercia and Northumbria‚Äî‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄúUgh!‚Äù said the Lory, with a shiver.
‚ÄúI beg your pardon!‚Äù said the Mouse, frowning, but very politely: ‚ÄúDid you speak?‚Äù
‚ÄúNot I!‚Äù said the Lory hastily.
‚ÄúI thought you did,‚Äù said the Mouse. ‚Äú‚ÄîI proceed. ‚ÄòEdwin and Morcar, the earls of Mercia and Northumbria, declared for him: and even Stigand, the patriotic archbishop of Canterbury, found it advisable‚Äî‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄúFound what?‚Äù said the Duck.
‚ÄúFound it,‚Äù the Mouse replied rather crossly: ‚Äúof course you know what ‚Äòit‚Äô means.‚Äù
‚ÄúI know what ‚Äòit‚Äô means well enough, when I find a thing,‚Äù said the Duck: ‚Äúit‚Äôs generally a frog or a worm. The question is, what did the archbishop find?‚Äù
The Mouse did not notice this question, but hurriedly went on, ‚Äú‚Äò‚Äîfound it advisable to go with Edgar Atheling to meet William and offer him the crown. William‚Äôs conduct at first was moderate. But the insolence of his Normans‚Äî‚Äô How are you getting on now, my dear?‚Äù it continued, turning to Alice as it spoke.
‚ÄúAs wet as ever,‚Äù said Alice in a melancholy tone: ‚Äúit doesn‚Äôt seem to dry me at all.‚Äù
‚ÄúIn that case,‚Äù said the Dodo solemnly, rising to its feet, ‚ÄúI move that the meeting adjourn, for the immediate adoption of more energetic remedies‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúSpeak English!‚Äù said the Eaglet. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know the meaning of half those long words, and, what‚Äôs more, I don‚Äôt believe you do either!‚Äù And the Eaglet bent down its head to hide a smile: some of the other birds tittered audibly.
‚ÄúWhat I was going to say,‚Äù said the Dodo in an offended tone, ‚Äúwas, that the best thing to get us dry would be a Caucus-race.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat is a Caucus-race?‚Äù said Alice; not that she wanted much to know, but the Dodo had paused as if it thought that somebody ought to speak, and no one else seemed inclined to say anything.
‚ÄúWhy,‚Äù said the Dodo, ‚Äúthe best way to explain it is to do it.‚Äù (And, as you might like to try the thing yourself, some winter day, I will tell you how the Dodo managed it.)
First it marked out a race-course, in a sort of circle, (‚Äúthe exact shape doesn‚Äôt matter,‚Äù it said,) and then all the party were placed along the course, here and there. There was no ‚ÄúOne, two, three, and away,‚Äù but they began running when they liked, and left off when they liked, so that it was not easy to know when the race was over. However, when they had been running half an hour or so, and were quite dry again, the Dodo suddenly called out ‚ÄúThe race is over!‚Äù and they all crowded round it, panting, and asking, ‚ÄúBut who has won?‚Äù
This question the Dodo could not answer without a great deal of thought, and it sat for a long time with one finger pressed upon its forehead (the position in which you usually see Shakespeare, in the pictures of him), while the rest waited in silence. At last the Dodo said, ‚ÄúEverybody has won, and all must have prizes.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut who is to give the prizes?‚Äù quite a chorus of voices asked.
‚ÄúWhy, she, of course,‚Äù said the Dodo, pointing to Alice with one finger; and the whole party at once crowded round her, calling out in a confused way, ‚ÄúPrizes! Prizes!‚Äù
Alice had no idea what to do, and in despair she put her hand in her pocket, and pulled out a box of comfits, (luckily the salt water had not got into it), and handed them round as prizes. There was exactly one a-piece, all round.
‚ÄúBut she must have a prize herself, you know,‚Äù said the Mouse.
‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù the Dodo replied very gravely. ‚ÄúWhat else have you got in your pocket?‚Äù he went on, turning to Alice.
‚ÄúOnly a thimble,‚Äù said Alice sadly.
‚ÄúHand it over here,‚Äù said the Dodo.
Then they all crowded round her once more, while the Dodo solemnly presented the thimble, saying ‚ÄúWe beg your acceptance of this elegant thimble;‚Äù and, when it had finished this short speech, they all cheered.
Alice thought the whole thing very absurd, but they all looked so grave that she did not dare to laugh; and, as she could not think of anything to say, she simply bowed, and took the thimble, looking as solemn as she could.
The next thing was to eat the comfits: this caused some noise and confusion, as the large birds complained that they could not taste theirs, and the small ones choked and had to be patted on the back. However, it was over at last, and they sat down again in a ring, and begged the Mouse to tell them something more.
‚ÄúYou promised to tell me your history, you know,‚Äù said Alice, ‚Äúand why it is you hate‚ÄîC and D,‚Äù she added in a whisper, half afraid that it would be offended again.
‚ÄúMine is a long and a sad tale!‚Äù said the Mouse, turning to Alice, and sighing.
‚ÄúIt is a long tail, certainly,‚Äù said Alice, looking down with wonder at the Mouse‚Äôs tail; ‚Äúbut why do you call it sad?‚Äù And she kept on puzzling about it while the Mouse was speaking, so that her idea of the tale was something like this:‚Äî
‚ÄúFury said to a
mouse, That he
met in the
house,
‚ÄòLet us
both go to
law: I will
prosecute
YOU. ‚ÄîCome,
I‚Äôll take no
denial; We
must have a
trial: For
really this
morning I‚Äôve
nothing
to do.‚Äô
Said the
mouse to the
cur, ‚ÄòSuch
a trial,
dear Sir,
With
no jury
or judge,
would be
wasting
our
breath.‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôll be
judge, I‚Äôll
be jury,‚Äô
Said
cunning
old Fury:
‚ÄòI‚Äôll
try the
whole
cause,
and
condemn
you
to
death.‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄúYou are not attending!‚Äù said the Mouse to Alice severely. ‚ÄúWhat are you thinking of?‚Äù
‚ÄúI beg your pardon,‚Äù said Alice very humbly: ‚Äúyou had got to the fifth bend, I think?‚Äù
‚ÄúI had not!‚Äù cried the Mouse, sharply and very angrily.
‚ÄúA knot!‚Äù said Alice, always ready to make herself useful, and looking anxiously about her. ‚ÄúOh, do let me help to undo it!‚Äù
‚ÄúI shall do nothing of the sort,‚Äù said the Mouse, getting up and walking away. ‚ÄúYou insult me by talking such nonsense!‚Äù
‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt mean it!‚Äù pleaded poor Alice. ‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre so easily offended, you know!‚Äù
The Mouse only growled in reply.
‚ÄúPlease come back and finish your story!‚Äù Alice called after it; and the others all joined in chorus, ‚ÄúYes, please do!‚Äù but the Mouse only shook its head impatiently, and walked a little quicker.
‚ÄúWhat a pity it wouldn‚Äôt stay!‚Äù sighed the Lory, as soon as it was quite out of sight; and an old Crab took the opportunity of saying to her daughter ‚ÄúAh, my dear! Let this be a lesson to you never to lose your temper!‚Äù ‚ÄúHold your tongue, Ma!‚Äù said the young Crab, a little snappishly. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre enough to try the patience of an oyster!‚Äù
‚ÄúI wish I had our Dinah here, I know I do!‚Äù said Alice aloud, addressing nobody in particular. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôd soon fetch it back!‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd who is Dinah, if I might venture to ask the question?‚Äù said the Lory.
Alice replied eagerly, for she was always ready to talk about her pet: ‚ÄúDinah‚Äôs our cat. And she‚Äôs such a capital one for catching mice you can‚Äôt think! And oh, I wish you could see her after the birds! Why, she‚Äôll eat a little bird as soon as look at it!‚Äù
This speech caused a remarkable sensation among the party. Some of the birds hurried off at once: one old Magpie began wrapping itself up very carefully, remarking, ‚ÄúI really must be getting home; the night-air doesn‚Äôt suit my throat!‚Äù and a Canary called out in a trembling voice to its children, ‚ÄúCome away, my dears! It‚Äôs high time you were all in bed!‚Äù On various pretexts they all moved off, and Alice was soon left alone.
‚ÄúI wish I hadn‚Äôt mentioned Dinah!‚Äù she said to herself in a melancholy tone. ‚ÄúNobody seems to like her, down here, and I‚Äôm sure she‚Äôs the best cat in the world! Oh, my dear Dinah! I wonder if I shall ever see you any more!‚Äù And here poor Alice began to cry again, for she felt very lonely and low-spirited. In a little while, however, she again heard a little pattering of footsteps in the distance, and she looked up eagerly, half hoping that the Mouse had changed his mind, and was coming back to finish his story.

resource.label: Alice in Wonderland - Chapter 4 - The Rabbit sends in a little Bill

text-prop.name: :hasName
text-prop.text: The Rabbit sends in a little Bill

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The fanning makes her shrink again until she's only two feet tall.She tries to get in, but the door's still locked and the key's still lying on the table.Then she slips and falls into her own pool of tears.She meets a mouse who fell in too, but she scares him when she starts talking about her cat Dinah and a dog. He says he'll tell her why he hates cats and dogs, and they swim to the shore, taking other creatures that fell into the pool with them.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: Eager to explore, Alice followed RabbIT through a landscape where trees had digital screens for leaves displaying fantastical images and data streamed across the sky like shooting stars. They passed houses that changed shape and color at the occupants' whims and gardens where flowers sang melodies in harmony.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
It was the White Rabbit, trotting slowly back again, and looking anxiously about as it went, as if it had lost something; and she heard it muttering to itself ‚ÄúThe Duchess! The Duchess! Oh my dear paws! Oh my fur and whiskers! She‚Äôll get me executed, as sure as ferrets are ferrets! Where can I have dropped them, I wonder?‚Äù Alice guessed in a moment that it was looking for the fan and the pair of white kid gloves, and she very good-naturedly began hunting about for them, but they were nowhere to be seen‚Äîeverything seemed to have changed since her swim in the pool, and the great hall, with the glass table and the little door, had vanished completely.
Very soon the Rabbit noticed Alice, as she went hunting about, and called out to her in an angry tone, ‚ÄúWhy, Mary Ann, what are you doing out here? Run home this moment, and fetch me a pair of gloves and a fan! Quick, now!‚Äù And Alice was so much frightened that she ran off at once in the direction it pointed to, without trying to explain the mistake it had made.
‚ÄúHe took me for his housemaid,‚Äù she said to herself as she ran. ‚ÄúHow surprised he‚Äôll be when he finds out who I am! But I‚Äôd better take him his fan and gloves‚Äîthat is, if I can find them.‚Äù As she said this, she came upon a neat little house, on the door of which was a bright brass plate with the name ‚ÄúW. RABBIT,‚Äù engraved upon it. She went in without knocking, and hurried upstairs, in great fear lest she should meet the real Mary Ann, and be turned out of the house before she had found the fan and gloves.
‚ÄúHow queer it seems,‚Äù Alice said to herself, ‚Äúto be going messages for a rabbit! I suppose Dinah‚Äôll be sending me on messages next!‚Äù And she began fancying the sort of thing that would happen: ‚Äú‚ÄòMiss Alice! Come here directly, and get ready for your walk!‚Äô ‚ÄòComing in a minute, nurse! But I‚Äôve got to see that the mouse doesn‚Äôt get out.‚Äô Only I don‚Äôt think,‚Äù Alice went on, ‚Äúthat they‚Äôd let Dinah stop in the house if it began ordering people about like that!‚Äù
By this time she had found her way into a tidy little room with a table in the window, and on it (as she had hoped) a fan and two or three pairs of tiny white kid gloves: she took up the fan and a pair of the gloves, and was just going to leave the room, when her eye fell upon a little bottle that stood near the looking-glass. There was no label this time with the words ‚ÄúDRINK ME,‚Äù but nevertheless she uncorked it and put it to her lips. ‚ÄúI know something interesting is sure to happen,‚Äù she said to herself, ‚Äúwhenever I eat or drink anything; so I‚Äôll just see what this bottle does. I do hope it‚Äôll make me grow large again, for really I‚Äôm quite tired of being such a tiny little thing!‚Äù
It did so indeed, and much sooner than she had expected: before she had drunk half the bottle, she found her head pressing against the ceiling, and had to stoop to save her neck from being broken. She hastily put down the bottle, saying to herself ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs quite enough‚ÄîI hope I shan‚Äôt grow any more‚ÄîAs it is, I can‚Äôt get out at the door‚ÄîI do wish I hadn‚Äôt drunk quite so much!‚Äù
Alas! it was too late to wish that! She went on growing, and growing, and very soon had to kneel down on the floor: in another minute there was not even room for this, and she tried the effect of lying down with one elbow against the door, and the other arm curled round her head. Still she went on growing, and, as a last resource, she put one arm out of the window, and one foot up the chimney, and said to herself ‚ÄúNow I can do no more, whatever happens. What will become of me?‚Äù
Luckily for Alice, the little magic bottle had now had its full effect, and she grew no larger: still it was very uncomfortable, and, as there seemed to be no sort of chance of her ever getting out of the room again, no wonder she felt unhappy.
‚ÄúIt was much pleasanter at home,‚Äù thought poor Alice, ‚Äúwhen one wasn‚Äôt always growing larger and smaller, and being ordered about by mice and rabbits. I almost wish I hadn‚Äôt gone down that rabbit-hole‚Äîand yet‚Äîand yet‚Äîit‚Äôs rather curious, you know, this sort of life! I do wonder what can have happened to me! When I used to read fairy-tales, I fancied that kind of thing never happened, and now here I am in the middle of one! There ought to be a book written about me, that there ought! And when I grow up, I‚Äôll write one‚Äîbut I‚Äôm grown up now,‚Äù she added in a sorrowful tone; ‚Äúat least there‚Äôs no room to grow up any more here.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut then,‚Äù thought Alice, ‚Äúshall I never get any older than I am now? That‚Äôll be a comfort, one way‚Äînever to be an old woman‚Äîbut then‚Äîalways to have lessons to learn! Oh, I shouldn‚Äôt like that!‚Äù
‚ÄúOh, you foolish Alice!‚Äù she answered herself. ‚ÄúHow can you learn lessons in here? Why, there‚Äôs hardly room for you, and no room at all for any lesson-books!‚Äù
And so she went on, taking first one side and then the other, and making quite a conversation of it altogether; but after a few minutes she heard a voice outside, and stopped to listen.
‚ÄúMary Ann! Mary Ann!‚Äù said the voice. ‚ÄúFetch me my gloves this moment!‚Äù Then came a little pattering of feet on the stairs. Alice knew it was the Rabbit coming to look for her, and she trembled till she shook the house, quite forgetting that she was now about a thousand times as large as the Rabbit, and had no reason to be afraid of it.
Presently the Rabbit came up to the door, and tried to open it; but, as the door opened inwards, and Alice‚Äôs elbow was pressed hard against it, that attempt proved a failure. Alice heard it say to itself ‚ÄúThen I‚Äôll go round and get in at the window.‚Äù
‚ÄúThat you won‚Äôt!‚Äù thought Alice, and, after waiting till she fancied she heard the Rabbit just under the window, she suddenly spread out her hand, and made a snatch in the air. She did not get hold of anything, but she heard a little shriek and a fall, and a crash of broken glass, from which she concluded that it was just possible it had fallen into a cucumber-frame, or something of the sort.
Next came an angry voice‚Äîthe Rabbit‚Äôs‚Äî‚ÄúPat! Pat! Where are you?‚Äù And then a voice she had never heard before, ‚ÄúSure then I‚Äôm here! Digging for apples, yer honour!‚Äù
‚ÄúDigging for apples, indeed!‚Äù said the Rabbit angrily. ‚ÄúHere! Come and help me out of this!‚Äù (Sounds of more broken glass.)
‚ÄúNow tell me, Pat, what‚Äôs that in the window?‚Äù
‚ÄúSure, it‚Äôs an arm, yer honour!‚Äù (He pronounced it ‚Äúarrum.‚Äù)
‚ÄúAn arm, you goose! Who ever saw one that size? Why, it fills the whole window!‚Äù
‚ÄúSure, it does, yer honour: but it‚Äôs an arm for all that.‚Äù
‚ÄúWell, it‚Äôs got no business there, at any rate: go and take it away!‚Äù
There was a long silence after this, and Alice could only hear whispers now and then; such as, ‚ÄúSure, I don‚Äôt like it, yer honour, at all, at all!‚Äù ‚ÄúDo as I tell you, you coward!‚Äù and at last she spread out her hand again, and made another snatch in the air. This time there were two little shrieks, and more sounds of broken glass. ‚ÄúWhat a number of cucumber-frames there must be!‚Äù thought Alice. ‚ÄúI wonder what they‚Äôll do next! As for pulling me out of the window, I only wish they could! I‚Äôm sure I don‚Äôt want to stay in here any longer!‚Äù
She waited for some time without hearing anything more: at last came a rumbling of little cartwheels, and the sound of a good many voices all talking together: she made out the words: ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the other ladder?‚ÄîWhy, I hadn‚Äôt to bring but one; Bill‚Äôs got the other‚ÄîBill! fetch it here, lad!‚ÄîHere, put ‚Äôem up at this corner‚ÄîNo, tie ‚Äôem together first‚Äîthey don‚Äôt reach half high enough yet‚ÄîOh! they‚Äôll do well enough; don‚Äôt be particular‚ÄîHere, Bill! catch hold of this rope‚ÄîWill the roof bear?‚ÄîMind that loose slate‚ÄîOh, it‚Äôs coming down! Heads below!‚Äù (a loud crash)‚Äî‚ÄúNow, who did that?‚ÄîIt was Bill, I fancy‚ÄîWho‚Äôs to go down the chimney?‚ÄîNay, I shan‚Äôt! You do it!‚ÄîThat I won‚Äôt, then!‚ÄîBill‚Äôs to go down‚ÄîHere, Bill! the master says you‚Äôre to go down the chimney!‚Äù
‚ÄúOh! So Bill‚Äôs got to come down the chimney, has he?‚Äù said Alice to herself. ‚ÄúShy, they seem to put everything upon Bill! I wouldn‚Äôt be in Bill‚Äôs place for a good deal: this fireplace is narrow, to be sure; but I think I can kick a little!‚Äù
She drew her foot as far down the chimney as she could, and waited till she heard a little animal (she couldn‚Äôt guess of what sort it was) scratching and scrambling about in the chimney close above her: then, saying to herself ‚ÄúThis is Bill,‚Äù she gave one sharp kick, and waited to see what would happen next.
The first thing she heard was a general chorus of ‚ÄúThere goes Bill!‚Äù then the Rabbit‚Äôs voice along‚Äî‚ÄúCatch him, you by the hedge!‚Äù then silence, and then another confusion of voices‚Äî‚ÄúHold up his head‚ÄîBrandy now‚ÄîDon‚Äôt choke him‚ÄîHow was it, old fellow? What happened to you? Tell us all about it!‚Äù
Last came a little feeble, squeaking voice, (‚ÄúThat‚Äôs Bill,‚Äù thought Alice,) ‚ÄúWell, I hardly know‚ÄîNo more, thank ye; I‚Äôm better now‚Äîbut I‚Äôm a deal too flustered to tell you‚Äîall I know is, something comes at me like a Jack-in-the-box, and up I goes like a sky-rocket!‚Äù
‚ÄúSo you did, old fellow!‚Äù said the others.
‚ÄúWe must burn the house down!‚Äù said the Rabbit‚Äôs voice; and Alice called out as loud as she could, ‚ÄúIf you do, I‚Äôll set Dinah at you!‚Äù
There was a dead silence instantly, and Alice thought to herself, ‚ÄúI wonder what they will do next! If they had any sense, they‚Äôd take the roof off.‚Äù After a minute or two, they began moving about again, and Alice heard the Rabbit say, ‚ÄúA barrowful will do, to begin with.‚Äù
‚ÄúA barrowful of what?‚Äù thought Alice; but she had not long to doubt, for the next moment a shower of little pebbles came rattling in at the window, and some of them hit her in the face. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll put a stop to this,‚Äù she said to herself, and shouted out, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd better not do that again!‚Äù which produced another dead silence.
Alice noticed with some surprise that the pebbles were all turning into little cakes as they lay on the floor, and a bright idea came into her head. ‚ÄúIf I eat one of these cakes,‚Äù she thought, ‚Äúit‚Äôs sure to make some change in my size; and as it can‚Äôt possibly make me larger, it must make me smaller, I suppose.‚Äù
So she swallowed one of the cakes, and was delighted to find that she began shrinking directly. As soon as she was small enough to get through the door, she ran out of the house, and found quite a crowd of little animals and birds waiting outside. The poor little Lizard, Bill, was in the middle, being held up by two guinea-pigs, who were giving it something out of a bottle. They all made a rush at Alice the moment she appeared; but she ran off as hard as she could, and soon found herself safe in a thick wood.
‚ÄúThe first thing I‚Äôve got to do,‚Äù said Alice to herself, as she wandered about in the wood, ‚Äúis to grow to my right size again; and the second thing is to find my way into that lovely garden. I think that will be the best plan.‚Äù
It sounded an excellent plan, no doubt, and very neatly and simply arranged; the only difficulty was, that she had not the smallest idea how to set about it; and while she was peering about anxiously among the trees, a little sharp bark just over her head made her look up in a great hurry.
An enormous puppy was looking down at her with large round eyes, and feebly stretching out one paw, trying to touch her. ‚ÄúPoor little thing!‚Äù said Alice, in a coaxing tone, and she tried hard to whistle to it; but she was terribly frightened all the time at the thought that it might be hungry, in which case it would be very likely to eat her up in spite of all her coaxing.
Hardly knowing what she did, she picked up a little bit of stick, and held it out to the puppy; whereupon the puppy jumped into the air off all its feet at once, with a yelp of delight, and rushed at the stick, and made believe to worry it; then Alice dodged behind a great thistle, to keep herself from being run over; and the moment she appeared on the other side, the puppy made another rush at the stick, and tumbled head over heels in its hurry to get hold of it; then Alice, thinking it was very like having a game of play with a cart-horse, and expecting every moment to be trampled under its feet, ran round the thistle again; then the puppy began a series of short charges at the stick, running a very little way forwards each time and a long way back, and barking hoarsely all the while, till at last it sat down a good way off, panting, with its tongue hanging out of its mouth, and its great eyes half shut.
This seemed to Alice a good opportunity for making her escape; so she set off at once, and ran till she was quite tired and out of breath, and till the puppy‚Äôs bark sounded quite faint in the distance.
‚ÄúAnd yet what a dear little puppy it was!‚Äù said Alice, as she leant against a buttercup to rest herself, and fanned herself with one of the leaves: ‚ÄúI should have liked teaching it tricks very much, if‚Äîif I‚Äôd only been the right size to do it! Oh dear! I‚Äôd nearly forgotten that I‚Äôve got to grow up again! Let me see‚Äîhow is it to be managed? I suppose I ought to eat or drink something or other; but the great question is, what?‚Äù
The great question certainly was, what? Alice looked all round her at the flowers and the blades of grass, but she did not see anything that looked like the right thing to eat or drink under the circumstances. There was a large mushroom growing near her, about the same height as herself; and when she had looked under it, and on both sides of it, and behind it, it occurred to her that she might as well look and see what was on the top of it.
She stretched herself up on tiptoe, and peeped over the edge of the mushroom, and her eyes immediately met those of a large caterpillar, that was sitting on the top with its arms folded, quietly smoking a long hookah, and taking not the smallest notice of her or of anything else.

resource.label: Alice in Wonderland - Chapter 5 - Advice from a Caterpillar

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice meets a Caterpillar who gives her cryptic advice and a mushroom that can change her size. Alice experiments with the mushroom and adjusts her size.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: Their first stop was the Tea Time Caf√©, where a Mad Hatter, an eccentric inventor in DaSCHland, served tea that could make one shrink or grow. Alice sipped a cup marked "Grow" and instantly stretched taller than the trees. Amused and a bit startled, she laughed, marveling at the wonders of DaSCHland.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
he Caterpillar and Alice looked at each other for some time in silence: at last the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth, and addressed her in a languid, sleepy voice.
‚ÄúWho are you?‚Äù said the Caterpillar.
This was not an encouraging opening for a conversation. Alice replied, rather shyly, ‚ÄúI‚ÄîI hardly know, sir, just at present‚Äîat least I know who I was when I got up this morning, but I think I must have been changed several times since then.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat do you mean by that?‚Äù said the Caterpillar sternly. ‚ÄúExplain yourself!‚Äù
‚ÄúI can‚Äôt explain myself, I‚Äôm afraid, sir,‚Äù said Alice, ‚Äúbecause I‚Äôm not myself, you see.‚Äù
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see,‚Äù said the Caterpillar.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid I can‚Äôt put it more clearly,‚Äù Alice replied very politely, ‚Äúfor I can‚Äôt understand it myself to begin with; and being so many different sizes in a day is very confusing.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt,‚Äù said the Caterpillar.
‚ÄúWell, perhaps you haven‚Äôt found it so yet,‚Äù said Alice; ‚Äúbut when you have to turn into a chrysalis‚Äîyou will some day, you know‚Äîand then after that into a butterfly, I should think you‚Äôll feel it a little queer, won‚Äôt you?‚Äù
‚ÄúNot a bit,‚Äù said the Caterpillar.
‚ÄúWell, perhaps your feelings may be different,‚Äù said Alice; ‚Äúall I know is, it would feel very queer to me.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou!‚Äù said the Caterpillar contemptuously. ‚ÄúWho are you?‚Äù
Which brought them back again to the beginning of the conversation. Alice felt a little irritated at the Caterpillar‚Äôs making such very short remarks, and she drew herself up and said, very gravely, ‚ÄúI think, you ought to tell me who you are, first.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù said the Caterpillar.
Here was another puzzling question; and as Alice could not think of any good reason, and as the Caterpillar seemed to be in a very unpleasant state of mind, she turned away.
‚ÄúCome back!‚Äù the Caterpillar called after her. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve something important to say!‚Äù
This sounded promising, certainly: Alice turned and came back again.
‚ÄúKeep your temper,‚Äù said the Caterpillar.
‚ÄúIs that all?‚Äù said Alice, swallowing down her anger as well as she could.
‚ÄúNo,‚Äù said the Caterpillar.
Alice thought she might as well wait, as she had nothing else to do, and perhaps after all it might tell her something worth hearing. For some minutes it puffed away without speaking, but at last it unfolded its arms, took the hookah out of its mouth again, and said, ‚ÄúSo you think you‚Äôre changed, do you?‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid I am, sir,‚Äù said Alice; ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt remember things as I used‚Äîand I don‚Äôt keep the same size for ten minutes together!‚Äù
‚ÄúCan‚Äôt remember what things?‚Äù said the Caterpillar.
‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôve tried to say ‚ÄúHow doth the little busy bee,‚Äù but it all came different!‚Äù Alice replied in a very melancholy voice.
‚ÄúRepeat, ‚ÄúYou are old, Father William,‚Äô‚Äù said the Caterpillar.
Alice folded her hands, and began:‚Äî
‚ÄúYou are old, Father William,‚Äù the young man said, ‚ÄúAnd your hair has become very white; And yet you incessantly stand on your head‚Äî Do you think, at your age, it is right?‚Äù
‚ÄúIn my youth,‚Äù Father William replied to his son, ‚ÄúI feared it might injure the brain; But, now that I‚Äôm perfectly sure I have none, Why, I do it again and again.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou are old,‚Äù said the youth, ‚Äúas I mentioned before, And have grown most uncommonly fat; Yet you turned a back-somersault in at the door‚Äî Pray, what is the reason of that?‚Äù
‚ÄúIn my youth,‚Äù said the sage, as he shook his grey locks, ‚ÄúI kept all my limbs very supple By the use of this ointment‚Äîone shilling the box‚Äî Allow me to sell you a couple?‚Äù
‚ÄúYou are old,‚Äù said the youth, ‚Äúand your jaws are too weak For anything tougher than suet; Yet you finished the goose, with the bones and the beak‚Äî Pray, how did you manage to do it?‚Äù
‚ÄúIn my youth,‚Äù said his father, ‚ÄúI took to the law, And argued each case with my wife; And the muscular strength, which it gave to my jaw, Has lasted the rest of my life.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou are old,‚Äù said the youth, ‚Äúone would hardly suppose That your eye was as steady as ever; Yet you balanced an eel on the end of your nose‚Äî What made you so awfully clever?‚Äù
‚ÄúI have answered three questions, and that is enough,‚Äù Said his father; ‚Äúdon‚Äôt give yourself airs! Do you think I can listen all day to such stuff? Be off, or I‚Äôll kick you down stairs!‚Äù
‚ÄúThat is not said right,‚Äù said the Caterpillar.
‚ÄúNot quite right, I‚Äôm afraid,‚Äù said Alice, timidly; ‚Äúsome of the words have got altered.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is wrong from beginning to end,‚Äù said the Caterpillar decidedly, and there was silence for some minutes.
The Caterpillar was the first to speak.
‚ÄúWhat size do you want to be?‚Äù it asked.
‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôm not particular as to size,‚Äù Alice hastily replied; ‚Äúonly one doesn‚Äôt like changing so often, you know.‚Äù
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù said the Caterpillar.
Alice said nothing: she had never been so much contradicted in her life before, and she felt that she was losing her temper.
‚ÄúAre you content now?‚Äù said the Caterpillar.
‚ÄúWell, I should like to be a little larger, sir, if you wouldn‚Äôt mind,‚Äù said Alice: ‚Äúthree inches is such a wretched height to be.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is a very good height indeed!‚Äù said the Caterpillar angrily, rearing itself upright as it spoke (it was exactly three inches high).
‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm not used to it!‚Äù pleaded poor Alice in a piteous tone. And she thought of herself, ‚ÄúI wish the creatures wouldn‚Äôt be so easily offended!‚Äù
‚ÄúYou‚Äôll get used to it in time,‚Äù said the Caterpillar; and it put the hookah into its mouth and began smoking again.
This time Alice waited patiently until it chose to speak again. In a minute or two the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth and yawned once or twice, and shook itself. Then it got down off the mushroom, and crawled away in the grass, merely remarking as it went, ‚ÄúOne side will make you grow taller, and the other side will make you grow shorter.‚Äù
‚ÄúOne side of what? The other side of what?‚Äù thought Alice to herself.
‚ÄúOf the mushroom,‚Äù said the Caterpillar, just as if she had asked it aloud; and in another moment it was out of sight.
Alice remained looking thoughtfully at the mushroom for a minute, trying to make out which were the two sides of it; and as it was perfectly round, she found this a very difficult question. However, at last she stretched her arms round it as far as they would go, and broke off a bit of the edge with each hand.
‚ÄúAnd now which is which?‚Äù she said to herself, and nibbled a little of the right-hand bit to try the effect: the next moment she felt a violent blow underneath her chin: it had struck her foot!
She was a good deal frightened by this very sudden change, but she felt that there was no time to be lost, as she was shrinking rapidly; so she set to work at once to eat some of the other bit. Her chin was pressed so closely against her foot, that there was hardly room to open her mouth; but she did it at last, and managed to swallow a morsel of the lefthand bit.
* * * * * * *
* * * * * *
* * * * * * *
‚ÄúCome, my head‚Äôs free at last!‚Äù said Alice in a tone of delight, which changed into alarm in another moment, when she found that her shoulders were nowhere to be found: all she could see, when she looked down, was an immense length of neck, which seemed to rise like a stalk out of a sea of green leaves that lay far below her.
‚ÄúWhat can all that green stuff be?‚Äù said Alice. ‚ÄúAnd where have my shoulders got to? And oh, my poor hands, how is it I can‚Äôt see you?‚Äù She was moving them about as she spoke, but no result seemed to follow, except a little shaking among the distant green leaves.
As there seemed to be no chance of getting her hands up to her head, she tried to get her head down to them, and was delighted to find that her neck would bend about easily in any direction, like a serpent. She had just succeeded in curving it down into a graceful zigzag, and was going to dive in among the leaves, which she found to be nothing but the tops of the trees under which she had been wandering, when a sharp hiss made her draw back in a hurry: a large pigeon had flown into her face, and was beating her violently with its wings.
‚ÄúSerpent!‚Äù screamed the Pigeon.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a serpent!‚Äù said Alice indignantly. ‚ÄúLet me alone!‚Äù
‚ÄúSerpent, I say again!‚Äù repeated the Pigeon, but in a more subdued tone, and added with a kind of sob, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve tried every way, and nothing seems to suit them!‚Äù
‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt the least idea what you‚Äôre talking about,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve tried the roots of trees, and I‚Äôve tried banks, and I‚Äôve tried hedges,‚Äù the Pigeon went on, without attending to her; ‚Äúbut those serpents! There‚Äôs no pleasing them!‚Äù
Alice was more and more puzzled, but she thought there was no use in saying anything more till the Pigeon had finished.
‚ÄúAs if it wasn‚Äôt trouble enough hatching the eggs,‚Äù said the Pigeon; ‚Äúbut I must be on the look-out for serpents night and day! Why, I haven‚Äôt had a wink of sleep these three weeks!‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm very sorry you‚Äôve been annoyed,‚Äù said Alice, who was beginning to see its meaning.
‚ÄúAnd just as I‚Äôd taken the highest tree in the wood,‚Äù continued the Pigeon, raising its voice to a shriek, ‚Äúand just as I was thinking I should be free of them at last, they must needs come wriggling down from the sky! Ugh, Serpent!‚Äù
‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm not a serpent, I tell you!‚Äù said Alice. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a‚ÄîI‚Äôm a‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúWell! What are you?‚Äù said the Pigeon. ‚ÄúI can see you‚Äôre trying to invent something!‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚ÄîI‚Äôm a little girl,‚Äù said Alice, rather doubtfully, as she remembered the number of changes she had gone through that day.
‚ÄúA likely story indeed!‚Äù said the Pigeon in a tone of the deepest contempt. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen a good many little girls in my time, but never one with such a neck as that! No, no! You‚Äôre a serpent; and there‚Äôs no use denying it. I suppose you‚Äôll be telling me next that you never tasted an egg!‚Äù
‚ÄúI have tasted eggs, certainly,‚Äù said Alice, who was a very truthful child; ‚Äúbut little girls eat eggs quite as much as serpents do, you know.‚Äù
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe it,‚Äù said the Pigeon; ‚Äúbut if they do, why then they‚Äôre a kind of serpent, that‚Äôs all I can say.‚Äù
This was such a new idea to Alice, that she was quite silent for a minute or two, which gave the Pigeon the opportunity of adding, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre looking for eggs, I know that well enough; and what does it matter to me whether you‚Äôre a little girl or a serpent?‚Äù
‚ÄúIt matters a good deal to me,‚Äù said Alice hastily; ‚Äúbut I‚Äôm not looking for eggs, as it happens; and if I was, I shouldn‚Äôt want yours: I don‚Äôt like them raw.‚Äù
‚ÄúWell, be off, then!‚Äù said the Pigeon in a sulky tone, as it settled down again into its nest. Alice crouched down among the trees as well as she could, for her neck kept getting entangled among the branches, and every now and then she had to stop and untwist it. After a while she remembered that she still held the pieces of mushroom in her hands, and she set to work very carefully, nibbling first at one and then at the other, and growing sometimes taller and sometimes shorter, until she had succeeded in bringing herself down to her usual height.
It was so long since she had been anything near the right size, that it felt quite strange at first; but she got used to it in a few minutes, and began talking to herself, as usual. ‚ÄúCome, there‚Äôs half my plan done now! How puzzling all these changes are! I‚Äôm never sure what I‚Äôm going to be, from one minute to another! However, I‚Äôve got back to my right size: the next thing is, to get into that beautiful garden‚Äîhow is that to be done, I wonder?‚Äù As she said this, she came suddenly upon an open place, with a little house in it about four feet high. ‚ÄúWhoever lives there,‚Äù thought Alice, ‚Äúit‚Äôll never do to come upon them this size: why, I should frighten them out of their wits!‚Äù So she began nibbling at the righthand bit again, and did not venture to go near the house till she had brought herself down to nine inches high.

resource.label: Alice in Wonderland - Chapter 6 - Pig and Pepper

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice visits the Duchess's house, where she encounters a chaotic scene involving the Duchess, a baby that turns into a pig, and the grinning Cheshire Cat, who tells her about the Mad Hatter and the March Hare.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: Next, they visited the Queen of Hearts, who was not a queen of cards but a brilliant engineer leading the Hearts Division, specializing in creating technologies that connected emotions with devices. The Queen showed Alice a mirror that didn't just reflect one's image but also displayed one‚Äôs innermost feelings and thoughts.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
For a minute or two she stood looking at the house, and wondering what to do next, when suddenly a footman in livery came running out of the wood‚Äî(she considered him to be a footman because he was in livery: otherwise, judging by his face only, she would have called him a fish)‚Äîand rapped loudly at the door with his knuckles. It was opened by another footman in livery, with a round face, and large eyes like a frog; and both footmen, Alice noticed, had powdered hair that curled all over their heads. She felt very curious to know what it was all about, and crept a little way out of the wood to listen.
The Fish-Footman began by producing from under his arm a great letter, nearly as large as himself, and this he handed over to the other, saying, in a solemn tone, ‚ÄúFor the Duchess. An invitation from the Queen to play croquet.‚Äù The Frog-Footman repeated, in the same solemn tone, only changing the order of the words a little, ‚ÄúFrom the Queen. An invitation for the Duchess to play croquet.‚Äù
Then they both bowed low, and their curls got entangled together.
Alice laughed so much at this, that she had to run back into the wood for fear of their hearing her; and when she next peeped out the Fish-Footman was gone, and the other was sitting on the ground near the door, staring stupidly up into the sky.
Alice went timidly up to the door, and knocked.
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no sort of use in knocking,‚Äù said the Footman, ‚Äúand that for two reasons. First, because I‚Äôm on the same side of the door as you are; secondly, because they‚Äôre making such a noise inside, no one could possibly hear you.‚Äù And certainly there was a most extraordinary noise going on within‚Äîa constant howling and sneezing, and every now and then a great crash, as if a dish or kettle had been broken to pieces.
‚ÄúPlease, then,‚Äù said Alice, ‚Äúhow am I to get in?‚Äù
‚ÄúThere might be some sense in your knocking,‚Äù the Footman went on without attending to her, ‚Äúif we had the door between us. For instance, if you were inside, you might knock, and I could let you out, you know.‚Äù He was looking up into the sky all the time he was speaking, and this Alice thought decidedly uncivil. ‚ÄúBut perhaps he can‚Äôt help it,‚Äù she said to herself; ‚Äúhis eyes are so very nearly at the top of his head. But at any rate he might answer questions.‚ÄîHow am I to get in?‚Äù she repeated, aloud.
‚ÄúI shall sit here,‚Äù the Footman remarked, ‚Äútill tomorrow‚Äî‚Äù
At this moment the door of the house opened, and a large plate came skimming out, straight at the Footman‚Äôs head: it just grazed his nose, and broke to pieces against one of the trees behind him.
‚Äú‚Äîor next day, maybe,‚Äù the Footman continued in the same tone, exactly as if nothing had happened.
‚ÄúHow am I to get in?‚Äù asked Alice again, in a louder tone.
‚ÄúAre you to get in at all?‚Äù said the Footman. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the first question, you know.‚Äù
It was, no doubt: only Alice did not like to be told so. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really dreadful,‚Äù she muttered to herself, ‚Äúthe way all the creatures argue. It‚Äôs enough to drive one crazy!‚Äù
The Footman seemed to think this a good opportunity for repeating his remark, with variations. ‚ÄúI shall sit here,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúon and off, for days and days.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut what am I to do?‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúAnything you like,‚Äù said the Footman, and began whistling.
‚ÄúOh, there‚Äôs no use in talking to him,‚Äù said Alice desperately: ‚Äúhe‚Äôs perfectly idiotic!‚Äù And she opened the door and went in.
The door led right into a large kitchen, which was full of smoke from one end to the other: the Duchess was sitting on a three-legged stool in the middle, nursing a baby; the cook was leaning over the fire, stirring a large cauldron which seemed to be full of soup.
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs certainly too much pepper in that soup!‚Äù Alice said to herself, as well as she could for sneezing.
There was certainly too much of it in the air. Even the Duchess sneezed occasionally; and as for the baby, it was sneezing and howling alternately without a moment‚Äôs pause. The only things in the kitchen that did not sneeze, were the cook, and a large cat which was sitting on the hearth and grinning from ear to ear.
‚ÄúPlease would you tell me,‚Äù said Alice, a little timidly, for she was not quite sure whether it was good manners for her to speak first, ‚Äúwhy your cat grins like that?‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a Cheshire cat,‚Äù said the Duchess, ‚Äúand that‚Äôs why. Pig!‚Äù
She said the last word with such sudden violence that Alice quite jumped; but she saw in another moment that it was addressed to the baby, and not to her, so she took courage, and went on again:‚Äî
‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know that Cheshire cats always grinned; in fact, I didn‚Äôt know that cats could grin.‚Äù
‚ÄúThey all can,‚Äù said the Duchess; ‚Äúand most of ‚Äôem do.‚Äù
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know of any that do,‚Äù Alice said very politely, feeling quite pleased to have got into a conversation.
‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know much,‚Äù said the Duchess; ‚Äúand that‚Äôs a fact.‚Äù
Alice did not at all like the tone of this remark, and thought it would be as well to introduce some other subject of conversation. While she was trying to fix on one, the cook took the cauldron of soup off the fire, and at once set to work throwing everything within her reach at the Duchess and the baby‚Äîthe fire-irons came first; then followed a shower of saucepans, plates, and dishes. The Duchess took no notice of them even when they hit her; and the baby was howling so much already, that it was quite impossible to say whether the blows hurt it or not.
‚ÄúOh, please mind what you‚Äôre doing!‚Äù cried Alice, jumping up and down in an agony of terror. ‚ÄúOh, there goes his precious nose!‚Äù as an unusually large saucepan flew close by it, and very nearly carried it off.
‚ÄúIf everybody minded their own business,‚Äù the Duchess said in a hoarse growl, ‚Äúthe world would go round a deal faster than it does.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhich would not be an advantage,‚Äù said Alice, who felt very glad to get an opportunity of showing off a little of her knowledge. ‚ÄúJust think of what work it would make with the day and night! You see the earth takes twenty-four hours to turn round on its axis‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúTalking of axes,‚Äù said the Duchess, ‚Äúchop off her head!‚Äù
Alice glanced rather anxiously at the cook, to see if she meant to take the hint; but the cook was busily stirring the soup, and seemed not to be listening, so she went on again: ‚ÄúTwenty-four hours, I think; or is it twelve? I‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúOh, don‚Äôt bother me,‚Äù said the Duchess; ‚ÄúI never could abide figures!‚Äù And with that she began nursing her child again, singing a sort of lullaby to it as she did so, and giving it a violent shake at the end of every line:
‚ÄúSpeak roughly to your little boy, And beat him when he sneezes: He only does it to annoy, Because he knows it teases.‚Äù
CHORUS (In which the cook and the baby joined): ‚ÄúWow! wow! wow!‚Äù
While the Duchess sang the second verse of the song, she kept tossing the baby violently up and down, and the poor little thing howled so, that Alice could hardly hear the words:‚Äî
‚ÄúI speak severely to my boy, I beat him when he sneezes; For he can thoroughly enjoy The pepper when he pleases!‚Äù
CHORUS ‚ÄúWow! wow! wow!‚Äù
‚ÄúHere! you may nurse it a bit, if you like!‚Äù the Duchess said to Alice, flinging the baby at her as she spoke. ‚ÄúI must go and get ready to play croquet with the Queen,‚Äù and she hurried out of the room. The cook threw a frying-pan after her as she went out, but it just missed her.
Alice caught the baby with some difficulty, as it was a queer-shaped little creature, and held out its arms and legs in all directions, ‚Äújust like a star-fish,‚Äù thought Alice. The poor little thing was snorting like a steam-engine when she caught it, and kept doubling itself up and straightening itself out again, so that altogether, for the first minute or two, it was as much as she could do to hold it.
As soon as she had made out the proper way of nursing it, (which was to twist it up into a sort of knot, and then keep tight hold of its right ear and left foot, so as to prevent its undoing itself,) she carried it out into the open air. ‚ÄúIf I don‚Äôt take this child away with me,‚Äù thought Alice, ‚Äúthey‚Äôre sure to kill it in a day or two: wouldn‚Äôt it be murder to leave it behind?‚Äù She said the last words out loud, and the little thing grunted in reply (it had left off sneezing by this time). ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt grunt,‚Äù said Alice; ‚Äúthat‚Äôs not at all a proper way of expressing yourself.‚Äù
The baby grunted again, and Alice looked very anxiously into its face to see what was the matter with it. There could be no doubt that it had a very turn-up nose, much more like a snout than a real nose; also its eyes were getting extremely small for a baby: altogether Alice did not like the look of the thing at all. ‚ÄúBut perhaps it was only sobbing,‚Äù she thought, and looked into its eyes again, to see if there were any tears.
No, there were no tears. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre going to turn into a pig, my dear,‚Äù said Alice, seriously, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll have nothing more to do with you. Mind now!‚Äù The poor little thing sobbed again (or grunted, it was impossible to say which), and they went on for some while in silence.
Alice was just beginning to think to herself, ‚ÄúNow, what am I to do with this creature when I get it home?‚Äù when it grunted again, so violently, that she looked down into its face in some alarm. This time there could be no mistake about it: it was neither more nor less than a pig, and she felt that it would be quite absurd for her to carry it further.
So she set the little creature down, and felt quite relieved to see it trot away quietly into the wood. ‚ÄúIf it had grown up,‚Äù she said to herself, ‚Äúit would have made a dreadfully ugly child: but it makes rather a handsome pig, I think.‚Äù And she began thinking over other children she knew, who might do very well as pigs, and was just saying to herself, ‚Äúif one only knew the right way to change them‚Äî‚Äù when she was a little startled by seeing the Cheshire Cat sitting on a bough of a tree a few yards off.
