The Cat only grinned when it saw Alice. It looked good-natured, she thought: still it had very long claws and a great many teeth, so she felt that it ought to be treated with respect.
‚ÄúCheshire Puss,‚Äù she began, rather timidly, as she did not at all know whether it would like the name: however, it only grinned a little wider. ‚ÄúCome, it‚Äôs pleased so far,‚Äù thought Alice, and she went on. ‚ÄúWould you tell me, please, which way I ought to go from here?‚Äù
‚ÄúThat depends a good deal on where you want to get to,‚Äù said the Cat.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt much care where‚Äî‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúThen it doesn‚Äôt matter which way you go,‚Äù said the Cat.
‚Äú‚Äîso long as I get somewhere,‚Äù Alice added as an explanation.
‚ÄúOh, you‚Äôre sure to do that,‚Äù said the Cat, ‚Äúif you only walk long enough.‚Äù
Alice felt that this could not be denied, so she tried another question. ‚ÄúWhat sort of people live about here?‚Äù
‚ÄúIn that direction,‚Äù the Cat said, waving its right paw round, ‚Äúlives a Hatter: and in that direction,‚Äù waving the other paw, ‚Äúlives a March Hare. Visit either you like: they‚Äôre both mad.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt want to go among mad people,‚Äù Alice remarked.
‚ÄúOh, you can‚Äôt help that,‚Äù said the Cat: ‚Äúwe‚Äôre all mad here. I‚Äôm mad. You‚Äôre mad.‚Äù
‚ÄúHow do you know I‚Äôm mad?‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúYou must be,‚Äù said the Cat, ‚Äúor you wouldn‚Äôt have come here.‚Äù
Alice didn‚Äôt think that proved it at all; however, she went on ‚ÄúAnd how do you know that you‚Äôre mad?‚Äù
‚ÄúTo begin with,‚Äù said the Cat, ‚Äúa dog‚Äôs not mad. You grant that?‚Äù
‚ÄúI suppose so,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúWell, then,‚Äù the Cat went on, ‚Äúyou see, a dog growls when it‚Äôs angry, and wags its tail when it‚Äôs pleased. Now I growl when I‚Äôm pleased, and wag my tail when I‚Äôm angry. Therefore I‚Äôm mad.‚Äù
‚ÄúI call it purring, not growling,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúCall it what you like,‚Äù said the Cat. ‚ÄúDo you play croquet with the Queen to-day?‚Äù
‚ÄúI should like it very much,‚Äù said Alice, ‚Äúbut I haven‚Äôt been invited yet.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou‚Äôll see me there,‚Äù said the Cat, and vanished.
Alice was not much surprised at this, she was getting so used to queer things happening. While she was looking at the place where it had been, it suddenly appeared again.
‚ÄúBy-the-bye, what became of the baby?‚Äù said the Cat. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd nearly forgotten to ask.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt turned into a pig,‚Äù Alice quietly said, just as if it had come back in a natural way.
‚ÄúI thought it would,‚Äù said the Cat, and vanished again.
Alice waited a little, half expecting to see it again, but it did not appear, and after a minute or two she walked on in the direction in which the March Hare was said to live. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen hatters before,‚Äù she said to herself; ‚Äúthe March Hare will be much the most interesting, and perhaps as this is May it won‚Äôt be raving mad‚Äîat least not so mad as it was in March.‚Äù As she said this, she looked up, and there was the Cat again, sitting on a branch of a tree.
‚ÄúDid you say pig, or fig?‚Äù said the Cat.
‚ÄúI said pig,‚Äù replied Alice; ‚Äúand I wish you wouldn‚Äôt keep appearing and vanishing so suddenly: you make one quite giddy.‚Äù
‚ÄúAll right,‚Äù said the Cat; and this time it vanished quite slowly, beginning with the end of the tail, and ending with the grin, which remained some time after the rest of it had gone.
‚ÄúWell! I‚Äôve often seen a cat without a grin,‚Äù thought Alice; ‚Äúbut a grin without a cat! It‚Äôs the most curious thing I ever saw in my life!‚Äù
She had not gone much farther before she came in sight of the house of the March Hare: she thought it must be the right house, because the chimneys were shaped like ears and the roof was thatched with fur. It was so large a house, that she did not like to go nearer till she had nibbled some more of the lefthand bit of mushroom, and raised herself to about two feet high: even then she walked up towards it rather timidly, saying to herself ‚ÄúSuppose it should be raving mad after all! I almost wish I‚Äôd gone to see the Hatter instead!‚Äù

resource.label: Alice in Wonderland - Chapter 7 - A Mad Tea-Party

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice attends a nonsensical tea party with the Mad Hatter, the March Hare, and the Dormouse. The characters engage in illogical conversations and absurd behavior, frustrating Alice.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: As the day turned to dusk, RabbIT led Alice to the Grand Library, a vast, spiraling tower filled with books that whispered their stories aloud, eager to be heard. Here, Alice learned the history of DaSCHland, how it was built by dreamers and thinkers, innovators and creators, all powered by the visionary company DaSCH, dedicated to bringing humanities data to life.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it: a Dormouse was sitting between them, fast asleep, and the other two were using it as a cushion, resting their elbows on it, and talking over its head. ‚ÄúVery uncomfortable for the Dormouse,‚Äù thought Alice; ‚Äúonly, as it‚Äôs asleep, I suppose it doesn‚Äôt mind.‚Äù
The table was a large one, but the three were all crowded together at one corner of it: ‚ÄúNo room! No room!‚Äù they cried out when they saw Alice coming. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs plenty of room!‚Äù said Alice indignantly, and she sat down in a large arm-chair at one end of the table.
‚ÄúHave some wine,‚Äù the March Hare said in an encouraging tone.
Alice looked all round the table, but there was nothing on it but tea. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see any wine,‚Äù she remarked.
‚ÄúThere isn‚Äôt any,‚Äù said the March Hare.
‚ÄúThen it wasn‚Äôt very civil of you to offer it,‚Äù said Alice angrily.
‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt very civil of you to sit down without being invited,‚Äù said the March Hare.
‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know it was your table,‚Äù said Alice; ‚Äúit‚Äôs laid for a great many more than three.‚Äù
‚ÄúYour hair wants cutting,‚Äù said the Hatter. He had been looking at Alice for some time with great curiosity, and this was his first speech.
‚ÄúYou should learn not to make personal remarks,‚Äù Alice said with some severity; ‚Äúit‚Äôs very rude.‚Äù
The Hatter opened his eyes very wide on hearing this; but all he said was, ‚ÄúWhy is a raven like a writing-desk?‚Äù
‚ÄúCome, we shall have some fun now!‚Äù thought Alice. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad they‚Äôve begun asking riddles.‚ÄîI believe I can guess that,‚Äù she added aloud.
‚ÄúDo you mean that you think you can find out the answer to it?‚Äù said the March Hare.
‚ÄúExactly so,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúThen you should say what you mean,‚Äù the March Hare went on.
‚ÄúI do,‚Äù Alice hastily replied; ‚Äúat least‚Äîat least I mean what I say‚Äîthat‚Äôs the same thing, you know.‚Äù
‚ÄúNot the same thing a bit!‚Äù said the Hatter. ‚ÄúYou might just as well say that ‚ÄòI see what I eat‚Äô is the same thing as ‚ÄòI eat what I see‚Äô!‚Äù
‚ÄúYou might just as well say,‚Äù added the March Hare, ‚Äúthat ‚ÄòI like what I get‚Äô is the same thing as ‚ÄòI get what I like‚Äô!‚Äù
‚ÄúYou might just as well say,‚Äù added the Dormouse, who seemed to be talking in his sleep, ‚Äúthat ‚ÄòI breathe when I sleep‚Äô is the same thing as ‚ÄòI sleep when I breathe‚Äô!‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is the same thing with you,‚Äù said the Hatter, and here the conversation dropped, and the party sat silent for a minute, while Alice thought over all she could remember about ravens and writing-desks, which wasn‚Äôt much.
The Hatter was the first to break the silence. ‚ÄúWhat day of the month is it?‚Äù he said, turning to Alice: he had taken his watch out of his pocket, and was looking at it uneasily, shaking it every now and then, and holding it to his ear.
Alice considered a little, and then said ‚ÄúThe fourth.‚Äù
‚ÄúTwo days wrong!‚Äù sighed the Hatter. ‚ÄúI told you butter wouldn‚Äôt suit the works!‚Äù he added looking angrily at the March Hare.
‚ÄúIt was the best butter,‚Äù the March Hare meekly replied.
‚ÄúYes, but some crumbs must have got in as well,‚Äù the Hatter grumbled: ‚Äúyou shouldn‚Äôt have put it in with the bread-knife.‚Äù
The March Hare took the watch and looked at it gloomily: then he dipped it into his cup of tea, and looked at it again: but he could think of nothing better to say than his first remark, ‚ÄúIt was the best butter, you know.‚Äù
Alice had been looking over his shoulder with some curiosity. ‚ÄúWhat a funny watch!‚Äù she remarked. ‚ÄúIt tells the day of the month, and doesn‚Äôt tell what o‚Äôclock it is!‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy should it?‚Äù muttered the Hatter. ‚ÄúDoes your watch tell you what year it is?‚Äù
‚ÄúOf course not,‚Äù Alice replied very readily: ‚Äúbut that‚Äôs because it stays the same year for such a long time together.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhich is just the case with mine,‚Äù said the Hatter.
Alice felt dreadfully puzzled. The Hatter‚Äôs remark seemed to have no sort of meaning in it, and yet it was certainly English. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt quite understand you,‚Äù she said, as politely as she could.
‚ÄúThe Dormouse is asleep again,‚Äù said the Hatter, and he poured a little hot tea upon its nose.
The Dormouse shook its head impatiently, and said, without opening its eyes, ‚ÄúOf course, of course; just what I was going to remark myself.‚Äù
‚ÄúHave you guessed the riddle yet?‚Äù the Hatter said, turning to Alice again.
‚ÄúNo, I give it up,‚Äù Alice replied: ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs the answer?‚Äù
‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt the slightest idea,‚Äù said the Hatter.
‚ÄúNor I,‚Äù said the March Hare.
Alice sighed wearily. ‚ÄúI think you might do something better with the time,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúthan waste it in asking riddles that have no answers.‚Äù
‚ÄúIf you knew Time as well as I do,‚Äù said the Hatter, ‚Äúyou wouldn‚Äôt talk about wasting it. It‚Äôs him.‚Äù
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what you mean,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúOf course you don‚Äôt!‚Äù the Hatter said, tossing his head contemptuously. ‚ÄúI dare say you never even spoke to Time!‚Äù
‚ÄúPerhaps not,‚Äù Alice cautiously replied: ‚Äúbut I know I have to beat time when I learn music.‚Äù
‚ÄúAh! that accounts for it,‚Äù said the Hatter. ‚ÄúHe won‚Äôt stand beating. Now, if you only kept on good terms with him, he‚Äôd do almost anything you liked with the clock. For instance, suppose it were nine o‚Äôclock in the morning, just time to begin lessons: you‚Äôd only have to whisper a hint to Time, and round goes the clock in a twinkling! Half-past one, time for dinner!‚Äù
(‚ÄúI only wish it was,‚Äù the March Hare said to itself in a whisper.)
‚ÄúThat would be grand, certainly,‚Äù said Alice thoughtfully: ‚Äúbut then‚ÄîI shouldn‚Äôt be hungry for it, you know.‚Äù
‚ÄúNot at first, perhaps,‚Äù said the Hatter: ‚Äúbut you could keep it to half-past one as long as you liked.‚Äù
‚ÄúIs that the way you manage?‚Äù Alice asked.
The Hatter shook his head mournfully. ‚ÄúNot I!‚Äù he replied. ‚ÄúWe quarrelled last March‚Äîjust before he went mad, you know‚Äî‚Äù (pointing with his tea spoon at the March Hare,) ‚Äú‚Äîit was at the great concert given by the Queen of Hearts, and I had to sing
‚ÄòTwinkle, twinkle, little bat! How I wonder what you‚Äôre at!‚Äô
You know the song, perhaps?‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard something like it,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúIt goes on, you know,‚Äù the Hatter continued, ‚Äúin this way:‚Äî
‚ÄòUp above the world you fly, Like a tea-tray in the sky. Twinkle, twinkle‚Äî‚Äô‚Äù
Here the Dormouse shook itself, and began singing in its sleep ‚ÄúTwinkle, twinkle, twinkle, twinkle‚Äî‚Äù and went on so long that they had to pinch it to make it stop.
‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôd hardly finished the first verse,‚Äù said the Hatter, ‚Äúwhen the Queen jumped up and bawled out, ‚ÄòHe‚Äôs murdering the time! Off with his head!‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄúHow dreadfully savage!‚Äù exclaimed Alice.
‚ÄúAnd ever since that,‚Äù the Hatter went on in a mournful tone, ‚Äúhe won‚Äôt do a thing I ask! It‚Äôs always six o‚Äôclock now.‚Äù
A bright idea came into Alice‚Äôs head. ‚ÄúIs that the reason so many tea-things are put out here?‚Äù she asked.
‚ÄúYes, that‚Äôs it,‚Äù said the Hatter with a sigh: ‚Äúit‚Äôs always tea-time, and we‚Äôve no time to wash the things between whiles.‚Äù
‚ÄúThen you keep moving round, I suppose?‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúExactly so,‚Äù said the Hatter: ‚Äúas the things get used up.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut what happens when you come to the beginning again?‚Äù Alice ventured to ask.
‚ÄúSuppose we change the subject,‚Äù the March Hare interrupted, yawning. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm getting tired of this. I vote the young lady tells us a story.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid I don‚Äôt know one,‚Äù said Alice, rather alarmed at the proposal.
‚ÄúThen the Dormouse shall!‚Äù they both cried. ‚ÄúWake up, Dormouse!‚Äù And they pinched it on both sides at once.
The Dormouse slowly opened his eyes. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt asleep,‚Äù he said in a hoarse, feeble voice: ‚ÄúI heard every word you fellows were saying.‚Äù
‚ÄúTell us a story!‚Äù said the March Hare.
‚ÄúYes, please do!‚Äù pleaded Alice.
‚ÄúAnd be quick about it,‚Äù added the Hatter, ‚Äúor you‚Äôll be asleep again before it‚Äôs done.‚Äù
‚ÄúOnce upon a time there were three little sisters,‚Äù the Dormouse began in a great hurry; ‚Äúand their names were Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie; and they lived at the bottom of a well‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat did they live on?‚Äù said Alice, who always took a great interest in questions of eating and drinking.
‚ÄúThey lived on treacle,‚Äù said the Dormouse, after thinking a minute or two.
‚ÄúThey couldn‚Äôt have done that, you know,‚Äù Alice gently remarked; ‚Äúthey‚Äôd have been ill.‚Äù
‚ÄúSo they were,‚Äù said the Dormouse; ‚Äúvery ill.‚Äù
Alice tried to fancy to herself what such an extraordinary ways of living would be like, but it puzzled her too much, so she went on: ‚ÄúBut why did they live at the bottom of a well?‚Äù
‚ÄúTake some more tea,‚Äù the March Hare said to Alice, very earnestly.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve had nothing yet,‚Äù Alice replied in an offended tone, ‚Äúso I can‚Äôt take more.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou mean you can‚Äôt take less,‚Äù said the Hatter: ‚Äúit‚Äôs very easy to take more than nothing.‚Äù
‚ÄúNobody asked your opinion,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúWho‚Äôs making personal remarks now?‚Äù the Hatter asked triumphantly.
Alice did not quite know what to say to this: so she helped herself to some tea and bread-and-butter, and then turned to the Dormouse, and repeated her question. ‚ÄúWhy did they live at the bottom of a well?‚Äù
The Dormouse again took a minute or two to think about it, and then said, ‚ÄúIt was a treacle-well.‚Äù
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no such thing!‚Äù Alice was beginning very angrily, but the Hatter and the March Hare went ‚ÄúSh! sh!‚Äù and the Dormouse sulkily remarked, ‚ÄúIf you can‚Äôt be civil, you‚Äôd better finish the story for yourself.‚Äù
‚ÄúNo, please go on!‚Äù Alice said very humbly; ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt interrupt again. I dare say there may be one.‚Äù
‚ÄúOne, indeed!‚Äù said the Dormouse indignantly. However, he consented to go on. ‚ÄúAnd so these three little sisters‚Äîthey were learning to draw, you know‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat did they draw?‚Äù said Alice, quite forgetting her promise.
‚ÄúTreacle,‚Äù said the Dormouse, without considering at all this time.
‚ÄúI want a clean cup,‚Äù interrupted the Hatter: ‚Äúlet‚Äôs all move one place on.‚Äù
He moved on as he spoke, and the Dormouse followed him: the March Hare moved into the Dormouse‚Äôs place, and Alice rather unwillingly took the place of the March Hare. The Hatter was the only one who got any advantage from the change: and Alice was a good deal worse off than before, as the March Hare had just upset the milk-jug into his plate.
Alice did not wish to offend the Dormouse again, so she began very cautiously: ‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt understand. Where did they draw the treacle from?‚Äù
‚ÄúYou can draw water out of a water-well,‚Äù said the Hatter; ‚Äúso I should think you could draw treacle out of a treacle-well‚Äîeh, stupid?‚Äù
‚ÄúBut they were in the well,‚Äù Alice said to the Dormouse, not choosing to notice this last remark.
‚ÄúOf course they were,‚Äù said the Dormouse; ‚Äú‚Äîwell in.‚Äù
This answer so confused poor Alice, that she let the Dormouse go on for some time without interrupting it.
‚ÄúThey were learning to draw,‚Äù the Dormouse went on, yawning and rubbing its eyes, for it was getting very sleepy; ‚Äúand they drew all manner of things‚Äîeverything that begins with an M‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy with an M?‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù said the March Hare.
Alice was silent.
The Dormouse had closed its eyes by this time, and was going off into a doze; but, on being pinched by the Hatter, it woke up again with a little shriek, and went on: ‚Äú‚Äîthat begins with an M, such as mouse-traps, and the moon, and memory, and muchness‚Äîyou know you say things are ‚Äúmuch of a muchness‚Äù‚Äîdid you ever see such a thing as a drawing of a muchness?‚Äù
‚ÄúReally, now you ask me,‚Äù said Alice, very much confused, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúThen you shouldn‚Äôt talk,‚Äù said the Hatter.
This piece of rudeness was more than Alice could bear: she got up in great disgust, and walked off; the Dormouse fell asleep instantly, and neither of the others took the least notice of her going, though she looked back once or twice, half hoping that they would call after her: the last time she saw them, they were trying to put the Dormouse into the teapot.
‚ÄúAt any rate I‚Äôll never go there again!‚Äù said Alice as she picked her way through the wood. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the stupidest tea-party I ever was at in all my life!‚Äù
Just as she said this, she noticed that one of the trees had a door leading right into it. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs very curious!‚Äù she thought. ‚ÄúBut everything‚Äôs curious today. I think I may as well go in at once.‚Äù And in she went.
Once more she found herself in the long hall, and close to the little glass table. ‚ÄúNow, I‚Äôll manage better this time,‚Äù she said to herself, and began by taking the little golden key, and unlocking the door that led into the garden. Then she went to work nibbling at the mushroom (she had kept a piece of it in her pocket) till she was about a foot high: then she walked down the little passage: and then‚Äîshe found herself at last in the beautiful garden, among the bright flower-beds and the cool fountains.

resource.label: Alice in Wonderland - Chapter 8 - The Queen‚Äôs Croquet-Ground

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice enters the Queen's garden and witnesses the playing cards painting white roses red. She meets the Queen of Hearts, who invites her to play a bizarre game of croquet with flamingos and hedgehogs.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: But soon, the sky darkened, and a soft voice whispered that it was time for Alice to return to her world. Reluctantly, Alice followed RabbIT back to the rabbit hole. "You must return, but remember that DaSCHland is always here, waiting for your return. Keep dreaming and wondering," RabbIT said as Alice climbed out of the hole.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily painting them red. Alice thought this a very curious thing, and she went nearer to watch them, and just as she came up to them she heard one of them say, ‚ÄúLook out now, Five! Don‚Äôt go splashing paint over me like that!‚Äù
‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt help it,‚Äù said Five, in a sulky tone; ‚ÄúSeven jogged my elbow.‚Äù
On which Seven looked up and said, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs right, Five! Always lay the blame on others!‚Äù
‚ÄúYou‚Äôd better not talk!‚Äù said Five. ‚ÄúI heard the Queen say only yesterday you deserved to be beheaded!‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat for?‚Äù said the one who had spoken first.
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs none of your business, Two!‚Äù said Seven.
‚ÄúYes, it is his business!‚Äù said Five, ‚Äúand I‚Äôll tell him‚Äîit was for bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions.‚Äù
Seven flung down his brush, and had just begun ‚ÄúWell, of all the unjust things‚Äî‚Äù when his eye chanced to fall upon Alice, as she stood watching them, and he checked himself suddenly: the others looked round also, and all of them bowed low.
‚ÄúWould you tell me,‚Äù said Alice, a little timidly, ‚Äúwhy you are painting those roses?‚Äù
Five and Seven said nothing, but looked at Two. Two began in a low voice, ‚ÄúWhy the fact is, you see, Miss, this here ought to have been a red rose-tree, and we put a white one in by mistake; and if the Queen was to find it out, we should all have our heads cut off, you know. So you see, Miss, we‚Äôre doing our best, afore she comes, to‚Äî‚Äù At this moment Five, who had been anxiously looking across the garden, called out ‚ÄúThe Queen! The Queen!‚Äù and the three gardeners instantly threw themselves flat upon their faces. There was a sound of many footsteps, and Alice looked round, eager to see the Queen.
First came ten soldiers carrying clubs; these were all shaped like the three gardeners, oblong and flat, with their hands and feet at the corners: next the ten courtiers; these were ornamented all over with diamonds, and walked two and two, as the soldiers did. After these came the royal children; there were ten of them, and the little dears came jumping merrily along hand in hand, in couples: they were all ornamented with hearts. Next came the guests, mostly Kings and Queens, and among them Alice recognised the White Rabbit: it was talking in a hurried nervous manner, smiling at everything that was said, and went by without noticing her. Then followed the Knave of Hearts, carrying the King‚Äôs crown on a crimson velvet cushion; and, last of all this grand procession, came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS.
Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought not to lie down on her face like the three gardeners, but she could not remember ever having heard of such a rule at processions; ‚Äúand besides, what would be the use of a procession,‚Äù thought she, ‚Äúif people had all to lie down upon their faces, so that they couldn‚Äôt see it?‚Äù So she stood still where she was, and waited.
When the procession came opposite to Alice, they all stopped and looked at her, and the Queen said severely ‚ÄúWho is this?‚Äù She said it to the Knave of Hearts, who only bowed and smiled in reply.
‚ÄúIdiot!‚Äù said the Queen, tossing her head impatiently; and, turning to Alice, she went on, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your name, child?‚Äù
‚ÄúMy name is Alice, so please your Majesty,‚Äù said Alice very politely; but she added, to herself, ‚ÄúWhy, they‚Äôre only a pack of cards, after all. I needn‚Äôt be afraid of them!‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd who are these?‚Äù said the Queen, pointing to the three gardeners who were lying round the rose-tree; for, you see, as they were lying on their faces, and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the pack, she could not tell whether they were gardeners, or soldiers, or courtiers, or three of her own children.
‚ÄúHow should I know?‚Äù said Alice, surprised at her own courage. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no business of mine.‚Äù
The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a moment like a wild beast, screamed ‚ÄúOff with her head! Off‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúNonsense!‚Äù said Alice, very loudly and decidedly, and the Queen was silent.
The King laid his hand upon her arm, and timidly said ‚ÄúConsider, my dear: she is only a child!‚Äù
The Queen turned angrily away from him, and said to the Knave ‚ÄúTurn them over!‚Äù
The Knave did so, very carefully, with one foot.
‚ÄúGet up!‚Äù said the Queen, in a shrill, loud voice, and the three gardeners instantly jumped up, and began bowing to the King, the Queen, the royal children, and everybody else.
‚ÄúLeave off that!‚Äù screamed the Queen. ‚ÄúYou make me giddy.‚Äù And then, turning to the rose-tree, she went on, ‚ÄúWhat have you been doing here?‚Äù
‚ÄúMay it please your Majesty,‚Äù said Two, in a very humble tone, going down on one knee as he spoke, ‚Äúwe were trying‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúI see!‚Äù said the Queen, who had meanwhile been examining the roses. ‚ÄúOff with their heads!‚Äù and the procession moved on, three of the soldiers remaining behind to execute the unfortunate gardeners, who ran to Alice for protection.
‚ÄúYou shan‚Äôt be beheaded!‚Äù said Alice, and she put them into a large flower-pot that stood near. The three soldiers wandered about for a minute or two, looking for them, and then quietly marched off after the others.
‚ÄúAre their heads off?‚Äù shouted the Queen.
‚ÄúTheir heads are gone, if it please your Majesty!‚Äù the soldiers shouted in reply.
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs right!‚Äù shouted the Queen. ‚ÄúCan you play croquet?‚Äù
The soldiers were silent, and looked at Alice, as the question was evidently meant for her.
‚ÄúYes!‚Äù shouted Alice.
‚ÄúCome on, then!‚Äù roared the Queen, and Alice joined the procession, wondering very much what would happen next.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚Äîit‚Äôs a very fine day!‚Äù said a timid voice at her side. She was walking by the White Rabbit, who was peeping anxiously into her face.
‚ÄúVery,‚Äù said Alice: ‚Äú‚Äîwhere‚Äôs the Duchess?‚Äù
‚ÄúHush! Hush!‚Äù said the Rabbit in a low, hurried tone. He looked anxiously over his shoulder as he spoke, and then raised himself upon tiptoe, put his mouth close to her ear, and whispered ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs under sentence of execution.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat for?‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúDid you say ‚ÄòWhat a pity!‚Äô?‚Äù the Rabbit asked.
‚ÄúNo, I didn‚Äôt,‚Äù said Alice: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs at all a pity. I said ‚ÄòWhat for?‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄúShe boxed the Queen‚Äôs ears‚Äî‚Äù the Rabbit began. Alice gave a little scream of laughter. ‚ÄúOh, hush!‚Äù the Rabbit whispered in a frightened tone. ‚ÄúThe Queen will hear you! You see, she came rather late, and the Queen said‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúGet to your places!‚Äù shouted the Queen in a voice of thunder, and people began running about in all directions, tumbling up against each other; however, they got settled down in a minute or two, and the game began. Alice thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground in her life; it was all ridges and furrows; the balls were live hedgehogs, the mallets live flamingoes, and the soldiers had to double themselves up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.
The chief difficulty Alice found at first was in managing her flamingo: she succeeded in getting its body tucked away, comfortably enough, under her arm, with its legs hanging down, but generally, just as she had got its neck nicely straightened out, and was going to give the hedgehog a blow with its head, it would twist itself round and look up in her face, with such a puzzled expression that she could not help bursting out laughing: and when she had got its head down, and was going to begin again, it was very provoking to find that the hedgehog had unrolled itself, and was in the act of crawling away: besides all this, there was generally a ridge or furrow in the way wherever she wanted to send the hedgehog to, and, as the doubled-up soldiers were always getting up and walking off to other parts of the ground, Alice soon came to the conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed.
The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting ‚ÄúOff with his head!‚Äù or ‚ÄúOff with her head!‚Äù about once in a minute.
Alice began to feel very uneasy: to be sure, she had not as yet had any dispute with the Queen, but she knew that it might happen any minute, ‚Äúand then,‚Äù thought she, ‚Äúwhat would become of me? They‚Äôre dreadfully fond of beheading people here; the great wonder is, that there‚Äôs any one left alive!‚Äù
She was looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she could get away without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance in the air: it puzzled her very much at first, but, after watching it a minute or two, she made it out to be a grin, and she said to herself ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the Cheshire Cat: now I shall have somebody to talk to.‚Äù
‚ÄúHow are you getting on?‚Äù said the Cat, as soon as there was mouth enough for it to speak with.
Alice waited till the eyes appeared, and then nodded. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no use speaking to it,‚Äù she thought, ‚Äútill its ears have come, or at least one of them.‚Äù In another minute the whole head appeared, and then Alice put down her flamingo, and began an account of the game, feeling very glad she had someone to listen to her. The Cat seemed to think that there was enough of it now in sight, and no more of it appeared.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think they play at all fairly,‚Äù Alice began, in rather a complaining tone, ‚Äúand they all quarrel so dreadfully one can‚Äôt hear oneself speak‚Äîand they don‚Äôt seem to have any rules in particular; at least, if there are, nobody attends to them‚Äîand you‚Äôve no idea how confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there‚Äôs the arch I‚Äôve got to go through next walking about at the other end of the ground‚Äîand I should have croqueted the Queen‚Äôs hedgehog just now, only it ran away when it saw mine coming!‚Äù
‚ÄúHow do you like the Queen?‚Äù said the Cat in a low voice.
‚ÄúNot at all,‚Äù said Alice: ‚Äúshe‚Äôs so extremely‚Äî‚Äù Just then she noticed that the Queen was close behind her, listening: so she went on, ‚Äú‚Äîlikely to win, that it‚Äôs hardly worth while finishing the game.‚Äù
The Queen smiled and passed on.
‚ÄúWho are you talking to?‚Äù said the King, going up to Alice, and looking at the Cat‚Äôs head with great curiosity.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a friend of mine‚Äîa Cheshire Cat,‚Äù said Alice: ‚Äúallow me to introduce it.‚Äù
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like the look of it at all,‚Äù said the King: ‚Äúhowever, it may kiss my hand if it likes.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather not,‚Äù the Cat remarked.
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be impertinent,‚Äù said the King, ‚Äúand don‚Äôt look at me like that!‚Äù He got behind Alice as he spoke.
‚ÄúA cat may look at a king,‚Äù said Alice. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve read that in some book, but I don‚Äôt remember where.‚Äù
‚ÄúWell, it must be removed,‚Äù said the King very decidedly, and he called the Queen, who was passing at the moment, ‚ÄúMy dear! I wish you would have this cat removed!‚Äù
The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small. ‚ÄúOff with his head!‚Äù she said, without even looking round.
‚ÄúI‚Äôll fetch the executioner myself,‚Äù said the King eagerly, and he hurried off.
Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going on, as she heard the Queen‚Äôs voice in the distance, screaming with passion. She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be executed for having missed their turns, and she did not like the look of things at all, as the game was in such confusion that she never knew whether it was her turn or not. So she went in search of her hedgehog.
The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog, which seemed to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the other: the only difficulty was, that her flamingo was gone across to the other side of the garden, where Alice could see it trying in a helpless sort of way to fly up into a tree.
By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back, the fight was over, and both the hedgehogs were out of sight: ‚Äúbut it doesn‚Äôt matter much,‚Äù thought Alice, ‚Äúas all the arches are gone from this side of the ground.‚Äù So she tucked it away under her arm, that it might not escape again, and went back for a little more conversation with her friend.
When she got back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it: there was a dispute going on between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who were all talking at once, while all the rest were quite silent, and looked very uncomfortable.
The moment Alice appeared, she was appealed to by all three to settle the question, and they repeated their arguments to her, though, as they all spoke at once, she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly what they said.
The executioner‚Äôs argument was, that you couldn‚Äôt cut off a head unless there was a body to cut it off from: that he had never had to do such a thing before, and he wasn‚Äôt going to begin at his time of life.
The King‚Äôs argument was, that anything that had a head could be beheaded, and that you weren‚Äôt to talk nonsense.
The Queen‚Äôs argument was, that if something wasn‚Äôt done about it in less than no time she‚Äôd have everybody executed, all round. (It was this last remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious.)
Alice could think of nothing else to say but ‚ÄúIt belongs to the Duchess: you‚Äôd better ask her about it.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe‚Äôs in prison,‚Äù the Queen said to the executioner: ‚Äúfetch her here.‚Äù And the executioner went off like an arrow.
The Cat‚Äôs head began fading away the moment he was gone, and, by the time he had come back with the Duchess, it had entirely disappeared; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down looking for it, while the rest of the party went back to the game.

resource.label: Alice in Wonderland - Chapter 9 - The Mock Turtle‚Äôs Story

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The Queen orders Alice to visit the Mock Turtle. Accompanied by the Gryphon, Alice listens to the Mock Turtle's sad story and learns the Lobster Quadrille dance.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In a room lit by a soft, ocean-like glow, Alice stood with RabbitIT, her robotic guide in Daschland. They activated a hologram of the Mock Turtle, brought to life by DaSCH, a vast repository of historical data. The Turtle shared his tale of an underwater school, his voice echoing in the simulated sea, with subjects like Reeling, Writhing, and humorous Arithmetic courses‚ÄîAmbition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.
As the Turtle recounted the Lobster Quadrille, the room transformed, and holographic lobsters danced around them. RabbitIT explained the dance steps, integrating knowledge from DaSCH‚Äôs archives. Alice joined in, laughing and learning through the dance.
When the music ceased, the Turtle‚Äôs tone turned melancholic as he reminisced about his past, now preserved in digital form. Alice, touched by the narrative and the blend of reality and data, thanked the Turtle. With a final look at the fading hologram, she and RabbitIT left, Alice pondering the poignant intersection of technology and tradition.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!‚Äù said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice‚Äôs, and they walked off together.
Alice was very glad to find her in such a pleasant temper, and thought to herself that perhaps it was only the pepper that had made her so savage when they met in the kitchen.
‚ÄúWhen I‚Äôm a Duchess,‚Äù she said to herself, (not in a very hopeful tone though), ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt have any pepper in my kitchen at all. Soup does very well without‚ÄîMaybe it‚Äôs always pepper that makes people hot-tempered,‚Äù she went on, very much pleased at having found out a new kind of rule, ‚Äúand vinegar that makes them sour‚Äîand camomile that makes them bitter‚Äîand‚Äîand barley-sugar and such things that make children sweet-tempered. I only wish people knew that: then they wouldn‚Äôt be so stingy about it, you know‚Äî‚Äù
She had quite forgotten the Duchess by this time, and was a little startled when she heard her voice close to her ear. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre thinking about something, my dear, and that makes you forget to talk. I can‚Äôt tell you just now what the moral of that is, but I shall remember it in a bit.‚Äù
‚ÄúPerhaps it hasn‚Äôt one,‚Äù Alice ventured to remark.
‚ÄúTut, tut, child!‚Äù said the Duchess. ‚ÄúEverything‚Äôs got a moral, if only you can find it.‚Äù And she squeezed herself up closer to Alice‚Äôs side as she spoke.
Alice did not much like keeping so close to her: first, because the Duchess was very ugly; and secondly, because she was exactly the right height to rest her chin upon Alice‚Äôs shoulder, and it was an uncomfortably sharp chin. However, she did not like to be rude, so she bore it as well as she could.
‚ÄúThe game‚Äôs going on rather better now,‚Äù she said, by way of keeping up the conversation a little.
‚Äú‚ÄôTis so,‚Äù said the Duchess: ‚Äúand the moral of that is‚Äî‚ÄòOh, ‚Äôtis love, ‚Äôtis love, that makes the world go round!‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄúSomebody said,‚Äù Alice whispered, ‚Äúthat it‚Äôs done by everybody minding their own business!‚Äù
‚ÄúAh, well! It means much the same thing,‚Äù said the Duchess, digging her sharp little chin into Alice‚Äôs shoulder as she added, ‚Äúand the moral of that is‚Äî‚ÄòTake care of the sense, and the sounds will take care of themselves.‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄúHow fond she is of finding morals in things!‚Äù Alice thought to herself.
‚ÄúI dare say you‚Äôre wondering why I don‚Äôt put my arm round your waist,‚Äù the Duchess said after a pause: ‚Äúthe reason is, that I‚Äôm doubtful about the temper of your flamingo. Shall I try the experiment?‚Äù
‚ÄúHe might bite,‚Äù Alice cautiously replied, not feeling at all anxious to have the experiment tried.
‚ÄúVery true,‚Äù said the Duchess: ‚Äúflamingoes and mustard both bite. And the moral of that is‚Äî‚ÄòBirds of a feather flock together.‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄúOnly mustard isn‚Äôt a bird,‚Äù Alice remarked.
‚ÄúRight, as usual,‚Äù said the Duchess: ‚Äúwhat a clear way you have of putting things!‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a mineral, I think,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúOf course it is,‚Äù said the Duchess, who seemed ready to agree to everything that Alice said; ‚Äúthere‚Äôs a large mustard-mine near here. And the moral of that is‚Äî‚ÄòThe more there is of mine, the less there is of yours.‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄúOh, I know!‚Äù exclaimed Alice, who had not attended to this last remark, ‚Äúit‚Äôs a vegetable. It doesn‚Äôt look like one, but it is.‚Äù
‚ÄúI quite agree with you,‚Äù said the Duchess; ‚Äúand the moral of that is‚Äî‚ÄòBe what you would seem to be‚Äô‚Äîor if you‚Äôd like it put more simply‚Äî‚ÄòNever imagine yourself not to be otherwise than what it might appear to others that what you were or might have been was not otherwise than what you had been would have appeared to them to be otherwise.‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄúI think I should understand that better,‚Äù Alice said very politely, ‚Äúif I had it written down: but I can‚Äôt quite follow it as you say it.‚Äù
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs nothing to what I could say if I chose,‚Äù the Duchess replied, in a pleased tone.
‚ÄúPray don‚Äôt trouble yourself to say it any longer than that,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúOh, don‚Äôt talk about trouble!‚Äù said the Duchess. ‚ÄúI make you a present of everything I‚Äôve said as yet.‚Äù
‚ÄúA cheap sort of present!‚Äù thought Alice. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad they don‚Äôt give birthday presents like that!‚Äù But she did not venture to say it out loud.
‚ÄúThinking again?‚Äù the Duchess asked, with another dig of her sharp little chin.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve a right to think,‚Äù said Alice sharply, for she was beginning to feel a little worried.
‚ÄúJust about as much right,‚Äù said the Duchess, ‚Äúas pigs have to fly; and the m‚Äî‚Äù
But here, to Alice‚Äôs great surprise, the Duchess‚Äôs voice died away, even in the middle of her favourite word ‚Äòmoral,‚Äô and the arm that was linked into hers began to tremble. Alice looked up, and there stood the Queen in front of them, with her arms folded, frowning like a thunderstorm.
‚ÄúA fine day, your Majesty!‚Äù the Duchess began in a low, weak voice.
‚ÄúNow, I give you fair warning,‚Äù shouted the Queen, stamping on the ground as she spoke; ‚Äúeither you or your head must be off, and that in about half no time! Take your choice!‚Äù
The Duchess took her choice, and was gone in a moment.
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go on with the game,‚Äù the Queen said to Alice; and Alice was too much frightened to say a word, but slowly followed her back to the croquet-ground.
The other guests had taken advantage of the Queen‚Äôs absence, and were resting in the shade: however, the moment they saw her, they hurried back to the game, the Queen merely remarking that a moment‚Äôs delay would cost them their lives.
All the time they were playing the Queen never left off quarrelling with the other players, and shouting ‚ÄúOff with his head!‚Äù or ‚ÄúOff with her head!‚Äù Those whom she sentenced were taken into custody by the soldiers, who of course had to leave off being arches to do this, so that by the end of half an hour or so there were no arches left, and all the players, except the King, the Queen, and Alice, were in custody and under sentence of execution.
Then the Queen left off, quite out of breath, and said to Alice, ‚ÄúHave you seen the Mock Turtle yet?‚Äù
‚ÄúNo,‚Äù said Alice. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even know what a Mock Turtle is.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the thing Mock Turtle Soup is made from,‚Äù said the Queen.
‚ÄúI never saw one, or heard of one,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúCome on, then,‚Äù said the Queen, ‚Äúand he shall tell you his history,‚Äù
As they walked off together, Alice heard the King say in a low voice, to the company generally, ‚ÄúYou are all pardoned.‚Äù ‚ÄúCome, that‚Äôs a good thing!‚Äù she said to herself, for she had felt quite unhappy at the number of executions the Queen had ordered.
They very soon came upon a Gryphon, lying fast asleep in the sun. (If you don‚Äôt know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.) ‚ÄúUp, lazy thing!‚Äù said the Queen, ‚Äúand take this young lady to see the Mock Turtle, and to hear his history. I must go back and see after some executions I have ordered;‚Äù and she walked off, leaving Alice alone with the Gryphon. Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but on the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go after that savage Queen: so she waited.
The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes: then it watched the Queen till she was out of sight: then it chuckled. ‚ÄúWhat fun!‚Äù said the Gryphon, half to itself, half to Alice.
‚ÄúWhat is the fun?‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúWhy, she,‚Äù said the Gryphon. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all her fancy, that: they never executes nobody, you know. Come on!‚Äù
‚ÄúEverybody says ‚Äòcome on!‚Äô here,‚Äù thought Alice, as she went slowly after it: ‚ÄúI never was so ordered about in all my life, never!‚Äù
They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance, sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break. She pitied him deeply. ‚ÄúWhat is his sorrow?‚Äù she asked the Gryphon, and the Gryphon answered, very nearly in the same words as before, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all his fancy, that: he hasn‚Äôt got no sorrow, you know. Come on!‚Äù
So they went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large eyes full of tears, but said nothing.
‚ÄúThis here young lady,‚Äù said the Gryphon, ‚Äúshe wants for to know your history, she do.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell it her,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle in a deep, hollow tone: ‚Äúsit down, both of you, and don‚Äôt speak a word till I‚Äôve finished.‚Äù
So they sat down, and nobody spoke for some minutes. Alice thought to herself, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see how he can ever finish, if he doesn‚Äôt begin.‚Äù But she waited patiently.
‚ÄúOnce,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle at last, with a deep sigh, ‚ÄúI was a real Turtle.‚Äù
These words were followed by a very long silence, broken only by an occasional exclamation of ‚ÄúHjckrrh!‚Äù from the Gryphon, and the constant heavy sobbing of the Mock Turtle. Alice was very nearly getting up and saying, ‚ÄúThank you, sir, for your interesting story,‚Äù but she could not help thinking there must be more to come, so she sat still and said nothing.
‚ÄúWhen we were little,‚Äù the Mock Turtle went on at last, more calmly, though still sobbing a little now and then, ‚Äúwe went to school in the sea. The master was an old Turtle‚Äîwe used to call him Tortoise‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn‚Äôt one?‚Äù Alice asked.
‚ÄúWe called him Tortoise because he taught us,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle angrily: ‚Äúreally you are very dull!‚Äù
‚ÄúYou ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple question,‚Äù added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth. At last the Gryphon said to the Mock Turtle, ‚ÄúDrive on, old fellow! Don‚Äôt be all day about it!‚Äù and he went on in these words:
‚ÄúYes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn‚Äôt believe it‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúI never said I didn‚Äôt!‚Äù interrupted Alice.
‚ÄúYou did,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle.
‚ÄúHold your tongue!‚Äù added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again. The Mock Turtle went on.
‚ÄúWe had the best of educations‚Äîin fact, we went to school every day‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôve been to a day-school, too,‚Äù said Alice; ‚Äúyou needn‚Äôt be so proud as all that.‚Äù
‚ÄúWith extras?‚Äù asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.
‚ÄúYes,‚Äù said Alice, ‚Äúwe learned French and music.‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd washing?‚Äù said the Mock Turtle.
‚ÄúCertainly not!‚Äù said Alice indignantly.
‚ÄúAh! then yours wasn‚Äôt a really good school,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle in a tone of great relief. ‚ÄúNow at ours they had at the end of the bill, ‚ÄòFrench, music, and washing‚Äîextra.‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄúYou couldn‚Äôt have wanted it much,‚Äù said Alice; ‚Äúliving at the bottom of the sea.‚Äù
‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt afford to learn it.‚Äù said the Mock Turtle with a sigh. ‚ÄúI only took the regular course.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat was that?‚Äù inquired Alice.
‚ÄúReeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with,‚Äù the Mock Turtle replied; ‚Äúand then the different branches of Arithmetic‚ÄîAmbition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.‚Äù
‚ÄúI never heard of ‚ÄòUglification,‚Äô‚Äù Alice ventured to say. ‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù
The Gryphon lifted up both its paws in surprise. ‚ÄúWhat! Never heard of uglifying!‚Äù it exclaimed. ‚ÄúYou know what to beautify is, I suppose?‚Äù
‚ÄúYes,‚Äù said Alice doubtfully: ‚Äúit means‚Äîto‚Äîmake‚Äîanything‚Äîprettier.‚Äù
‚ÄúWell, then,‚Äù the Gryphon went on, ‚Äúif you don‚Äôt know what to uglify is, you are a simpleton.‚Äù
Alice did not feel encouraged to ask any more questions about it, so she turned to the Mock Turtle, and said ‚ÄúWhat else had you to learn?‚Äù
‚ÄúWell, there was Mystery,‚Äù the Mock Turtle replied, counting off the subjects on his flappers, ‚Äú‚ÄîMystery, ancient and modern, with Seaography: then Drawling‚Äîthe Drawling-master was an old conger-eel, that used to come once a week: he taught us Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat was that like?‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúWell, I can‚Äôt show it you myself,‚Äù the Mock Turtle said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm too stiff. And the Gryphon never learnt it.‚Äù
‚ÄúHadn‚Äôt time,‚Äù said the Gryphon: ‚ÄúI went to the Classics master, though. He was an old crab, he was.‚Äù
‚ÄúI never went to him,‚Äù the Mock Turtle said with a sigh: ‚Äúhe taught Laughing and Grief, they used to say.‚Äù
‚ÄúSo he did, so he did,‚Äù said the Gryphon, sighing in his turn; and both creatures hid their faces in their paws.
‚ÄúAnd how many hours a day did you do lessons?‚Äù said Alice, in a hurry to change the subject.
‚ÄúTen hours the first day,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle: ‚Äúnine the next, and so on.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat a curious plan!‚Äù exclaimed Alice.
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the reason they‚Äôre called lessons,‚Äù the Gryphon remarked: ‚Äúbecause they lessen from day to day.‚Äù
This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little before she made her next remark. ‚ÄúThen the eleventh day must have been a holiday?‚Äù
‚ÄúOf course it was,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle.
‚ÄúAnd how did you manage on the twelfth?‚Äù Alice went on eagerly.
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs enough about lessons,‚Äù the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided tone: ‚Äútell her something about the games now.‚Äù

resource.label: Alice in Wonderland - Chapter 10 - The Lobster Quadrille

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The Mock Turtle and the Gryphon perform the Lobster Quadrille dance. Alice is asked to recite a poem but instead recites a nonsensical version of "Father William."

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, Alice and her robotic guide RabbitIT, ventured to a digital beach, orchestrated by the DaSCH repository, to learn about the "Lobster Quadrille." RabbitIT activated a holographic display, where sea creatures performed the intricate dance, synchronized perfectly through the archive's historical data.
RabbitIT encouraged Alice to join the dance using a virtual interface. As she mimicked the steps, her initial clumsiness turned into delight, guided by the precise, educational commentary from RabbitIT. They danced together among holographic lobsters and turtles, with Alice laughing joyfully.
As the dance concluded, Alice clapped her hands, overwhelmed by the digital spectacle. "It's the most curious thing I ever saw in my life!" she exclaimed, appreciating how DaSCH and RabbitIT vividly brought the whimsical Lobster Quadrille to life.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes. He looked at Alice, and tried to speak, but for a minute or two sobs choked his voice. ‚ÄúSame as if he had a bone in his throat,‚Äù said the Gryphon: and it set to work shaking him and punching him in the back. At last the Mock Turtle recovered his voice, and, with tears running down his cheeks, he went on again:‚Äî
‚ÄúYou may not have lived much under the sea‚Äî‚Äù (‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt,‚Äù said Alice)‚Äî‚Äúand perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster‚Äî‚Äù (Alice began to say ‚ÄúI once tasted‚Äî‚Äù but checked herself hastily, and said ‚ÄúNo, never‚Äù) ‚Äú‚Äîso you can have no idea what a delightful thing a Lobster Quadrille is!‚Äù
‚ÄúNo, indeed,‚Äù said Alice. ‚ÄúWhat sort of a dance is it?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy,‚Äù said the Gryphon, ‚Äúyou first form into a line along the sea-shore‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúTwo lines!‚Äù cried the Mock Turtle. ‚ÄúSeals, turtles, salmon, and so on; then, when you‚Äôve cleared all the jelly-fish out of the way‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúThat generally takes some time,‚Äù interrupted the Gryphon.
‚Äú‚Äîyou advance twice‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúEach with a lobster as a partner!‚Äù cried the Gryphon.
‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù the Mock Turtle said: ‚Äúadvance twice, set to partners‚Äî‚Äù
‚Äú‚Äîchange lobsters, and retire in same order,‚Äù continued the Gryphon.
‚ÄúThen, you know,‚Äù the Mock Turtle went on, ‚Äúyou throw the‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúThe lobsters!‚Äù shouted the Gryphon, with a bound into the air.
‚Äú‚Äîas far out to sea as you can‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúSwim after them!‚Äù screamed the Gryphon.
‚ÄúTurn a somersault in the sea!‚Äù cried the Mock Turtle, capering wildly about.
‚ÄúChange lobsters again!‚Äù yelled the Gryphon at the top of its voice.
‚ÄúBack to land again, and that‚Äôs all the first figure,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle, suddenly dropping his voice; and the two creatures, who had been jumping about like mad things all this time, sat down again very sadly and quietly, and looked at Alice.
‚ÄúIt must be a very pretty dance,‚Äù said Alice timidly.
‚ÄúWould you like to see a little of it?‚Äù said the Mock Turtle.
‚ÄúVery much indeed,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúCome, let‚Äôs try the first figure!‚Äù said the Mock Turtle to the Gryphon. ‚ÄúWe can do without lobsters, you know. Which shall sing?‚Äù
‚ÄúOh, you sing,‚Äù said the Gryphon. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve forgotten the words.‚Äù
So they began solemnly dancing round and round Alice, every now and then treading on her toes when they passed too close, and waving their forepaws to mark the time, while the Mock Turtle sang this, very slowly and sadly:‚Äî
‚ÄúWill you walk a little faster?‚Äù said a whiting to a snail. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a porpoise close behind us, and he‚Äôs treading on my tail. See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles all advance! They are waiting on the shingle‚Äîwill you come and join the dance? Will you, won‚Äôt you, will you, won‚Äôt you, will you join the dance? Will you, won‚Äôt you, will you, won‚Äôt you, won‚Äôt you join the dance?
‚ÄúYou can really have no notion how delightful it will be When they take us up and throw us, with the lobsters, out to sea!‚Äù But the snail replied ‚ÄúToo far, too far!‚Äù and gave a look askance‚Äî Said he thanked the whiting kindly, but he would not join the dance. Would not, could not, would not, could not, would not join the dance. Would not, could not, would not, could not, could not join the dance.
‚ÄúWhat matters it how far we go?‚Äù his scaly friend replied. ‚ÄúThere is another shore, you know, upon the other side. The further off from England the nearer is to France‚Äî Then turn not pale, beloved snail, but come and join the dance. Will you, won‚Äôt you, will you, won‚Äôt you, will you join the dance? Will you, won‚Äôt you, will you, won‚Äôt you, won‚Äôt you join the dance?‚Äù
‚ÄúThank you, it‚Äôs a very interesting dance to watch,‚Äù said Alice, feeling very glad that it was over at last: ‚Äúand I do so like that curious song about the whiting!‚Äù
‚ÄúOh, as to the whiting,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle, ‚Äúthey‚Äîyou‚Äôve seen them, of course?‚Äù
‚ÄúYes,‚Äù said Alice, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve often seen them at dinn‚Äî‚Äù she checked herself hastily.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know where Dinn may be,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle, ‚Äúbut if you‚Äôve seen them so often, of course you know what they‚Äôre like.‚Äù
‚ÄúI believe so,‚Äù Alice replied thoughtfully. ‚ÄúThey have their tails in their mouths‚Äîand they‚Äôre all over crumbs.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre wrong about the crumbs,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle: ‚Äúcrumbs would all wash off in the sea. But they have their tails in their mouths; and the reason is‚Äî‚Äù here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.‚Äî‚ÄúTell her about the reason and all that,‚Äù he said to the Gryphon.
‚ÄúThe reason is,‚Äù said the Gryphon, ‚Äúthat they would go with the lobsters to the dance. So they got thrown out to sea. So they had to fall a long way. So they got their tails fast in their mouths. So they couldn‚Äôt get them out again. That‚Äôs all.‚Äù
‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù said Alice, ‚Äúit‚Äôs very interesting. I never knew so much about a whiting before.‚Äù
‚ÄúI can tell you more than that, if you like,‚Äù said the Gryphon. ‚ÄúDo you know why it‚Äôs called a whiting?‚Äù
‚ÄúI never thought about it,‚Äù said Alice. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù
‚ÄúIt does the boots and shoes,‚Äù the Gryphon replied very solemnly.
Alice was thoroughly puzzled. ‚ÄúDoes the boots and shoes!‚Äù she repeated in a wondering tone.
‚ÄúWhy, what are your shoes done with?‚Äù said the Gryphon. ‚ÄúI mean, what makes them so shiny?‚Äù
Alice looked down at them, and considered a little before she gave her answer. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre done with blacking, I believe.‚Äù
‚ÄúBoots and shoes under the sea,‚Äù the Gryphon went on in a deep voice, ‚Äúare done with a whiting. Now you know.‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd what are they made of?‚Äù Alice asked in a tone of great curiosity.
‚ÄúSoles and eels, of course,‚Äù the Gryphon replied rather impatiently: ‚Äúany shrimp could have told you that.‚Äù
‚ÄúIf I‚Äôd been the whiting,‚Äù said Alice, whose thoughts were still running on the song, ‚ÄúI‚Äôd have said to the porpoise, ‚ÄòKeep back, please: we don‚Äôt want you with us!‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄúThey were obliged to have him with them,‚Äù the Mock Turtle said: ‚Äúno wise fish would go anywhere without a porpoise.‚Äù
‚ÄúWouldn‚Äôt it really?‚Äù said Alice in a tone of great surprise.
‚ÄúOf course not,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle: ‚Äúwhy, if a fish came to me, and told me he was going a journey, I should say ‚ÄòWith what porpoise?‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you mean ‚Äòpurpose‚Äô?‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúI mean what I say,‚Äù the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone. And the Gryphon added ‚ÄúCome, let‚Äôs hear some of your adventures.‚Äù
‚ÄúI could tell you my adventures‚Äîbeginning from this morning,‚Äù said Alice a little timidly: ‚Äúbut it‚Äôs no use going back to yesterday, because I was a different person then.‚Äù
‚ÄúExplain all that,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle.
‚ÄúNo, no! The adventures first,‚Äù said the Gryphon in an impatient tone: ‚Äúexplanations take such a dreadful time.‚Äù
So Alice began telling them her adventures from the time when she first saw the White Rabbit. She was a little nervous about it just at first, the two creatures got so close to her, one on each side, and opened their eyes and mouths so very wide, but she gained courage as she went on. Her listeners were perfectly quiet till she got to the part about her repeating ‚ÄúYou are old, Father William,‚Äù to the Caterpillar, and the words all coming different, and then the Mock Turtle drew a long breath, and said ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs very curious.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all about as curious as it can be,‚Äù said the Gryphon.
‚ÄúIt all came different!‚Äù the Mock Turtle repeated thoughtfully. ‚ÄúI should like to hear her try and repeat something now. Tell her to begin.‚Äù He looked at the Gryphon as if he thought it had some kind of authority over Alice.
‚ÄúStand up and repeat ‚Äò‚ÄôTis the voice of the sluggard,‚Äô‚Äù said the Gryphon.
‚ÄúHow the creatures order one about, and make one repeat lessons!‚Äù thought Alice; ‚ÄúI might as well be at school at once.‚Äù However, she got up, and began to repeat it, but her head was so full of the Lobster Quadrille, that she hardly knew what she was saying, and the words came very queer indeed:‚Äî
‚Äú‚ÄôTis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare, ‚ÄúYou have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair.‚Äù As a duck with its eyelids, so he with his nose Trims his belt and his buttons, and turns out his toes. [later editions continue as follows: When the sands are all dry, he is gay as a lark, And will talk in contemptuous tones of the Shark, But, when the tide rises and sharks are around, His voice has a timid and tremulous sound.‚Äù]
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs different from what I used to say when I was a child,‚Äù said the Gryphon.
‚ÄúWell, I never heard it before,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle; ‚Äúbut it sounds uncommon nonsense.‚Äù
Alice said nothing; she had sat down with her face in her hands, wondering if anything would ever happen in a natural way again.
‚ÄúI should like to have it explained,‚Äù said the Mock Turtle.
‚ÄúShe can‚Äôt explain it,‚Äù said the Gryphon hastily. ‚ÄúGo on with the next verse.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut about his toes?‚Äù the Mock Turtle persisted. ‚ÄúHow could he turn them out with his nose, you know?‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the first position in dancing.‚Äù Alice said; but was dreadfully puzzled by the whole thing, and longed to change the subject.
‚ÄúGo on with the next verse,‚Äù the Gryphon repeated impatiently: ‚Äúit begins ‚ÄòI passed by his garden.‚Äô‚Äù
Alice did not dare to disobey, though she felt sure it would all come wrong, and she went on in a trembling voice:‚Äî
‚ÄúI passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye, How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie‚Äî [later editions continue as follows: The Panther took pie-crust, and gravy, and meat, While the Owl had the dish as its share of the treat. When the pie was all finished, the Owl, as a boon, Was kindly permitted to pocket the spoon: While the Panther received knife and fork with a growl, And concluded the banquet‚Äî‚Äù]
‚ÄúWhat is the use of repeating all that stuff,‚Äù the Mock Turtle interrupted, ‚Äúif you don‚Äôt explain it as you go on? It‚Äôs by far the most confusing thing I ever heard!‚Äù
‚ÄúYes, I think you‚Äôd better leave off,‚Äù said the Gryphon: and Alice was only too glad to do so.
‚ÄúShall we try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille?‚Äù the Gryphon went on. ‚ÄúOr would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?‚Äù
‚ÄúOh, a song, please, if the Mock Turtle would be so kind,‚Äù Alice replied, so eagerly that the Gryphon said, in a rather offended tone, ‚ÄúHm! No accounting for tastes! Sing her ‚ÄòTurtle Soup,‚Äô will you, old fellow?‚Äù
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a voice sometimes choked with sobs, to sing this:‚Äî
‚ÄúBeautiful Soup, so rich and green, Waiting in a hot tureen! Who for such dainties would not stoop? Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup! Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup! Beau‚Äîootiful Soo‚Äîoop! Beau‚Äîootiful Soo‚Äîoop! Soo‚Äîoop of the e‚Äîe‚Äîevening, Beautiful, beautiful Soup!
‚ÄúBeautiful Soup! Who cares for fish, Game, or any other dish? Who would not give all else for two p ennyworth only of beautiful Soup? Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup? Beau‚Äîootiful Soo‚Äîoop! Beau‚Äîootiful Soo‚Äîoop! Soo‚Äîoop of the e‚Äîe‚Äîevening, Beautiful, beauti‚ÄîFUL SOUP!‚Äù
‚ÄúChorus again!‚Äù cried the Gryphon, and the Mock Turtle had just begun to repeat it, when a cry of ‚ÄúThe trial‚Äôs beginning!‚Äù was heard in the distance.
‚ÄúCome on!‚Äù cried the Gryphon, and, taking Alice by the hand, it hurried off, without waiting for the end of the song.
‚ÄúWhat trial is it?‚Äù Alice panted as she ran; but the Gryphon only answered ‚ÄúCome on!‚Äù and ran the faster, while more and more faintly came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:‚Äî
‚ÄúSoo‚Äîoop of the e‚Äîe‚Äîevening, Beautiful, beautiful Soup!‚Äù

resource.label: Alice in Wonderland - Chapter 11 - Who stole the Tarts?

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice attends a trial where the Knave of Hearts is accused of stealing the Queen's tarts. The proceedings are absurd, with nonsensical evidence and witnesses.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, Alice and her guide RabbitIT entered a virtual courtroom where the Knave of Hearts was on trial for stealing tarts, all recreated through the DaSCH repository. The courtroom, filled with holographic characters from classic tales, buzzed with the drama of the King and Queen of Hearts presiding over the proceedings.
As RabbitIT provided Alice with insights from the repository, the trial unfolded with whimsical and absurd testimonies, reflecting the story's original humor. Witnesses from the realm of Wonderland presented their often-irrelevant evidence, while RabbitIT helped Alice understand the peculiar legal proceedings.
The trial, filled with whimsy and legal quirks, captivated Alice. She marveled at the curious judicial system of Wonderland, expertly brought to life by DaSCH's digital archives. The chapter concluded with an unpredictable verdict, leaving Alice amused and thoughtful about the blend of reality and fantasy in DaSCHland's court.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them‚Äîall sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other. In the very middle of the court was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so good, that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them‚Äî‚ÄúI wish they‚Äôd get the trial done,‚Äù she thought, ‚Äúand hand round the refreshments!‚Äù But there seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about her, to pass away the time.
Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew the name of nearly everything there. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the judge,‚Äù she said to herself, ‚Äúbecause of his great wig.‚Äù
The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.
‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs the jury-box,‚Äù thought Alice, ‚Äúand those twelve creatures,‚Äù (she was obliged to say ‚Äúcreatures,‚Äù you see, because some of them were animals, and some were birds,) ‚ÄúI suppose they are the jurors.‚Äù She said this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her age knew the meaning of it at all. However, ‚Äújury-men‚Äù would have done just as well.
The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates. ‚ÄúWhat are they doing?‚Äù Alice whispered to the Gryphon. ‚ÄúThey can‚Äôt have anything to put down yet, before the trial‚Äôs begun.‚Äù
‚ÄúThey‚Äôre putting down their names,‚Äù the Gryphon whispered in reply, ‚Äúfor fear they should forget them before the end of the trial.‚Äù
‚ÄúStupid things!‚Äù Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out, ‚ÄúSilence in the court!‚Äù and the King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who was talking.
Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders, that all the jurors were writing down ‚Äústupid things!‚Äù on their slates, and she could even make out that one of them didn‚Äôt know how to spell ‚Äústupid,‚Äù and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him. ‚ÄúA nice muddle their slates‚Äôll be in before the trial‚Äôs over!‚Äù thought Alice.
One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked. This of course, Alice could not stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and very soon found an opportunity of taking it away. She did it so quickly that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) could not make out at all what had become of it; so, after hunting all about for it, he was obliged to write with one finger for the rest of the day; and this was of very little use, as it left no mark on the slate.
‚ÄúHerald, read the accusation!‚Äù said the King.
On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:‚Äî
‚ÄúThe Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts, All on a summer day: The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts, And took them quite away!‚Äù
‚ÄúConsider your verdict,‚Äù the King said to the jury.
‚ÄúNot yet, not yet!‚Äù the Rabbit hastily interrupted. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a great deal to come before that!‚Äù
‚ÄúCall the first witness,‚Äù said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and called out, ‚ÄúFirst witness!‚Äù
The first witness was the Hatter. He came in with a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other. ‚ÄúI beg pardon, your Majesty,‚Äù he began, ‚Äúfor bringing these in: but I hadn‚Äôt quite finished my tea when I was sent for.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou ought to have finished,‚Äù said the King. ‚ÄúWhen did you begin?‚Äù
The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse. ‚ÄúFourteenth of March, I think it was,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúFifteenth,‚Äù said the March Hare.
‚ÄúSixteenth,‚Äù added the Dormouse.
‚ÄúWrite that down,‚Äù the King said to the jury, and the jury eagerly wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and reduced the answer to shillings and pence.
‚ÄúTake off your hat,‚Äù the King said to the Hatter.
‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt mine,‚Äù said the Hatter.
‚ÄúStolen!‚Äù the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a memorandum of the fact.
‚ÄúI keep them to sell,‚Äù the Hatter added as an explanation; ‚ÄúI‚Äôve none of my own. I‚Äôm a hatter.‚Äù
Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter, who turned pale and fidgeted.
‚ÄúGive your evidence,‚Äù said the King; ‚Äúand don‚Äôt be nervous, or I‚Äôll have you executed on the spot.‚Äù
This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting from one foot to the other, looking uneasily at the Queen, and in his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the bread-and-butter.
Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.
‚ÄúI wish you wouldn‚Äôt squeeze so.‚Äù said the Dormouse, who was sitting next to her. ‚ÄúI can hardly breathe.‚Äù
‚ÄúI can‚Äôt help it,‚Äù said Alice very meekly: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm growing.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou‚Äôve no right to grow here,‚Äù said the Dormouse.
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt talk nonsense,‚Äù said Alice more boldly: ‚Äúyou know you‚Äôre growing too.‚Äù
‚ÄúYes, but I grow at a reasonable pace,‚Äù said the Dormouse: ‚Äúnot in that ridiculous fashion.‚Äù And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the other side of the court.
All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and, just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers of the court, ‚ÄúBring me the list of the singers in the last concert!‚Äù on which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.
‚ÄúGive your evidence,‚Äù the King repeated angrily, ‚Äúor I‚Äôll have you executed, whether you‚Äôre nervous or not.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm a poor man, your Majesty,‚Äù the Hatter began, in a trembling voice, ‚Äú‚Äîand I hadn‚Äôt begun my tea‚Äînot above a week or so‚Äîand what with the bread-and-butter getting so thin‚Äîand the twinkling of the tea‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúThe twinkling of the what?‚Äù said the King.
‚ÄúIt began with the tea,‚Äù the Hatter replied.
‚ÄúOf course twinkling begins with a T!‚Äù said the King sharply. ‚ÄúDo you take me for a dunce? Go on!‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm a poor man,‚Äù the Hatter went on, ‚Äúand most things twinkled after that‚Äîonly the March Hare said‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt!‚Äù the March Hare interrupted in a great hurry.
‚ÄúYou did!‚Äù said the Hatter.
‚ÄúI deny it!‚Äù said the March Hare.
‚ÄúHe denies it,‚Äù said the King: ‚Äúleave out that part.‚Äù
‚ÄúWell, at any rate, the Dormouse said‚Äî‚Äù the Hatter went on, looking anxiously round to see if he would deny it too: but the Dormouse denied nothing, being fast asleep.
‚ÄúAfter that,‚Äù continued the Hatter, ‚ÄúI cut some more bread-and-butter‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúBut what did the Dormouse say?‚Äù one of the jury asked.
‚ÄúThat I can‚Äôt remember,‚Äù said the Hatter.
‚ÄúYou must remember,‚Äù remarked the King, ‚Äúor I‚Äôll have you executed.‚Äù
The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went down on one knee. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a poor man, your Majesty,‚Äù he began.
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a very poor speaker,‚Äù said the King.
Here one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court. (As that is rather a hard word, I will just explain to you how it was done. They had a large canvas bag, which tied up at the mouth with strings: into this they slipped the guinea-pig, head first, and then sat upon it.)
‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad I‚Äôve seen that done,‚Äù thought Alice. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve so often read in the newspapers, at the end of trials, ‚ÄúThere was some attempts at applause, which was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court,‚Äù and I never understood what it meant till now.‚Äù
‚ÄúIf that‚Äôs all you know about it, you may stand down,‚Äù continued the King.
‚ÄúI can‚Äôt go no lower,‚Äù said the Hatter: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm on the floor, as it is.‚Äù
‚ÄúThen you may sit down,‚Äù the King replied.
Here the other guinea-pig cheered, and was suppressed.
‚ÄúCome, that finished the guinea-pigs!‚Äù thought Alice. ‚ÄúNow we shall get on better.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather finish my tea,‚Äù said the Hatter, with an anxious look at the Queen, who was reading the list of singers.
‚ÄúYou may go,‚Äù said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court, without even waiting to put his shoes on.
‚Äú‚Äîand just take his head off outside,‚Äù the Queen added to one of the officers: but the Hatter was out of sight before the officer could get to the door.
‚ÄúCall the next witness!‚Äù said the King.
The next witness was the Duchess‚Äôs cook. She carried the pepper-box in her hand, and Alice guessed who it was, even before she got into the court, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.
‚ÄúGive your evidence,‚Äù said the King.
‚ÄúShan‚Äôt,‚Äù said the cook.
The King looked anxiously at the White Rabbit, who said in a low voice, ‚ÄúYour Majesty must cross-examine this witness.‚Äù
‚ÄúWell, if I must, I must,‚Äù the King said, with a melancholy air, and, after folding his arms and frowning at the cook till his eyes were nearly out of sight, he said in a deep voice, ‚ÄúWhat are tarts made of?‚Äù
‚ÄúPepper, mostly,‚Äù said the cook.
‚ÄúTreacle,‚Äù said a sleepy voice behind her.
‚ÄúCollar that Dormouse,‚Äù the Queen shrieked out. ‚ÄúBehead that Dormouse! Turn that Dormouse out of court! Suppress him! Pinch him! Off with his whiskers!‚Äù
For some minutes the whole court was in confusion, getting the Dormouse turned out, and, by the time they had settled down again, the cook had disappeared.
‚ÄúNever mind!‚Äù said the King, with an air of great relief. ‚ÄúCall the next witness.‚Äù And he added in an undertone to the Queen, ‚ÄúReally, my dear, you must cross-examine the next witness. It quite makes my forehead ache!‚Äù
Alice watched the White Rabbit as he fumbled over the list, feeling very curious to see what the next witness would be like, ‚Äú‚Äîfor they haven‚Äôt got much evidence yet,‚Äù she said to herself. Imagine her surprise, when the White Rabbit read out, at the top of his shrill little voice, the name ‚ÄúAlice!‚Äù

resource.label: Alice in Wonderland - Chapter 12 - Alice‚Äôs Evidence

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice is called as a witness in the trial. She grows larger and larger, challenges the absurdity of the court, and finally, wakes up to find herself back on the riverbank with her sister, realizing it was all a dream.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: Back in her world, the adventure seemed like a dream. Yet, in her pocket was a small, glowing stone, a token from DaSCHland. Alice smiled, knowing that her journey had been real and that she would one day return to the wondrous realm of DaSCHland, where dreams and the rich tapestry of humanities research were just the beginning.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
‚ÄúHere!‚Äù cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before.
‚ÄúOh, I beg your pardon!‚Äù she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay, and began picking them up again as quickly as she could, for the accident of the goldfish kept running in her head, and she had a vague sort of idea that they must be collected at once and put back into the jury-box, or they would die.
‚ÄúThe trial cannot proceed,‚Äù said the King in a very grave voice, ‚Äúuntil all the jurymen are back in their proper places‚Äîall,‚Äù he repeated with great emphasis, looking hard at Alice as he said so.
Alice looked at the jury-box, and saw that, in her haste, she had put the Lizard in head downwards, and the poor little thing was waving its tail about in a melancholy way, being quite unable to move. She soon got it out again, and put it right; ‚Äúnot that it signifies much,‚Äù she said to herself; ‚ÄúI should think it would be quite as much use in the trial one way up as the other.‚Äù
As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the court.
‚ÄúWhat do you know about this business?‚Äù the King said to Alice.
‚ÄúNothing,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúNothing whatever?‚Äù persisted the King.
‚ÄúNothing whatever,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs very important,‚Äù the King said, turning to the jury. They were just beginning to write this down on their slates, when the White Rabbit interrupted: ‚ÄúUnimportant, your Majesty means, of course,‚Äù he said in a very respectful tone, but frowning and making faces at him as he spoke.
‚ÄúUnimportant, of course, I meant,‚Äù the King hastily said, and went on to himself in an undertone,
‚Äúimportant‚Äîunimportant‚Äîunimportant‚Äîimportant‚Äî‚Äù as if he were trying which word sounded best.
Some of the jury wrote it down ‚Äúimportant,‚Äù and some ‚Äúunimportant.‚Äù Alice could see this, as she was near enough to look over their slates; ‚Äúbut it doesn‚Äôt matter a bit,‚Äù she thought to herself.
At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in his note-book, cackled out ‚ÄúSilence!‚Äù and read out from his book, ‚ÄúRule Forty-two. All persons more than a mile high to leave the court.‚Äù
Everybody looked at Alice.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a mile high,‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúYou are,‚Äù said the King.
‚ÄúNearly two miles high,‚Äù added the Queen.
‚ÄúWell, I shan‚Äôt go, at any rate,‚Äù said Alice: ‚Äúbesides, that‚Äôs not a regular rule: you invented it just now.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the oldest rule in the book,‚Äù said the King.
‚ÄúThen it ought to be Number One,‚Äù said Alice.
The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily. ‚ÄúConsider your verdict,‚Äù he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,‚Äù said the White Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; ‚Äúthis paper has just been picked up.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs in it?‚Äù said the Queen.
‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt opened it yet,‚Äù said the White Rabbit, ‚Äúbut it seems to be a letter, written by the prisoner to‚Äîto somebody.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt must have been that,‚Äù said the King, ‚Äúunless it was written to nobody, which isn‚Äôt usual, you know.‚Äù
‚ÄúWho is it directed to?‚Äù said one of the jurymen.
‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt directed at all,‚Äù said the White Rabbit; ‚Äúin fact, there‚Äôs nothing written on the outside.‚Äù He unfolded the paper as he spoke, and added ‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt a letter, after all: it‚Äôs a set of verses.‚Äù
‚ÄúAre they in the prisoner‚Äôs handwriting?‚Äù asked another of the jurymen.
‚ÄúNo, they‚Äôre not,‚Äù said the White Rabbit, ‚Äúand that‚Äôs the queerest thing about it.‚Äù (The jury all looked puzzled.)
‚ÄúHe must have imitated somebody else‚Äôs hand,‚Äù said the King. (The jury all brightened up again.)
‚ÄúPlease your Majesty,‚Äù said the Knave, ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt write it, and they can‚Äôt prove I did: there‚Äôs no name signed at the end.‚Äù
‚ÄúIf you didn‚Äôt sign it,‚Äù said the King, ‚Äúthat only makes the matter worse. You must have meant some mischief, or else you‚Äôd have signed your name like an honest man.‚Äù
There was a general clapping of hands at this: it was the first really clever thing the King had said that day.
‚ÄúThat proves his guilt,‚Äù said the Queen.
‚ÄúIt proves nothing of the sort!‚Äù said Alice. ‚ÄúWhy, you don‚Äôt even know what they‚Äôre about!‚Äù
‚ÄúRead them,‚Äù said the King.
The White Rabbit put on his spectacles. ‚ÄúWhere shall I begin, please your Majesty?‚Äù he asked.
‚ÄúBegin at the beginning,‚Äù the King said gravely, ‚Äúand go on till you come to the end: then stop.‚Äù
These were the verses the White Rabbit read:‚Äî
‚ÄúThey told me you had been to her, And mentioned me to him: She gave me a good character, But said I could not swim.
He sent them word I had not gone (We know it to be true): If she should push the matter on, What would become of you?
I gave her one, they gave him two, You gave us three or more; They all returned from him to you, Though they were mine before.
If I or she should chance to be Involved in this affair, He trusts to you to set them free, Exactly as we were.
My notion was that you had been (Before she had this fit) An obstacle that came between Him, and ourselves, and it.
Don‚Äôt let him know she liked them best, For this must ever be A secret, kept from all the rest, Between yourself and me.‚Äù
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the most important piece of evidence we‚Äôve heard yet,‚Äù said the King, rubbing his hands; ‚Äúso now let the jury‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúIf any one of them can explain it,‚Äù said Alice, (she had grown so large in the last few minutes that she wasn‚Äôt a bit afraid of interrupting him,) ‚ÄúI‚Äôll give him sixpence. I don‚Äôt believe there‚Äôs an atom of meaning in it.‚Äù
