The jury all wrote down on their slates, ‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt believe there‚Äôs an atom of meaning in it,‚Äù but none of them attempted to explain the paper.
‚ÄúIf there‚Äôs no meaning in it,‚Äù said the King, ‚Äúthat saves a world of trouble, you know, as we needn‚Äôt try to find any. And yet I don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he went on, spreading out the verses on his knee, and looking at them with one eye; ‚ÄúI seem to see some meaning in them, after all. ‚Äú‚Äîsaid I could not swim‚Äî‚Äù you can‚Äôt swim, can you?‚Äù he added, turning to the Knave.
The Knave shook his head sadly. ‚ÄúDo I look like it?‚Äù he said. (Which he certainly did not, being made entirely of cardboard.)
‚ÄúAll right, so far,‚Äù said the King, and he went on muttering over the verses to himself: ‚Äú‚ÄòWe know it to be true‚Äî‚Äô that‚Äôs the jury, of course‚Äî‚ÄòI gave her one, they gave him two‚Äî‚Äô why, that must be what he did with the tarts, you know‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúBut, it goes on ‚Äòthey all returned from him to you,‚Äô‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúWhy, there they are!‚Äù said the King triumphantly, pointing to the tarts on the table. ‚ÄúNothing can be clearer than that. Then again‚Äî‚Äòbefore she had this fit‚Äî‚Äô you never had fits, my dear, I think?‚Äù he said to the Queen.
‚ÄúNever!‚Äù said the Queen furiously, throwing an inkstand at the Lizard as she spoke. (The unfortunate little Bill had left off writing on his slate with one finger, as he found it made no mark; but he now hastily began again, using the ink, that was trickling down his face, as long as it lasted.)
‚ÄúThen the words don‚Äôt fit you,‚Äù said the King, looking round the court with a smile. There was a dead silence.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a pun!‚Äù the King added in an offended tone, and everybody laughed, ‚ÄúLet the jury consider their verdict,‚Äù the King said, for about the twentieth time that day.
‚ÄúNo, no!‚Äù said the Queen. ‚ÄúSentence first‚Äîverdict afterwards.‚Äù
‚ÄúStuff and nonsense!‚Äù said Alice loudly. ‚ÄúThe idea of having the sentence first!‚Äù
‚ÄúHold your tongue!‚Äù said the Queen, turning purple.
‚ÄúI won‚Äôt!‚Äù said Alice.
‚ÄúOff with her head!‚Äù the Queen shouted at the top of her voice. Nobody moved.
‚ÄúWho cares for you?‚Äù said Alice, (she had grown to her full size by this time.) ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre nothing but a pack of cards!‚Äù
At this the whole pack rose up into the air, and came flying down upon her: she gave a little scream, half of fright and half of anger, and tried to beat them off, and found herself lying on the bank, with her head in the lap of her sister, who was gently brushing away some dead leaves that had fluttered down from the trees upon her face.
‚ÄúWake up, Alice dear!‚Äù said her sister; ‚ÄúWhy, what a long sleep you‚Äôve had!‚Äù
‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôve had such a curious dream!‚Äù said Alice, and she told her sister, as well as she could remember them, all these strange Adventures of hers that you have just been reading about; and when she had finished, her sister kissed her, and said, ‚ÄúIt was a curious dream, dear, certainly: but now run in to your tea; it‚Äôs getting late.‚Äù So Alice got up and ran off, thinking while she ran, as well she might, what a wonderful dream it had been.
____________
But her sister sat still just as she left her, leaning her head on her hand, watching the setting sun, and thinking of little Alice and all her wonderful Adventures, till she too began dreaming after a fashion, and this was her dream:‚Äî
First, she dreamed of little Alice herself, and once again the tiny hands were clasped upon her knee, and the bright eager eyes were looking up into hers‚Äîshe could hear the very tones of her voice, and see that queer little toss of her head to keep back the wandering hair that would always get into her eyes‚Äîand still as she listened, or seemed to listen, the whole place around her became alive with the strange creatures of her little sister‚Äôs dream.
The long grass rustled at her feet as the White Rabbit hurried by‚Äîthe frightened Mouse splashed his way through the neighbouring pool‚Äîshe could hear the rattle of the teacups as the March Hare and his friends shared their never-ending meal, and the shrill voice of the Queen ordering off her unfortunate guests to execution‚Äîonce more the pig-baby was sneezing on the Duchess‚Äôs knee, while plates and dishes crashed around it‚Äîonce more the shriek of the Gryphon, the squeaking of the Lizard‚Äôs slate-pencil, and the choking of the suppressed guinea-pigs, filled the air, mixed up with the distant sobs of the miserable Mock Turtle.
So she sat on, with closed eyes, and half believed herself in Wonderland, though she knew she had but to open them again, and all would change to dull reality‚Äîthe grass would be only rustling in the wind, and the pool rippling to the waving of the reeds‚Äîthe rattling teacups would change to tinkling sheep-bells, and the Queen‚Äôs shrill cries to the voice of the shepherd boy‚Äîand the sneeze of the baby, the shriek of the Gryphon, and all the other queer noises, would change (she knew) to the confused clamour of the busy farm-yard‚Äîwhile the lowing of the cattle in the distance would take the place of the Mock Turtle‚Äôs heavy sobs.
Lastly, she pictured to herself how this same little sister of hers would, in the after-time, be herself a grown woman; and how she would keep, through all her riper years, the simple and loving heart of her childhood: and how she would gather about her other little children, and make their eyes bright and eager with many a strange tale, perhaps even with the dream of Wonderland of long ago: and how she would feel with all their simple sorrows, and find a pleasure in all their simple joys, remembering her own child-life, and the happy summer days.
THE END.

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter nan - Dramatis Personae and chessboard

text-prop.name: :hasDescription

text.comment: The list of dramatis personae only appeared in early editions of the book. Carroll later removed it, when he replaced his preface in 1896.

text-prop.text:
The "Dramatis Personae and Chessboard" section of Lewis Carroll's "Through the Looking Glass" introduces the characters and the unique chessboard structure that defines the story's framework.
It presents a cast list resembling a play, featuring key characters like Alice, the Red Queen, the White Queen, and other chess pieces brought to life. This setup not only outlines the main players but also hints at their roles and interactions throughout the narrative. The chessboard itself symbolizes the structured yet fantastical journey Alice will embark on, where each move and encounter adheres to the rules and unpredictability of a chess game.
This inventive preface establishes a playful and strategic tone, blending logic with imagination, and setting the stage for Alice's adventures in the whimsical world beyond the looking glass.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
The "Dramatis Personae and Data Structure" section of Alice in DaSCHland introduces the key entities in the digital landscape and the unique framework of interrelated data points that shape the journey. Much like a play's cast list, this prelude presents Alice, the Red Node, the White Interface, and other critical components of the system. These elements hint at their roles within the structured but whimsical environment, where interactions follow the logic of an interconnected database.
The data structure itself reflects both the order and unpredictability Alice will encounter, setting a tone where logic, imagination, and algorithms combine to guide her through the intricate world of DaSCHland.

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter nan - Preface

text-prop.name: :hasDescription

text.comment: The preface has no chapter number because it does not belong to the story itself. It was placed at the beginning of the first edition of Through the Looking glass and what Alice found there.

text-prop.text:
The preface to Lewis Carroll's "Through the Looking Glass" serves as an introductory note, where Carroll addresses his readers directly.
He reflects on the success of "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" and expresses gratitude for its warm reception. Carroll also provides insight into the creation of the sequel, sharing his intentions to craft another whimsical and imaginative tale that continues to captivate the hearts of both children and adults. This preface establishes a connection between the author and his audience, setting a tone of nostalgia and anticipation for the new adventures that await Alice in the looking-glass world. Through this preamble, Carroll invites readers to once again suspend disbelief and join Alice on her fantastical journey.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
The preface to Alice in DaSCHland serves as an introductory note, where the creators address their users directly. Reflecting on the success of the original Alice's Adventures in Data project, they express appreciation for the enthusiastic engagement from the community. This preface offers a glimpse into the development of the sequel, aiming to expand the digital landscape while maintaining the playful and imaginative elements that captivated users. The authors set a tone of nostalgia and curiosity, inviting users to explore new data-driven adventures in DaSCHland.
Through this introduction, readers are once again encouraged to delve into the imaginative fusion of digital exploration and storytelling.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
As the chess-problem, given on a previous page, has puzzled some of my readers, it may be well to explain that it is correctly worked out, so far as themoves are concerned. The alternation of Red and White is perhaps not so strictly observed as it might be, and the ‚Äòcastling‚Äô of the three Queens is merely a way to saying that they entered the palace: but the ‚Äòcheck‚Äô of the White King at move 6, the capture of the Red Knight at move 7, and the final ‚Äòcheckmate‚Äô of the Red King, will be found, by anyone who will take the trouble to set the pieces and play the moves as directed, to be strictly in accordance with the laws of the game.
The new words, in the poem Jabberwocky (see p. 202), have given rise to some differences of opinion as to their pronunciation: so it may be well to give instructions on that point also. Pronounce ‚Äòslithy‚Äô as if it were the two words ‚Äòsly, the‚Äô: make the ‚Äòg‚Äô hard in ‚Äògyre‚Äô and ‚Äògimble‚Äô: and pronounce ‚Äòrath‚Äô to rhyme with ‚Äòbath‚Äô.

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter nan - Poem: ‚ÄúChild of the pure unclouded brow‚Äù

text-prop.name: :hasName
text-prop.text: Poem: ‚ÄúChild of the pure unclouded brow‚Äù

text-prop.name: :hasDescription

text.comment: The poem has no chapter number because it does not belong to the story. It was placed at the beginning of the first edition of Through the Looking glass and what Alice found there.

text-prop.text:
The poem "Child of the pure unclouded brow" serves as a prologue to Lewis Carroll's "Through the Looking Glass."
This dedicatory poem is an ode to Alice Liddell, the inspiration for Alice's character. Carroll reflects on the innocence and purity of childhood, capturing the essence of Alice's untainted, imaginative spirit. Through lyrical and affectionate verses, he immortalizes the charm of his muse and the enchantment of their shared adventures. This poem sets a nostalgic and tender tone for the sequel, bridging the real and fictional worlds, and inviting readers to embark on another whimsical journey with Alice.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
The poem "Child of the Pure Digital Stream" serves as a prologue to Alice in DaSCHland.
This dedicatory piece is an ode to the users and developers who inspire Alice‚Äôs digital journey. The creators reflect on the purity and limitless potential of data, capturing the unbounded curiosity and imagination that drives the project's evolution. Through thoughtful and innovative verses, they immortalize the pioneering spirit of those who contributed to shaping the digital landscape. This poem sets a reflective and inspiring tone for the new chapter, merging the digital and creative worlds, and inviting users to join Alice on another groundbreaking exploration of data and discovery.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
Child of the pure unclouded brow And dreaming eyes of wonder! Though time be fleet, and I and thou Are half a life asunder, Thy loving smile will surely hail The love-gift of a fairy-tale.
I have not seen thy sunny face, Nor heard thy silver laughter; No thought of me shall find a place In thy young life‚Äôs hereafter ‚Äì Enough that now thou wilt not fail To listen to my fairy-tale.
A tale begun in other days, When summer suns were glowing ‚Äì A simple chime, that served to time The rhythm of our rowing ‚Äì Whose echoes live in memory yet, Though envious years would say ‚Äòforget‚Äô.
Come, hearken then, ere voice of dread, With bitter tidings laden, Shall summon to unwelcome bed A melancholy maiden! We are but older children, dear, Who fret to find our bedtime near.
Without, the frost, the blinding snow, The storm-wind‚Äôs moody madness ‚Äì Within, the firelight‚Äôs ruddy glow, And childhood‚Äôs nest of gladness. The magic words shall hold thee fast: Thou shalt not heed the raving blast.
And though the shadow of a sigh May tremble through the story, For ‚Äòhappy summer days‚Äô gone by, And vanish‚Äôd summer glory ‚Äì It shall not touch with breath of bale The pleasance of our fairy-tale.

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter 1 - Looking-Glass House

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice is playing with her kittens and wonders what it would be like to step through the mirror (looking-glass). She finds herself in the Looking-Glass House, where everything is reversed. She explores the house and encounters animated chess pieces.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, Alice, guided by her robotic companion RabbitIT, encountered a mirror in her virtual home. Unlike any ordinary mirror, this one served as a portal within the DaSCH system, leading to a reversed world.
As Alice stepped through, she found herself in an environment where everything was flipped‚Äîtexts read backward, clocks ran counter, and even conversations followed reversed logic. RabbitIT, powered by DaSCH‚Äôs archives, provided insights and historical context, helping Alice navigate this topsy-turvy realm.
This chapter follows Alice as she explores and adapts to this mirrored world, relying on RabbitIT to make sense of the reversed dynamics. Her journey through the looking-glass reveals the complexities of this digital inversion, illustrating the capabilities of DaSCHland‚Äôs advanced technology.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
One thing was certain, that the white kitten had had nothing to do with it:‚Äîit was the black kitten‚Äôs fault entirely. For the white kitten had been having its face washed by the old cat for the last quarter of an hour (and bearing it pretty well, considering); so you see that it couldn‚Äôt have had any hand in the mischief.
The way Dinah washed her children‚Äôs faces was this: first she held the poor thing down by its ear with one paw, and then with the other paw she rubbed its face all over, the wrong way, beginning at the nose: and just now, as I said, she was hard at work on the white kitten, which was lying quite still and trying to purr‚Äîno doubt feeling that it was all meant for its good.
But the black kitten had been finished with earlier in the afternoon, and so, while Alice was sitting curled up in a corner of the great arm-chair, half talking to herself and half asleep, the kitten had been having a grand game of romps with the ball of worsted Alice had been trying to wind up, and had been rolling it up and down till it had all come undone again; and there it was, spread over the hearth-rug, all knots and tangles, with the kitten running after its own tail in the middle.
‚ÄòOh, you wicked little thing!‚Äô cried Alice, catching up the kitten, and giving it a little kiss to make it understand that it was in disgrace. ‚ÄòReally, Dinah ought to have taught you better manners! You ought, Dinah, you know you ought!‚Äô she added, looking reproachfully at the old cat, and speaking in as cross a voice as she could manage‚Äîand then she scrambled back into the arm-chair, taking the kitten and the worsted with her, and began winding up the ball again. But she didn‚Äôt get on very fast, as she was talking all the time, sometimes to the kitten, and sometimes to herself. Kitty sat very demurely on her knee, pretending to watch the progress of the winding, and now and then putting out one paw and gently touching the ball, as if it would be glad to help, if it might.
‚ÄòDo you know what to-morrow is, Kitty?‚Äô Alice began. ‚ÄòYou‚Äôd have guessed if you‚Äôd been up in the window with me‚Äîonly Dinah was making you tidy, so you couldn‚Äôt. I was watching the boys getting in sticks for the bonfire‚Äîand it wants plenty of sticks, Kitty! Only it got so cold, and it snowed so, they had to leave off. Never mind, Kitty, we‚Äôll go and see the bonfire to-morrow.‚Äô Here Alice wound two or three turns of the worsted round the kitten‚Äôs neck, just to see how it would look: this led to a scramble, in which the ball rolled down upon the floor, and yards and yards of it got unwound again.
‚ÄòDo you know, I was so angry, Kitty,‚Äô Alice went on as soon as they were comfortably settled again, ‚Äòwhen I saw all the mischief you had been doing, I was very nearly opening the window, and putting you out into the snow! And you‚Äôd have deserved it, you little mischievous darling! What have you got to say for yourself? Now don‚Äôt interrupt me!‚Äô she went on, holding up one finger. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm going to tell you all your faults. Number one: you squeaked twice while Dinah was washing your face this morning. Now you can‚Äôt deny it, Kitty: I heard you! What‚Äôs that you say?‚Äô (pretending that the kitten was speaking.) ‚ÄòHer paw went into your eye? Well, that‚Äôs your fault, for keeping your eyes open‚Äîif you‚Äôd shut them tight up, it wouldn‚Äôt have happened. Now don‚Äôt make any more excuses, but listen! Number two: you pulled Snowdrop away by the tail just as I had put down the saucer of milk before her! What, you were thirsty, were you? How do you know she wasn‚Äôt thirsty too? Now for number three: you unwound every bit of the worsted while I wasn‚Äôt looking!
‚ÄòThat‚Äôs three faults, Kitty, and you‚Äôve not been punished for any of them yet. You know I‚Äôm saving up all your punishments for Wednesday week‚ÄîSuppose they had saved up all my punishments!‚Äô she went on, talking more to herself than the kitten. ‚ÄòWhat would they do at the end of a year? I should be sent to prison, I suppose, when the day came. Or‚Äîlet me see‚Äîsuppose each punishment was to be going without a dinner: then, when the miserable day came, I should have to go without fifty dinners at once! Well, I shouldn‚Äôt mind that much! I‚Äôd far rather go without them than eat them!
‚ÄòDo you hear the snow against the window-panes, Kitty? How nice and soft it sounds! Just as if some one was kissing the window all over outside. I wonder if the snow loves the trees and fields, that it kisses them so gently? And then it covers them up snug, you know, with a white quilt; and perhaps it says, ‚ÄúGo to sleep, darlings, till the summer comes again.‚Äù And when they wake up in the summer, Kitty, they dress themselves all in green, and dance about‚Äîwhenever the wind blows‚Äîoh, that‚Äôs very pretty!‚Äô cried Alice, dropping the ball of worsted to clap her hands. ‚ÄòAnd I do so wish it was true! I‚Äôm sure the woods look sleepy in the autumn, when the leaves are getting brown.
‚ÄòKitty, can you play chess? Now, don‚Äôt smile, my dear, I‚Äôm asking it seriously. Because, when we were playing just now, you watched just as if you understood it: and when I said ‚ÄúCheck!‚Äù you purred! Well, it was a nice check, Kitty, and really I might have won, if it hadn‚Äôt been for that nasty Knight, that came wiggling down among my pieces. Kitty, dear, let‚Äôs pretend‚Äî‚Äô And here I wish I could tell you half the things Alice used to say, beginning with her favourite phrase ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs pretend.‚Äô She had had quite a long argument with her sister only the day before‚Äîall because Alice had begun with ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs pretend we‚Äôre kings and queens;‚Äô and her sister, who liked being very exact, had argued that they couldn‚Äôt, because there were only two of them, and Alice had been reduced at last to say, ‚ÄòWell, you can be one of them then, and I‚Äôll be all the rest.‚Äô And once she had really frightened her old nurse by shouting suddenly in her ear, ‚ÄòNurse! Do let‚Äôs pretend that I‚Äôm a hungry hyaena, and you‚Äôre a bone.‚Äô
But this is taking us away from Alice‚Äôs speech to the kitten. ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs pretend that you‚Äôre the Red Queen, Kitty! Do you know, I think if you sat up and folded your arms, you‚Äôd look exactly like her. Now do try, there‚Äôs a dear!‚Äô And Alice got the Red Queen off the table, and set it up before the kitten as a model for it to imitate: however, the thing didn‚Äôt succeed, principally, Alice said, because the kitten wouldn‚Äôt fold its arms properly. So, to punish it, she held it up to the Looking-glass, that it might see how sulky it was‚Äî‚Äòand if you‚Äôre not good directly,‚Äô she added, ‚ÄòI‚Äôll put you through into Looking-glass House. How would you like that?‚Äô
‚ÄòNow, if you‚Äôll only attend, Kitty, and not talk so much, I‚Äôll tell you all my ideas about Looking-glass House. First, there‚Äôs the room you can see through the glass‚Äîthat‚Äôs just the same as our drawing room, only the things go the other way. I can see all of it when I get upon a chair‚Äîall but the bit behind the fireplace. Oh! I do so wish I could see that bit! I want so much to know whether they‚Äôve a fire in the winter: you never can tell, you know, unless our fire smokes, and then smoke comes up in that room too‚Äîbut that may be only pretence, just to make it look as if they had a fire. Well then, the books are something like our books, only the words go the wrong way; I know that, because I‚Äôve held up one of our books to the glass, and then they hold up one in the other room.
‚ÄòHow would you like to live in Looking-glass House, Kitty? I wonder if they‚Äôd give you milk in there? Perhaps Looking-glass milk isn‚Äôt good to drink‚ÄîBut oh, Kitty! now we come to the passage. You can just see a little peep of the passage in Looking-glass House, if you leave the door of our drawing-room wide open: and it‚Äôs very like our passage as far as you can see, only you know it may be quite different on beyond. Oh, Kitty! how nice it would be if we could only get through into Looking-glass House! I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs got, oh! such beautiful things in it! Let‚Äôs pretend there‚Äôs a way of getting through into it, somehow, Kitty. Let‚Äôs pretend the glass has got all soft like gauze, so that we can get through. Why, it‚Äôs turning into a sort of mist now, I declare! It‚Äôll be easy enough to get through‚Äî‚Äô She was up on the chimney-piece while she said this, though she hardly knew how she had got there. And certainly the glass was beginning to melt away, just like a bright silvery mist.
In another moment Alice was through the glass, and had jumped lightly down into the Looking-glass room. The very first thing she did was to look whether there was a fire in the fireplace, and she was quite pleased to find that there was a real one, blazing away as brightly as the one she had left behind. ‚ÄòSo I shall be as warm here as I was in the old room,‚Äô thought Alice: ‚Äòwarmer, in fact, because there‚Äôll be no one here to scold me away from the fire. Oh, what fun it‚Äôll be, when they see me through the glass in here, and can‚Äôt get at me!‚Äô
Then she began looking about, and noticed that what could be seen from the old room was quite common and uninteresting, but that all the rest was as different as possible. For instance, the pictures on the wall next the fire seemed to be all alive, and the very clock on the chimney-piece (you know you can only see the back of it in the Looking-glass) had got the face of a little old man, and grinned at her.
‚ÄòThey don‚Äôt keep this room so tidy as the other,‚Äô Alice thought to herself, as she noticed several of the chessmen down in the hearth among the cinders: but in another moment, with a little ‚ÄòOh!‚Äô of surprise, she was down on her hands and knees watching them. The chessmen were walking about, two and two!
‚ÄòHere are the Red King and the Red Queen,‚Äô Alice said (in a whisper, for fear of frightening them), ‚Äòand there are the White King and the White Queen sitting on the edge of the shovel‚Äîand here are two castles walking arm in arm‚ÄîI don‚Äôt think they can hear me,‚Äô she went on, as she put her head closer down, ‚Äòand I‚Äôm nearly sure they can‚Äôt see me. I feel somehow as if I were invisible‚Äî‚Äô
Here something began squeaking on the table behind Alice, and made her turn her head just in time to see one of the White Pawns roll over and begin kicking: she watched it with great curiosity to see what would happen next.
‚ÄòIt is the voice of my child!‚Äô the White Queen cried out as she rushed past the King, so violently that she knocked him over among the cinders. ‚ÄòMy precious Lily! My imperial kitten!‚Äô and she began scrambling wildly up the side of the fender.
‚ÄòImperial fiddlestick!‚Äô said the King, rubbing his nose, which had been hurt by the fall. He had a right to be a little annoyed with the Queen, for he was covered with ashes from head to foot.
Alice was very anxious to be of use, and, as the poor little Lily was nearly screaming herself into a fit, she hastily picked up the Queen and set her on the table by the side of her noisy little daughter.
The Queen gasped, and sat down: the rapid journey through the air had quite taken away her breath and for a minute or two she could do nothing but hug the little Lily in silence. As soon as she had recovered her breath a little, she called out to the White King, who was sitting sulkily among the ashes, ‚ÄòMind the volcano!‚Äô
‚ÄòWhat volcano?‚Äô said the King, looking up anxiously into the fire, as if he thought that was the most likely place to find one.
‚ÄòBlew‚Äîme‚Äîup,‚Äô panted the Queen, who was still a little out of breath. ‚ÄòMind you come up‚Äîthe regular way‚Äîdon‚Äôt get blown up!‚Äô
Alice watched the White King as he slowly struggled up from bar to bar, till at last she said, ‚ÄòWhy, you‚Äôll be hours and hours getting to the table, at that rate. I‚Äôd far better help you, hadn‚Äôt I?‚Äô But the King took no notice of the question: it was quite clear that he could neither hear her nor see her.
So Alice picked him up very gently, and lifted him across more slowly than she had lifted the Queen, that she mightn‚Äôt take his breath away: but, before she put him on the table, she thought she might as well dust him a little, he was so covered with ashes.
She said afterwards that she had never seen in all her life such a face as the King made, when he found himself held in the air by an invisible hand, and being dusted: he was far too much astonished to cry out, but his eyes and his mouth went on getting larger and larger, and rounder and rounder, till her hand shook so with laughing that she nearly let him drop upon the floor.
‚ÄòOh! please don‚Äôt make such faces, my dear!‚Äô she cried out, quite forgetting that the King couldn‚Äôt hear her. ‚ÄòYou make me laugh so that I can hardly hold you! And don‚Äôt keep your mouth so wide open! All the ashes will get into it‚Äîthere, now I think you‚Äôre tidy enough!‚Äô she added, as she smoothed his hair, and set him upon the table near the Queen.
The King immediately fell flat on his back, and lay perfectly still: and Alice was a little alarmed at what she had done, and went round the room to see if she could find any water to throw over him. However, she could find nothing but a bottle of ink, and when she got back with it she found he had recovered, and he and the Queen were talking together in a frightened whisper‚Äîso low, that Alice could hardly hear what they said.
The King was saying, ‚ÄòI assure, you my dear, I turned cold to the very ends of my whiskers!‚Äô
To which the Queen replied, ‚ÄòYou haven‚Äôt got any whiskers.‚Äô
‚ÄòThe horror of that moment,‚Äô the King went on, ‚ÄòI shall never, never forget!‚Äô
‚ÄòYou will, though,‚Äô the Queen said, ‚Äòif you don‚Äôt make a memorandum of it.‚Äô
Alice looked on with great interest as the King took an enormous memorandum-book out of his pocket, and began writing. A sudden thought struck her, and she took hold of the end of the pencil, which came some way over his shoulder, and began writing for him.
The poor King looked puzzled and unhappy, and struggled with the pencil for some time without saying anything; but Alice was too strong for him, and at last he panted out, ‚ÄòMy dear! I really must get a thinner pencil. I can‚Äôt manage this one a bit; it writes all manner of things that I don‚Äôt intend‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòWhat manner of things?‚Äô said the Queen, looking over the book (in which Alice had put ‚ÄòThe White Knight is sliding down the poker. He balances very badly‚Äô) ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs not a memorandum of your feelings!‚Äô
There was a book lying near Alice on the table, and while she sat watching the White King (for she was still a little anxious about him, and had the ink all ready to throw over him, in case he fainted again), she turned over the leaves, to find some part that she could read, ‚Äò‚Äîfor it‚Äôs all in some language I don‚Äôt know,‚Äô she said to herself.
It was like this.
YKCOWREBBAJ
sevot yhtils eht dna,gillirb sawT‚Äô ebaw eht ni elbmig dna eryg diD ,sevogorob eht erew ysmim llA .ebargtuo shtar emom eht dnA
She puzzled over this for some time, but at last a bright thought struck her. ‚ÄòWhy, it‚Äôs a Looking-glass book, of course! And if I hold it up to a glass, the words will all go the right way again.‚Äô
This was the poem that Alice read.
JABBERWOCKY
‚ÄòTwas brillig, and the slithy toves Did gyre and gimble in the wabe; All mimsy were the borogoves, And the mome raths outgrabe.
‚ÄòBeware the Jabberwock, my son! The jaws that bite, the claws that catch! Beware the Jubjub bird, and shun The frumious Bandersnatch!‚Äô
He took his vorpal sword in hand: Long time the manxome foe he sought‚Äî So rested he by the Tumtum tree, And stood awhile in thought.
And as in uffish thought he stood, The Jabberwock, with eyes of flame, Came whiffling through the tulgey wood, And burbled as it came!
One, two! One, two! And through and through The vorpal blade went snicker-snack! He left it dead, and with its head He went galumphing back.
‚ÄòAnd hast thou slain the Jabberwock? Come to my arms, my beamish boy! O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!‚Äô He chortled in his joy.
‚ÄòTwas brillig, and the slithy toves Did gyre and gimble in the wabe; All mimsy were the borogoves, And the mome raths outgrabe.
‚ÄòIt seems very pretty,‚Äô she said when she had finished it, ‚Äòbut it‚Äôs rather hard to understand!‚Äô (You see she didn‚Äôt like to confess, ever to herself, that she couldn‚Äôt make it out at all.) ‚ÄòSomehow it seems to fill my head with ideas‚Äîonly I don‚Äôt exactly know what they are! However, somebody killed something: that‚Äôs clear, at any rate‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòBut oh!‚Äô thought Alice, suddenly jumping up, ‚Äòif I don‚Äôt make haste I shall have to go back through the Looking-glass, before I‚Äôve seen what the rest of the house is like! Let‚Äôs have a look at the garden first!‚Äô She was out of the room in a moment, and ran down stairs‚Äîor, at least, it wasn‚Äôt exactly running, but a new invention of hers for getting down stairs quickly and easily, as Alice said to herself. She just kept the tips of her fingers on the hand-rail, and floated gently down without even touching the stairs with her feet; then she floated on through the hall, and would have gone straight out at the door in the same way, if she hadn‚Äôt caught hold of the door-post. She was getting a little giddy with so much floating in the air, and was rather glad to find herself walking again in the natural way.

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter 2 - The Garden of Live Flowers

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice leaves the house and enters a garden filled with talking flowers. She meets the Red Queen, who explains that the land is laid out like a giant chessboard. The Red Queen guides Alice on how she can become a queen by moving through the different squares of the chessboard.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, guided by RabbitIT, Alice entered a digital garden crafted by the DaSCH repository. Here, she encountered talking flowers, each with dialogues derived from literary texts. The flowers humorously critiqued Alice's appearance and engaged in light chatter about their existence as digital entities.
RabbitIT assisted Alice by providing context and translations for the flowers' remarks, enriching her interaction. This chapter showcases Alice navigating a mix of playful criticism and conversation, illustrating the innovative integration of literature and technology in DaSCHland's virtual environment.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
‚ÄòI should see the garden far better,‚Äô said Alice to herself, ‚Äòif I could get to the top of that hill: and here‚Äôs a path that leads straight to it‚Äîat least, no, it doesn‚Äôt do that‚Äî‚Äô (after going a few yards along the path, and turning several sharp corners), ‚Äòbut I suppose it will at last. But how curiously it twists! It‚Äôs more like a corkscrew than a path! Well, this turn goes to the hill, I suppose‚Äîno, it doesn‚Äôt! This goes straight back to the house! Well then, I‚Äôll try it the other way.‚Äô
And so she did: wandering up and down, and trying turn after turn, but always coming back to the house, do what she would. Indeed, once, when she turned a corner rather more quickly than usual, she ran against it before she could stop herself.
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs no use talking about it,‚Äô Alice said, looking up at the house and pretending it was arguing with her. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm not going in again yet. I know I should have to get through the Looking-glass again‚Äîback into the old room‚Äîand there‚Äôd be an end of all my adventures!‚Äô
So, resolutely turning her back upon the house, she set out once more down the path, determined to keep straight on till she got to the hill. For a few minutes all went on well, and she was just saying, ‚ÄòI really shall do it this time‚Äî‚Äô when the path gave a sudden twist and shook itself (as she described it afterwards), and the next moment she found herself actually walking in at the door.
‚ÄòOh, it‚Äôs too bad!‚Äô she cried. ‚ÄòI never saw such a house for getting in the way! Never!‚Äô
However, there was the hill full in sight, so there was nothing to be done but start again. This time she came upon a large flower-bed, with a border of daisies, and a willow-tree growing in the middle.
‚ÄòO Tiger-lily,‚Äô said Alice, addressing herself to one that was waving gracefully about in the wind, ‚ÄòI wish you could talk!‚Äô
‚ÄòWe can talk,‚Äô said the Tiger-lily: ‚Äòwhen there‚Äôs anybody worth talking to.‚Äô
Alice was so astonished that she could not speak for a minute: it quite seemed to take her breath away. At length, as the Tiger-lily only went on waving about, she spoke again, in a timid voice‚Äîalmost in a whisper. ‚ÄòAnd can all the flowers talk?‚Äô
‚ÄòAs well as you can,‚Äô said the Tiger-lily. ‚ÄòAnd a great deal louder.‚Äô
‚ÄòIt isn‚Äôt manners for us to begin, you know,‚Äô said the Rose, ‚Äòand I really was wondering when you‚Äôd speak! Said I to myself, ‚ÄúHer face has got some sense in it, though it‚Äôs not a clever one!‚Äù Still, you‚Äôre the right colour, and that goes a long way.‚Äô
‚ÄòI don‚Äôt care about the colour,‚Äô the Tiger-lily remarked. ‚ÄòIf only her petals curled up a little more, she‚Äôd be all right.‚Äô
Alice didn‚Äôt like being criticised, so she began asking questions. ‚ÄòAren‚Äôt you sometimes frightened at being planted out here, with nobody to take care of you?‚Äô
‚ÄòThere‚Äôs the tree in the middle,‚Äô said the Rose: ‚Äòwhat else is it good for?‚Äô
‚ÄòBut what could it do, if any danger came?‚Äô Alice asked.
‚ÄòIt says ‚ÄúBough-wough!‚Äù‚Äô cried a Daisy: ‚Äòthat‚Äôs why its branches are called boughs!‚Äô
‚ÄòDidn‚Äôt you know that?‚Äô cried another Daisy, and here they all began shouting together, till the air seemed quite full of little shrill voices. ‚ÄòSilence, every one of you!‚Äô cried the Tiger-lily, waving itself passionately from side to side, and trembling with excitement. ‚ÄòThey know I can‚Äôt get at them!‚Äô it panted, bending its quivering head towards Alice, ‚Äòor they wouldn‚Äôt dare to do it!‚Äô
‚ÄòNever mind!‚Äô Alice said in a soothing tone, and stooping down to the daisies, who were just beginning again, she whispered, ‚ÄòIf you don‚Äôt hold your tongues, I‚Äôll pick you!‚Äô
There was silence in a moment, and several of the pink daisies turned white.
‚ÄòThat‚Äôs right!‚Äô said the Tiger-lily. ‚ÄòThe daisies are worst of all. When one speaks, they all begin together, and it‚Äôs enough to make one wither to hear the way they go on!‚Äô
‚ÄòHow is it you can all talk so nicely?‚Äô Alice said, hoping to get it into a better temper by a compliment. ‚ÄòI‚Äôve been in many gardens before, but none of the flowers could talk.‚Äô
‚ÄòPut your hand down, and feel the ground,‚Äô said the Tiger-lily. ‚ÄòThen you‚Äôll know why.‚Äô
Alice did so. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs very hard,‚Äô she said, ‚Äòbut I don‚Äôt see what that has to do with it.‚Äô
‚ÄòIn most gardens,‚Äô the Tiger-lily said, ‚Äòthey make the beds too soft‚Äîso that the flowers are always asleep.‚Äô
This sounded a very good reason, and Alice was quite pleased to know it. ‚ÄòI never thought of that before!‚Äô she said.
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs my opinion that you never think at all,‚Äô the Rose said in a rather severe tone.
‚ÄòI never saw anybody that looked stupider,‚Äô a Violet said, so suddenly, that Alice quite jumped; for it hadn‚Äôt spoken before.
‚ÄòHold your tongue!‚Äô cried the Tiger-lily. ‚ÄòAs if you ever saw anybody! You keep your head under the leaves, and snore away there, till you know no more what‚Äôs going on in the world, than if you were a bud!‚Äô
‚ÄòAre there any more people in the garden besides me?‚Äô Alice said, not choosing to notice the Rose‚Äôs last remark.
‚ÄòThere‚Äôs one other flower in the garden that can move about like you,‚Äô said the Rose. ‚ÄòI wonder how you do it‚Äî‚Äô (‚ÄòYou‚Äôre always wondering,‚Äô said the Tiger-lily), ‚Äòbut she‚Äôs more bushy than you are.‚Äô
‚ÄòIs she like me?‚Äô Alice asked eagerly, for the thought crossed her mind, ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs another little girl in the garden, somewhere!‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, she has the same awkward shape as you,‚Äô the Rose said, ‚Äòbut she‚Äôs redder‚Äîand her petals are shorter, I think.‚Äô
‚ÄòHer petals are done up close, almost like a dahlia,‚Äô the Tiger-lily interrupted: ‚Äònot tumbled about anyhow, like yours.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut that‚Äôs not your fault,‚Äô the Rose added kindly: ‚Äòyou‚Äôre beginning to fade, you know‚Äîand then one can‚Äôt help one‚Äôs petals getting a little untidy.‚Äô
Alice didn‚Äôt like this idea at all: so, to change the subject, she asked ‚ÄòDoes she ever come out here?‚Äô
‚ÄòI daresay you‚Äôll see her soon,‚Äô said the Rose. ‚ÄòShe‚Äôs one of the thorny kind.‚Äô
‚ÄòWhere does she wear the thorns?‚Äô Alice asked with some curiosity.
‚ÄòWhy all round her head, of course,‚Äô the Rose replied. ‚ÄòI was wondering you hadn‚Äôt got some too. I thought it was the regular rule.‚Äô
‚ÄòShe‚Äôs coming!‚Äô cried the Larkspur. ‚ÄòI hear her footstep, thump, thump, thump, along the gravel-walk!‚Äô
Alice looked round eagerly, and found that it was the Red Queen. ‚ÄòShe‚Äôs grown a good deal!‚Äô was her first remark. She had indeed: when Alice first found her in the ashes, she had been only three inches high‚Äîand here she was, half a head taller than Alice herself!
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs the fresh air that does it,‚Äô said the Rose: ‚Äòwonderfully fine air it is, out here.‚Äô
‚ÄòI think I‚Äôll go and meet her,‚Äô said Alice, for, though the flowers were interesting enough, she felt that it would be far grander to have a talk with a real Queen.
‚ÄòYou can‚Äôt possibly do that,‚Äô said the Rose: ‚ÄòI should advise you to walk the other way.‚Äô
This sounded nonsense to Alice, so she said nothing, but set off at once towards the Red Queen. To her surprise, she lost sight of her in a moment, and found herself walking in at the front-door again.
A little provoked, she drew back, and after looking everywhere for the queen (whom she spied out at last, a long way off), she thought she would try the plan, this time, of walking in the opposite direction.
It succeeded beautifully. She had not been walking a minute before she found herself face to face with the Red Queen, and full in sight of the hill she had been so long aiming at.
‚ÄòWhere do you come from?‚Äô said the Red Queen. ‚ÄòAnd where are you going? Look up, speak nicely, and don‚Äôt twiddle your fingers all the time.‚Äô
Alice attended to all these directions, and explained, as well as she could, that she had lost her way.
‚ÄòI don‚Äôt know what you mean by your way,‚Äô said the Queen: ‚Äòall the ways about here belong to me‚Äîbut why did you come out here at all?‚Äô she added in a kinder tone. ‚ÄòCurtsey while you‚Äôre thinking what to say, it saves time.‚Äô
Alice wondered a little at this, but she was too much in awe of the Queen to disbelieve it. ‚ÄòI‚Äôll try it when I go home,‚Äô she thought to herself, ‚Äòthe next time I‚Äôm a little late for dinner.‚Äô
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs time for you to answer now,‚Äô the Queen said, looking at her watch: ‚Äòopen your mouth a little wider when you speak, and always say ‚Äúyour Majesty.‚Äù‚Äô
‚ÄòI only wanted to see what the garden was like, your Majesty‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòThat‚Äôs right,‚Äô said the Queen, patting her on the head, which Alice didn‚Äôt like at all, ‚Äòthough, when you say ‚Äúgarden,‚Äù‚ÄîI‚Äôve seen gardens, compared with which this would be a wilderness.‚Äô
Alice didn‚Äôt dare to argue the point, but went on: ‚Äò‚Äîand I thought I‚Äôd try and find my way to the top of that hill‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòWhen you say ‚Äúhill,‚Äù‚Äô the Queen interrupted, ‚ÄòI could show you hills, in comparison with which you‚Äôd call that a valley.‚Äô
‚ÄòNo, I shouldn‚Äôt,‚Äô said Alice, surprised into contradicting her at last: ‚Äòa hill can‚Äôt be a valley, you know. That would be nonsense‚Äî‚Äô
The Red Queen shook her head, ‚ÄòYou may call it ‚Äúnonsense‚Äù if you like,‚Äô she said, ‚Äòbut I‚Äôve heard nonsense, compared with which that would be as sensible as a dictionary!‚Äô
Alice curtseyed again, as she was afraid from the Queen‚Äôs tone that she was a little offended: and they walked on in silence till they got to the top of the little hill.
For some minutes Alice stood without speaking, looking out in all directions over the country‚Äîand a most curious country it was. There were a number of tiny little brooks running straight across it from side to side, and the ground between was divided up into squares by a number of little green hedges, that reached from brook to brook.
‚ÄòI declare it‚Äôs marked out just like a large chessboard!‚Äô Alice said at last. ‚ÄòThere ought to be some men moving about somewhere‚Äîand so there are!‚Äô She added in a tone of delight, and her heart began to beat quick with excitement as she went on. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs a great huge game of chess that‚Äôs being played‚Äîall over the world‚Äîif this is the world at all, you know. Oh, what fun it is! How I wish I was one of them! I wouldn‚Äôt mind being a Pawn, if only I might join‚Äîthough of course I should like to be a Queen, best.‚Äô
She glanced rather shyly at the real Queen as she said this, but her companion only smiled pleasantly, and said, ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs easily managed. You can be the White Queen‚Äôs Pawn, if you like, as Lily‚Äôs too young to play; and you‚Äôre in the Second Square to begin with: when you get to the Eighth Square you‚Äôll be a Queen‚Äî‚Äô Just at this moment, somehow or other, they began to run.
Alice never could quite make out, in thinking it over afterwards, how it was that they began: all she remembers is, that they were running hand in hand, and the Queen went so fast that it was all she could do to keep up with her: and still the Queen kept crying ‚ÄòFaster! Faster!‚Äô but Alice felt she could not go faster, though she had not breath left to say so.
The most curious part of the thing was, that the trees and the other things round them never changed their places at all: however fast they went, they never seemed to pass anything. ‚ÄòI wonder if all the things move along with us?‚Äô thought poor puzzled Alice. And the Queen seemed to guess her thoughts, for she cried, ‚ÄòFaster! Don‚Äôt try to talk!‚Äô
Not that Alice had any idea of doing that. She felt as if she would never be able to talk again, she was getting so much out of breath: and still the Queen cried ‚ÄòFaster! Faster!‚Äô and dragged her along. ‚ÄòAre we nearly there?‚Äô Alice managed to pant out at last.
‚ÄòNearly there!‚Äô the Queen repeated. ‚ÄòWhy, we passed it ten minutes ago! Faster!‚Äô And they ran on for a time in silence, with the wind whistling in Alice‚Äôs ears, and almost blowing her hair off her head, she fancied.
‚ÄòNow! Now!‚Äô cried the Queen. ‚ÄòFaster! Faster!‚Äô And they went so fast that at last they seemed to skim through the air, hardly touching the ground with their feet, till suddenly, just as Alice was getting quite exhausted, they stopped, and she found herself sitting on the ground, breathless and giddy.
The Queen propped her up against a tree, and said kindly, ‚ÄòYou may rest a little now.‚Äô
Alice looked round her in great surprise. ‚ÄòWhy, I do believe we‚Äôve been under this tree the whole time! Everything‚Äôs just as it was!‚Äô
‚ÄòOf course it is,‚Äô said the Queen, ‚Äòwhat would you have it?‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, in our country,‚Äô said Alice, still panting a little, ‚Äòyou‚Äôd generally get to somewhere else‚Äîif you ran very fast for a long time, as we‚Äôve been doing.‚Äô
‚ÄòA slow sort of country!‚Äô said the Queen. ‚ÄòNow, here, you see, it takes all the running you can do, to keep in the same place. If you want to get somewhere else, you must run at least twice as fast as that!‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôd rather not try, please!‚Äô said Alice. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm quite content to stay here‚Äîonly I am so hot and thirsty!‚Äô
‚ÄòI know what you‚Äôd like!‚Äô the Queen said good-naturedly, taking a little box out of her pocket. ‚ÄòHave a biscuit?‚Äô
Alice thought it would not be civil to say ‚ÄòNo,‚Äô though it wasn‚Äôt at all what she wanted. So she took it, and ate it as well as she could: and it was very dry; and she thought she had never been so nearly choked in all her life.
‚ÄòWhile you‚Äôre refreshing yourself,‚Äô said the Queen, ‚ÄòI‚Äôll just take the measurements.‚Äô And she took a ribbon out of her pocket, marked in inches, and began measuring the ground, and sticking little pegs in here and there.
‚ÄòAt the end of two yards,‚Äô she said, putting in a peg to mark the distance, ‚ÄòI shall give you your directions‚Äîhave another biscuit?‚Äô
‚ÄòNo, thank you,‚Äô said Alice: ‚Äòone‚Äôs quite enough!‚Äô
‚ÄòThirst quenched, I hope?‚Äô said the Queen.
Alice did not know what to say to this, but luckily the Queen did not wait for an answer, but went on. ‚ÄòAt the end of three yards I shall repeat them‚Äîfor fear of your forgetting them. At the end of four, I shall say good-bye. And at the end of five, I shall go!‚Äô
She had got all the pegs put in by this time, and Alice looked on with great interest as she returned to the tree, and then began slowly walking down the row.
At the two-yard peg she faced round, and said, ‚ÄòA pawn goes two squares in its first move, you know. So you‚Äôll go very quickly through the Third Square‚Äîby railway, I should think‚Äîand you‚Äôll find yourself in the Fourth Square in no time. Well, that square belongs to Tweedledum and Tweedledee‚Äîthe Fifth is mostly water‚Äîthe Sixth belongs to Humpty Dumpty‚ÄîBut you make no remark?‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt know I had to make one‚Äîjust then,‚Äô Alice faltered out.
‚ÄòYou should have said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs extremely kind of you to tell me all this‚Äù‚Äîhowever, we‚Äôll suppose it said‚Äîthe Seventh Square is all forest‚Äîhowever, one of the Knights will show you the way‚Äîand in the Eighth Square we shall be Queens together, and it‚Äôs all feasting and fun!‚Äô Alice got up and curtseyed, and sat down again.
At the next peg the Queen turned again, and this time she said, ‚ÄòSpeak in French when you can‚Äôt think of the English for a thing‚Äîturn out your toes as you walk‚Äîand remember who you are!‚Äô She did not wait for Alice to curtsey this time, but walked on quickly to the next peg, where she turned for a moment to say ‚Äògood-bye,‚Äô and then hurried on to the last.
How it happened, Alice never knew, but exactly as she came to the last peg, she was gone. Whether she vanished into the air, or whether she ran quickly into the wood (‚Äòand she can run very fast!‚Äô thought Alice), there was no way of guessing, but she was gone, and Alice began to remember that she was a Pawn, and that it would soon be time for her to move.

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter 3 - Looking-Glass Insects

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice moves through the Woods where things have no names and meets a fawn. Both forget their identities while in the wood. Upon exiting the wood, the fawn realizes Alice is a human and runs away in fear.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In the imaginative domain of DaSCHland, Alice, guided by RabbitIT, ventured into a section of the virtual world where the flora and fauna were inspired by the DaSCH repository's literary data on "Looking-Glass Insects." These insects, unlike any found in the natural world, exhibited peculiar behaviors and appearances, reminiscent of characters from a storybook.
As Alice wandered through this digitally rendered environment, she encountered insects that moved in reverse, communicated in cryptic codes, and displayed vibrant, unnatural colors. RabbitIT explained each insect's significance and literary background, linking their characteristics to themes and motifs from various narratives.
This chapter captures Alice's fascination and interaction with these fantastical creatures, highlighting her wonder at the surreal and educational aspects of Daschland's technological wonders. The experience enriched her understanding of the literary world, bridged brilliantly by DaSCH's innovative use of data and digital reality.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
Of course the first thing to do was to make a grand survey of the country she was going to travel through. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs something very like learning geography,‚Äô thought Alice, as she stood on tiptoe in hopes of being able to see a little further. ‚ÄòPrincipal rivers‚Äîthere are none. Principal mountains‚ÄîI‚Äôm on the only one, but I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs got any name. Principal towns‚Äîwhy, what are those creatures, making honey down there? They can‚Äôt be bees‚Äînobody ever saw bees a mile off, you know‚Äî‚Äô and for some time she stood silent, watching one of them that was bustling about among the flowers, poking its proboscis into them, ‚Äòjust as if it was a regular bee,‚Äô thought Alice.
However, this was anything but a regular bee: in fact it was an elephant‚Äîas Alice soon found out, though the idea quite took her breath away at first. ‚ÄòAnd what enormous flowers they must be!‚Äô was her next idea. ‚ÄòSomething like cottages with the roofs taken off, and stalks put to them‚Äîand what quantities of honey they must make! I think I‚Äôll go down and‚Äîno, I won‚Äôt just yet,‚Äô she went on, checking herself just as she was beginning to run down the hill, and trying to find some excuse for turning shy so suddenly. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôll never do to go down among them without a good long branch to brush them away‚Äîand what fun it‚Äôll be when they ask me how I like my walk. I shall say‚Äî‚ÄúOh, I like it well enough‚Äî‚Äú‚Äô (here came the favourite little toss of the head), ‚Äò‚Äúonly it was so dusty and hot, and the elephants did tease so!‚Äù‚Äô
‚ÄòI think I‚Äôll go down the other way,‚Äô she said after a pause: ‚Äòand perhaps I may visit the elephants later on. Besides, I do so want to get into the Third Square!‚Äô
So with this excuse she ran down the hill and jumped over the first of the six little brooks.
* * * *
* * *
* * * *
‚ÄòTickets, please!‚Äô said the Guard, putting his head in at the window. In a moment everybody was holding out a ticket: they were about the same size as the people, and quite seemed to fill the carriage.
‚ÄòNow then! Show your ticket, child!‚Äô the Guard went on, looking angrily at Alice. And a great many voices all said together (‚Äòlike the chorus of a song,‚Äô thought Alice), ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt keep him waiting, child! Why, his time is worth a thousand pounds a minute!‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôm afraid I haven‚Äôt got one,‚Äô Alice said in a frightened tone: ‚Äòthere wasn‚Äôt a ticket-office where I came from.‚Äô And again the chorus of voices went on. ‚ÄòThere wasn‚Äôt room for one where she came from. The land there is worth a thousand pounds an inch!‚Äô
‚ÄòDon‚Äôt make excuses,‚Äô said the Guard: ‚Äòyou should have bought one from the engine-driver.‚Äô And once more the chorus of voices went on with ‚ÄòThe man that drives the engine. Why, the smoke alone is worth a thousand pounds a puff!‚Äô
Alice thought to herself, ‚ÄòThen there‚Äôs no use in speaking.‚Äô The voices didn‚Äôt join in this time, as she hadn‚Äôt spoken, but to her great surprise, they all thought in chorus (I hope you understand what thinking in chorus means‚Äîfor I must confess that I don‚Äôt), ‚ÄòBetter say nothing at all. Language is worth a thousand pounds a word!‚Äô
‚ÄòI shall dream about a thousand pounds tonight, I know I shall!‚Äô thought Alice.
All this time the Guard was looking at her, first through a telescope, then through a microscope, and then through an opera-glass. At last he said, ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre travelling the wrong way,‚Äô and shut up the window and went away.
‚ÄòSo young a child,‚Äô said the gentleman sitting opposite to her (he was dressed in white paper), ‚Äòought to know which way she‚Äôs going, even if she doesn‚Äôt know her own name!‚Äô
A Goat, that was sitting next to the gentleman in white, shut his eyes and said in a loud voice, ‚ÄòShe ought to know her way to the ticket-office, even if she doesn‚Äôt know her alphabet!‚Äô
There was a Beetle sitting next to the Goat (it was a very queer carriage-full of passengers altogether), and, as the rule seemed to be that they should all speak in turn, he went on with ‚ÄòShe‚Äôll have to go back from here as luggage!‚Äô
Alice couldn‚Äôt see who was sitting beyond the Beetle, but a hoarse voice spoke next. ‚ÄòChange engines‚Äî‚Äô it said, and was obliged to leave off.
‚ÄòIt sounds like a horse,‚Äô Alice thought to herself. And an extremely small voice, close to her ear, said, ‚ÄòYou might make a joke on that‚Äîsomething about ‚Äúhorse‚Äù and ‚Äúhoarse,‚Äù you know.‚Äô
Then a very gentle voice in the distance said, ‚ÄòShe must be labelled ‚ÄúLass, with care,‚Äù you know‚Äî‚Äô
And after that other voices went on (‚ÄòWhat a number of people there are in the carriage!‚Äô thought Alice), saying, ‚ÄòShe must go by post, as she‚Äôs got a head on her‚Äî‚Äô ‚ÄòShe must be sent as a message by the telegraph‚Äî‚Äô ‚ÄòShe must draw the train herself the rest of the way‚Äî‚Äô and so on.
But the gentleman dressed in white paper leaned forwards and whispered in her ear, ‚ÄòNever mind what they all say, my dear, but take a return-ticket every time the train stops.‚Äô
‚ÄòIndeed I shan‚Äôt!‚Äô Alice said rather impatiently. ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt belong to this railway journey at all‚ÄîI was in a wood just now‚Äîand I wish I could get back there.‚Äô
‚ÄòYou might make a joke on that,‚Äô said the little voice close to her ear: ‚Äòsomething about ‚Äúyou would if you could,‚Äù you know.‚Äô
‚ÄòDon‚Äôt tease so,‚Äô said Alice, looking about in vain to see where the voice came from; ‚Äòif you‚Äôre so anxious to have a joke made, why don‚Äôt you make one yourself?‚Äô
The little voice sighed deeply: it was very unhappy, evidently, and Alice would have said something pitying to comfort it, ‚ÄòIf it would only sigh like other people!‚Äô she thought. But this was such a wonderfully small sigh, that she wouldn‚Äôt have heard it at all, if it hadn‚Äôt come quite close to her ear. The consequence of this was that it tickled her ear very much, and quite took off her thoughts from the unhappiness of the poor little creature.
‚ÄòI know you are a friend,‚Äô the little voice went on; ‚Äòa dear friend, and an old friend. And you won‚Äôt hurt me, though I am an insect.‚Äô
‚ÄòWhat kind of insect?‚Äô Alice inquired a little anxiously. What she really wanted to know was, whether it could sting or not, but she thought this wouldn‚Äôt be quite a civil question to ask.
‚ÄòWhat, then you don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äô the little voice began, when it was drowned by a shrill scream from the engine, and everybody jumped up in alarm, Alice among the rest.
The Horse, who had put his head out of the window, quietly drew it in and said, ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs only a brook we have to jump over.‚Äô Everybody seemed satisfied with this, though Alice felt a little nervous at the idea of trains jumping at all. ‚ÄòHowever, it‚Äôll take us into the Fourth Square, that‚Äôs some comfort!‚Äô she said to herself. In another moment she felt the carriage rise straight up into the air, and in her fright she caught at the thing nearest to her hand, which happened to be the Goat‚Äôs beard.
* * * *
* * *
* * * *
But the beard seemed to melt away as she touched it, and she found herself sitting quietly under a tree‚Äîwhile the Gnat (for that was the insect she had been talking to) was balancing itself on a twig just over her head, and fanning her with its wings.
It certainly was a very large Gnat: ‚Äòabout the size of a chicken,‚Äô Alice thought. Still, she couldn‚Äôt feel nervous with it, after they had been talking together so long.
‚Äò‚Äîthen you don‚Äôt like all insects?‚Äô the Gnat went on, as quietly as if nothing had happened.
‚ÄòI like them when they can talk,‚Äô Alice said. ‚ÄòNone of them ever talk, where I come from.‚Äô
‚ÄòWhat sort of insects do you rejoice in, where you come from?‚Äô the Gnat inquired.
‚ÄòI don‚Äôt rejoice in insects at all,‚Äô Alice explained, ‚Äòbecause I‚Äôm rather afraid of them‚Äîat least the large kinds. But I can tell you the names of some of them.‚Äô
‚ÄòOf course they answer to their names?‚Äô the Gnat remarked carelessly.
‚ÄòI never knew them to do it.‚Äô
‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs the use of their having names,‚Äô the Gnat said, ‚Äòif they won‚Äôt answer to them?‚Äô
‚ÄòNo use to them,‚Äô said Alice; ‚Äòbut it‚Äôs useful to the people who name them, I suppose. If not, why do things have names at all?‚Äô
‚ÄòI can‚Äôt say,‚Äô the Gnat replied. ‚ÄòFurther on, in the wood down there, they‚Äôve got no names‚Äîhowever, go on with your list of insects: you‚Äôre wasting time.‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, there‚Äôs the Horse-fly,‚Äô Alice began, counting off the names on her fingers.
‚ÄòAll right,‚Äô said the Gnat: ‚Äòhalf way up that bush, you‚Äôll see a Rocking-horse-fly, if you look. It‚Äôs made entirely of wood, and gets about by swinging itself from branch to branch.‚Äô
‚ÄòWhat does it live on?‚Äô Alice asked, with great curiosity.
‚ÄòSap and sawdust,‚Äô said the Gnat. ‚ÄòGo on with the list.‚Äô
Alice looked up at the Rocking-horse-fly with great interest, and made up her mind that it must have been just repainted, it looked so bright and sticky; and then she went on.
‚ÄòAnd there‚Äôs the Dragon-fly.‚Äô
‚ÄòLook on the branch above your head,‚Äô said the Gnat, ‚Äòand there you‚Äôll find a snap-dragon-fly. Its body is made of plum-pudding, its wings of holly-leaves, and its head is a raisin burning in brandy.‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd what does it live on?‚Äô
‚ÄòFrumenty and mince pie,‚Äô the Gnat replied; ‚Äòand it makes its nest in a Christmas box.‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd then there‚Äôs the Butterfly,‚Äô Alice went on, after she had taken a good look at the insect with its head on fire, and had thought to herself, ‚ÄòI wonder if that‚Äôs the reason insects are so fond of flying into candles‚Äîbecause they want to turn into Snap-dragon-flies!‚Äô
‚ÄòCrawling at your feet,‚Äô said the Gnat (Alice drew her feet back in some alarm), ‚Äòyou may observe a Bread-and-Butterfly. Its wings are thin slices of Bread-and-butter, its body is a crust, and its head is a lump of sugar.‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd what does it live on?‚Äô
‚ÄòWeak tea with cream in it.‚Äô
A new difficulty came into Alice‚Äôs head. ‚ÄòSupposing it couldn‚Äôt find any?‚Äô she suggested.
‚ÄòThen it would die, of course.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut that must happen very often,‚Äô Alice remarked thoughtfully.
‚ÄòIt always happens,‚Äô said the Gnat.
After this, Alice was silent for a minute or two, pondering. The Gnat amused itself meanwhile by humming round and round her head: at last it settled again and remarked, ‚ÄòI suppose you don‚Äôt want to lose your name?‚Äô
‚ÄòNo, indeed,‚Äô Alice said, a little anxiously.
‚ÄòAnd yet I don‚Äôt know,‚Äô the Gnat went on in a careless tone: ‚Äòonly think how convenient it would be if you could manage to go home without it! For instance, if the governess wanted to call you to your lessons, she would call out ‚Äúcome here‚Äî,‚Äù and there she would have to leave off, because there wouldn‚Äôt be any name for her to call, and of course you wouldn‚Äôt have to go, you know.‚Äô
‚ÄòThat would never do, I‚Äôm sure,‚Äô said Alice: ‚Äòthe governess would never think of excusing me lessons for that. If she couldn‚Äôt remember my name, she‚Äôd call me ‚ÄúMiss!‚Äù as the servants do.‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, if she said ‚ÄúMiss,‚Äù and didn‚Äôt say anything more,‚Äô the Gnat remarked, ‚Äòof course you‚Äôd miss your lessons. That‚Äôs a joke. I wish you had made it.‚Äô
‚ÄòWhy do you wish I had made it?‚Äô Alice asked. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs a very bad one.‚Äô
But the Gnat only sighed deeply, while two large tears came rolling down its cheeks.
‚ÄòYou shouldn‚Äôt make jokes,‚Äô Alice said, ‚Äòif it makes you so unhappy.‚Äô
Then came another of those melancholy little sighs, and this time the poor Gnat really seemed to have sighed itself away, for, when Alice looked up, there was nothing whatever to be seen on the twig, and, as she was getting quite chilly with sitting still so long, she got up and walked on.
She very soon came to an open field, with a wood on the other side of it: it looked much darker than the last wood, and Alice felt a little timid about going into it. However, on second thoughts, she made up her mind to go on: ‚Äòfor I certainly won‚Äôt go back,‚Äô she thought to herself, and this was the only way to the Eighth Square.
‚ÄòThis must be the wood,‚Äô she said thoughtfully to herself, ‚Äòwhere things have no names. I wonder what‚Äôll become of my name when I go in? I shouldn‚Äôt like to lose it at all‚Äîbecause they‚Äôd have to give me another, and it would be almost certain to be an ugly one. But then the fun would be trying to find the creature that had got my old name! That‚Äôs just like the advertisements, you know, when people lose dogs‚Äî‚Äúanswers to the name of ‚ÄòDash:‚Äô had on a brass collar‚Äù‚Äîjust fancy calling everything you met ‚ÄúAlice,‚Äù till one of them answered! Only they wouldn‚Äôt answer at all, if they were wise.‚Äô
She was rambling on in this way when she reached the wood: it looked very cool and shady. ‚ÄòWell, at any rate it‚Äôs a great comfort,‚Äô she said as she stepped under the trees, ‚Äòafter being so hot, to get into the‚Äîinto what?‚Äô she went on, rather surprised at not being able to think of the word. ‚ÄòI mean to get under the‚Äîunder the‚Äîunder this, you know!‚Äô putting her hand on the trunk of the tree. ‚ÄòWhat does it call itself, I wonder? I do believe it‚Äôs got no name‚Äîwhy, to be sure it hasn‚Äôt!‚Äô
She stood silent for a minute, thinking: then she suddenly began again. ‚ÄòThen it really has happened, after all! And now, who am I? I will remember, if I can! I‚Äôm determined to do it!‚Äô But being determined didn‚Äôt help much, and all she could say, after a great deal of puzzling, was, ‚ÄòL, I know it begins with L!‚Äô
Just then a Fawn came wandering by: it looked at Alice with its large gentle eyes, but didn‚Äôt seem at all frightened. ‚ÄòHere then! Here then!‚Äô Alice said, as she held out her hand and tried to stroke it; but it only started back a little, and then stood looking at her again.
‚ÄòWhat do you call yourself?‚Äô the Fawn said at last. Such a soft sweet voice it had!
‚ÄòI wish I knew!‚Äô thought poor Alice. She answered, rather sadly, ‚ÄòNothing, just now.‚Äô
‚ÄòThink again,‚Äô it said: ‚Äòthat won‚Äôt do.‚Äô
Alice thought, but nothing came of it. ‚ÄòPlease, would you tell me what you call yourself?‚Äô she said timidly. ‚ÄòI think that might help a little.‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôll tell you, if you‚Äôll move a little further on,‚Äô the Fawn said. ‚ÄòI can‚Äôt remember here.‚Äô
So they walked on together though the wood, Alice with her arms clasped lovingly round the soft neck of the Fawn, till they came out into another open field, and here the Fawn gave a sudden bound into the air, and shook itself free from Alice‚Äôs arms. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm a Fawn!‚Äô it cried out in a voice of delight, ‚Äòand, dear me! you‚Äôre a human child!‚Äô A sudden look of alarm came into its beautiful brown eyes, and in another moment it had darted away at full speed.
Alice stood looking after it, almost ready to cry with vexation at having lost her dear little fellow-traveller so suddenly. ‚ÄòHowever, I know my name now.‚Äô she said, ‚Äòthat‚Äôs some comfort. Alice‚ÄîAlice‚ÄîI won‚Äôt forget it again. And now, which of these finger-posts ought I to follow, I wonder?‚Äô
It was not a very difficult question to answer, as there was only one road through the wood, and the two finger-posts both pointed along it. ‚ÄòI‚Äôll settle it,‚Äô Alice said to herself, ‚Äòwhen the road divides and they point different ways.‚Äô
But this did not seem likely to happen. She went on and on, a long way, but wherever the road divided there were sure to be two finger-posts pointing the same way, one marked ‚ÄòTO TWEEDLEDUM‚ÄôS HOUSE‚Äô and the other ‚ÄòTO THE HOUSE OF TWEEDLEDEE.‚Äô
‚ÄòI do believe,‚Äô said Alice at last, ‚Äòthat they live in the same house! I wonder I never thought of that before‚ÄîBut I can‚Äôt stay there long. I‚Äôll just call and say ‚Äúhow d‚Äôyou do?‚Äù and ask them the way out of the wood. If I could only get to the Eighth Square before it gets dark!‚Äô So she wandered on, talking to herself as she went, till, on turning a sharp corner, she came upon two fat little men, so suddenly that she could not help starting back, but in another moment she recovered herself, feeling sure that they must be

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter 4 - Tweedledum and Tweedledee

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice meets the twin brothers Tweedledum and Tweedledee, who engage in a series of absurd arguments and recite the poem "The Walrus and the Carpenter." They are about to fight but are interrupted by a giant crow.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, Alice, accompanied by RabbitIT, stumbled upon the twins, digital recreations powered by the DaSCH repository. In a whimsical setting, the twins recited the poem "The Walrus and the Carpenter," their voices animated with the theatrical flair stored in the database.
After the recitation, the twins engaged in a mock battle, a playful demonstration of their dispute from the poem. They wielded digital swords that clinked and clanged, generating harmless sparks in the virtual air, much to Alice's amusement.
This chapter showcases the blend of literature and interactive play in DaSCHland, with Alice delighting in both the lyrical recital and the spirited mock battle, further deepening her adventure in the world where data and whimsy intertwine.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
They were standing under a tree, each with an arm round the other‚Äôs neck, and Alice knew which was which in a moment, because one of them had ‚ÄòDUM‚Äô embroidered on his collar, and the other ‚ÄòDEE.‚Äô ‚ÄòI suppose they‚Äôve each got ‚ÄúTWEEDLE‚Äù round at the back of the collar,‚Äô she said to herself.
They stood so still that she quite forgot they were alive, and she was just looking round to see if the word ‚ÄúTWEEDLE‚Äù was written at the back of each collar, when she was startled by a voice coming from the one marked ‚ÄòDUM.‚Äô
‚ÄòIf you think we‚Äôre wax-works,‚Äô he said, ‚Äòyou ought to pay, you know. Wax-works weren‚Äôt made to be looked at for nothing, nohow!‚Äô
‚ÄòContrariwise,‚Äô added the one marked ‚ÄòDEE,‚Äô ‚Äòif you think we‚Äôre alive, you ought to speak.‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm very sorry,‚Äô was all Alice could say; for the words of the old song kept ringing through her head like the ticking of a clock, and she could hardly help saying them out loud:‚Äî ‚ÄòTweedledum and Tweedledee Agreed to have a battle; For Tweedledum said Tweedledee Had spoiled his nice new rattle. Just then flew down a monstrous crow, As black as a tar-barrel; Which frightened both the heroes so, They quite forgot their quarrel.‚Äô
‚ÄòI know what you‚Äôre thinking about,‚Äô said Tweedledum: ‚Äòbut it isn‚Äôt so, nohow.‚Äô
‚ÄòContrariwise,‚Äô continued Tweedledee, ‚Äòif it was so, it might be; and if it were so, it would be; but as it isn‚Äôt, it ain‚Äôt. That‚Äôs logic.‚Äô
‚ÄòI was thinking,‚Äô Alice said very politely, ‚Äòwhich is the best way out of this wood: it‚Äôs getting so dark. Would you tell me, please?‚Äô
But the little men only looked at each other and grinned.
They looked so exactly like a couple of great schoolboys, that Alice couldn‚Äôt help pointing her finger at Tweedledum, and saying ‚ÄòFirst Boy!‚Äô
‚ÄòNohow!‚Äô Tweedledum cried out briskly, and shut his mouth up again with a snap.
‚ÄòNext Boy!‚Äô said Alice, passing on to Tweedledee, though she felt quite certain he would only shout out ‚ÄòContrariwise!‚Äô and so he did.
‚ÄòYou‚Äôve been wrong!‚Äô cried Tweedledum. ‚ÄòThe first thing in a visit is to say ‚ÄúHow d‚Äôye do?‚Äù and shake hands!‚Äô And here the two brothers gave each other a hug, and then they held out the two hands that were free, to shake hands with her.
Alice did not like shaking hands with either of them first, for fear of hurting the other one‚Äôs feelings; so, as the best way out of the difficulty, she took hold of both hands at once: the next moment they were dancing round in a ring. This seemed quite natural (she remembered afterwards), and she was not even surprised to hear music playing: it seemed to come from the tree under which they were dancing, and it was done (as well as she could make it out) by the branches rubbing one across the other, like fiddles and fiddle-sticks.
‚ÄòBut it certainly was funny,‚Äô (Alice said afterwards, when she was telling her sister the history of all this,) ‚Äòto find myself singing ‚ÄúHere we go round the mulberry bush.‚Äù I don‚Äôt know when I began it, but somehow I felt as if I‚Äôd been singing it a long long time!‚Äô
The other two dancers were fat, and very soon out of breath. ‚ÄòFour times round is enough for one dance,‚Äô Tweedledum panted out, and they left off dancing as suddenly as they had begun: the music stopped at the same moment.
Then they let go of Alice‚Äôs hands, and stood looking at her for a minute: there was a rather awkward pause, as Alice didn‚Äôt know how to begin a conversation with people she had just been dancing with. ‚ÄòIt would never do to say ‚ÄúHow d‚Äôye do?‚Äù now,‚Äô she said to herself: ‚Äòwe seem to have got beyond that, somehow!‚Äô
‚ÄòI hope you‚Äôre not much tired?‚Äô she said at last.
‚ÄòNohow. And thank you very much for asking,‚Äô said Tweedledum.
‚ÄòSo much obliged!‚Äô added Tweedledee. ‚ÄòYou like poetry?‚Äô
‚ÄòYe-es, pretty well‚Äîsome poetry,‚Äô Alice said doubtfully. ‚ÄòWould you tell me which road leads out of the wood?‚Äô
‚ÄòWhat shall I repeat to her?‚Äô said Tweedledee, looking round at Tweedledum with great solemn eyes, and not noticing Alice‚Äôs question.
‚Äò‚ÄúThe Walrus and the Carpenter‚Äù is the longest,‚Äô Tweedledum replied, giving his brother an affectionate hug.
Tweedledee began instantly:
‚ÄòThe sun was shining‚Äî‚Äô
Here Alice ventured to interrupt him. ‚ÄòIf it‚Äôs very long,‚Äô she said, as politely as she could, ‚Äòwould you please tell me first which road‚Äî‚Äô
Tweedledee smiled gently, and began again:
‚ÄòThe sun was shining on the sea, Shining with all his might: He did his very best to make The billows smooth and bright‚Äî And this was odd, because it was The middle of the night.
The moon was shining sulkily, Because she thought the sun Had got no business to be there After the day was done‚Äî ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very rude of him,‚Äù she said, ‚ÄúTo come and spoil the fun!‚Äù
The sea was wet as wet could be, The sands were dry as dry. You could not see a cloud, because No cloud was in the sky: No birds were flying over head‚Äî There were no birds to fly.
The Walrus and the Carpenter Were walking close at hand; They wept like anything to see Such quantities of sand: ‚ÄúIf this were only cleared away,‚Äù They said, ‚Äúit would be grand!‚Äù
‚ÄúIf seven maids with seven mops Swept it for half a year, Do you suppose,‚Äù the Walrus said, ‚ÄúThat they could get it clear?‚Äù ‚ÄúI doubt it,‚Äù said the Carpenter, And shed a bitter tear.
‚ÄúO Oysters, come and walk with us!‚Äù The Walrus did beseech. ‚ÄúA pleasant walk, a pleasant talk, Along the briny beach: We cannot do with more than four, To give a hand to each.‚Äù
The eldest Oyster looked at him. But never a word he said: The eldest Oyster winked his eye, And shook his heavy head‚Äî Meaning to say he did not choose To leave the oyster-bed.
But four young oysters hurried up, All eager for the treat: Their coats were brushed, their faces washed, Their shoes were clean and neat‚Äî And this was odd, because, you know, They hadn‚Äôt any feet.
Four other Oysters followed them, And yet another four; And thick and fast they came at last, And more, and more, and more‚Äî All hopping through the frothy waves, And scrambling to the shore.
The Walrus and the Carpenter Walked on a mile or so, And then they rested on a rock Conveniently low: And all the little Oysters stood And waited in a row.
‚ÄúThe time has come,‚Äù the Walrus said, ‚ÄúTo talk of many things: Of shoes‚Äîand ships‚Äîand sealing-wax‚Äî Of cabbages‚Äîand kings‚Äî And why the sea is boiling hot‚Äî And whether pigs have wings.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut wait a bit,‚Äù the Oysters cried, ‚ÄúBefore we have our chat; For some of us are out of breath, And all of us are fat!‚Äù ‚ÄúNo hurry!‚Äù said the Carpenter. They thanked him much for that.
‚ÄúA loaf of bread,‚Äù the Walrus said, ‚ÄúIs what we chiefly need: Pepper and vinegar besides Are very good indeed‚Äî Now if you‚Äôre ready Oysters dear, We can begin to feed.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut not on us!‚Äù the Oysters cried, Turning a little blue, ‚ÄúAfter such kindness, that would be A dismal thing to do!‚Äù ‚ÄúThe night is fine,‚Äù the Walrus said ‚ÄúDo you admire the view?
‚ÄúIt was so kind of you to come! And you are very nice!‚Äù The Carpenter said nothing but ‚ÄúCut us another slice: I wish you were not quite so deaf‚Äî I‚Äôve had to ask you twice!‚Äù
‚ÄúIt seems a shame,‚Äù the Walrus said, ‚ÄúTo play them such a trick, After we‚Äôve brought them out so far, And made them trot so quick!‚Äù The Carpenter said nothing but ‚ÄúThe butter‚Äôs spread too thick!‚Äù
‚ÄúI weep for you,‚Äù the Walrus said. ‚ÄúI deeply sympathize.‚Äù With sobs and tears he sorted out Those of the largest size. Holding his pocket handkerchief Before his streaming eyes.
‚ÄúO Oysters,‚Äù said the Carpenter. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve had a pleasant run! Shall we be trotting home again?‚Äù But answer came there none‚Äî And that was scarcely odd, because They‚Äôd eaten every one.‚Äô
‚ÄòI like the Walrus best,‚Äô said Alice: ‚Äòbecause you see he was a little sorry for the poor oysters.‚Äô
‚ÄòHe ate more than the Carpenter, though,‚Äô said Tweedledee. ‚ÄòYou see he held his handkerchief in front, so that the Carpenter couldn‚Äôt count how many he took: contrariwise.‚Äô
‚ÄòThat was mean!‚Äô Alice said indignantly. ‚ÄòThen I like the Carpenter best‚Äîif he didn‚Äôt eat so many as the Walrus.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut he ate as many as he could get,‚Äô said Tweedledum.
This was a puzzler. After a pause, Alice began, ‚ÄòWell! They were both very unpleasant characters‚Äî‚Äô Here she checked herself in some alarm, at hearing something that sounded to her like the puffing of a large steam-engine in the wood near them, though she feared it was more likely to be a wild beast. ‚ÄòAre there any lions or tigers about here?‚Äô she asked timidly.
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs only the Red King snoring,‚Äô said Tweedledee.
‚ÄòCome and look at him!‚Äô the brothers cried, and they each took one of Alice‚Äôs hands, and led her up to where the King was sleeping.
‚ÄòIsn‚Äôt he a lovely sight?‚Äô said Tweedledum.
Alice couldn‚Äôt say honestly that he was. He had a tall red night-cap on, with a tassel, and he was lying crumpled up into a sort of untidy heap, and snoring loud‚Äî‚Äòfit to snore his head off!‚Äô as Tweedledum remarked.
‚ÄòI‚Äôm afraid he‚Äôll catch cold with lying on the damp grass,‚Äô said Alice, who was a very thoughtful little girl.
‚ÄòHe‚Äôs dreaming now,‚Äô said Tweedledee: ‚Äòand what do you think he‚Äôs dreaming about?‚Äô
Alice said ‚ÄòNobody can guess that.‚Äô
‚ÄòWhy, about you!‚Äô Tweedledee exclaimed, clapping his hands triumphantly. ‚ÄòAnd if he left off dreaming about you, where do you suppose you‚Äôd be?‚Äô
‚ÄòWhere I am now, of course,‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòNot you!‚Äô Tweedledee retorted contemptuously. ‚ÄòYou‚Äôd be nowhere. Why, you‚Äôre only a sort of thing in his dream!‚Äô
‚ÄòIf that there King was to wake,‚Äô added Tweedledum, ‚Äòyou‚Äôd go out‚Äîbang!‚Äîjust like a candle!‚Äô
‚ÄòI shouldn‚Äôt!‚Äô Alice exclaimed indignantly. ‚ÄòBesides, if I‚Äôm only a sort of thing in his dream, what are you, I should like to know?‚Äô
‚ÄòDitto‚Äô said Tweedledum.
‚ÄòDitto, ditto‚Äô cried Tweedledee.
He shouted this so loud that Alice couldn‚Äôt help saying, ‚ÄòHush! You‚Äôll be waking him, I‚Äôm afraid, if you make so much noise.‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, it no use your talking about waking him,‚Äô said Tweedledum, ‚Äòwhen you‚Äôre only one of the things in his dream. You know very well you‚Äôre not real.‚Äô
‚ÄòI am real!‚Äô said Alice and began to cry.
‚ÄòYou won‚Äôt make yourself a bit realler by crying,‚Äô Tweedledee remarked: ‚Äòthere‚Äôs nothing to cry about.‚Äô
‚ÄòIf I wasn‚Äôt real,‚Äô Alice said‚Äîhalf-laughing through her tears, it all seemed so ridiculous‚Äî‚ÄòI shouldn‚Äôt be able to cry.‚Äô
‚ÄòI hope you don‚Äôt suppose those are real tears?‚Äô Tweedledum interrupted in a tone of great contempt.
‚ÄòI know they‚Äôre talking nonsense,‚Äô Alice thought to herself: ‚Äòand it‚Äôs foolish to cry about it.‚Äô So she brushed away her tears, and went on as cheerfully as she could. ‚ÄòAt any rate I‚Äôd better be getting out of the wood, for really it‚Äôs coming on very dark. Do you think it‚Äôs going to rain?‚Äô
