Tweedledum spread a large umbrella over himself and his brother, and looked up into it. ‚ÄòNo, I don‚Äôt think it is,‚Äô he said: ‚Äòat least‚Äînot under here. Nohow.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut it may rain outside?‚Äô
‚ÄòIt may‚Äîif it chooses,‚Äô said Tweedledee: ‚Äòwe‚Äôve no objection. Contrariwise.‚Äô
‚ÄòSelfish things!‚Äô thought Alice, and she was just going to say ‚ÄòGood-night‚Äô and leave them, when Tweedledum sprang out from under the umbrella and seized her by the wrist.
‚ÄòDo you see that?‚Äô he said, in a voice choking with passion, and his eyes grew large and yellow all in a moment, as he pointed with a trembling finger at a small white thing lying under the tree.
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs only a rattle,‚Äô Alice said, after a careful examination of the little white thing. ‚ÄòNot a rattle-snake, you know,‚Äô she added hastily, thinking that he was frightened: ‚Äòonly an old rattle‚Äîquite old and broken.‚Äô
‚ÄòI knew it was!‚Äô cried Tweedledum, beginning to stamp about wildly and tear his hair. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs spoilt, of course!‚Äô Here he looked at Tweedledee, who immediately sat down on the ground, and tried to hide himself under the umbrella.
Alice laid her hand upon his arm, and said in a soothing tone, ‚ÄòYou needn‚Äôt be so angry about an old rattle.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut it isn‚Äôt old!‚Äô Tweedledum cried, in a greater fury than ever. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs new, I tell you‚ÄîI bought it yesterday‚Äîmy nice new RATTLE!‚Äô and his voice rose to a perfect scream.
All this time Tweedledee was trying his best to fold up the umbrella, with himself in it: which was such an extraordinary thing to do, that it quite took off Alice‚Äôs attention from the angry brother. But he couldn‚Äôt quite succeed, and it ended in his rolling over, bundled up in the umbrella, with only his head out: and there he lay, opening and shutting his mouth and his large eyes‚Äî‚Äòlooking more like a fish than anything else,‚Äô Alice thought.
‚ÄòOf course you agree to have a battle?‚Äô Tweedledum said in a calmer tone.
‚ÄòI suppose so,‚Äô the other sulkily replied, as he crawled out of the umbrella: ‚Äòonly she must help us to dress up, you know.‚Äô
So the two brothers went off hand-in-hand into the wood, and returned in a minute with their arms full of things‚Äîsuch as bolsters, blankets, hearth-rugs, table-cloths, dish-covers and coal-scuttles. ‚ÄòI hope you‚Äôre a good hand at pinning and tying strings?‚Äô Tweedledum remarked. ‚ÄòEvery one of these things has got to go on, somehow or other.‚Äô
Alice said afterwards she had never seen such a fuss made about anything in all her life‚Äîthe way those two bustled about‚Äîand the quantity of things they put on‚Äîand the trouble they gave her in tying strings and fastening buttons‚Äî‚ÄòReally they‚Äôll be more like bundles of old clothes than anything else, by the time they‚Äôre ready!‚Äô she said to herself, as she arranged a bolster round the neck of Tweedledee, ‚Äòto keep his head from being cut off,‚Äô as he said.
‚ÄòYou know,‚Äô he added very gravely, ‚Äòit‚Äôs one of the most serious things that can possibly happen to one in a battle‚Äîto get one‚Äôs head cut off.‚Äô
Alice laughed aloud: but she managed to turn it into a cough, for fear of hurting his feelings.
‚ÄòDo I look very pale?‚Äô said Tweedledum, coming up to have his helmet tied on. (He called it a helmet, though it certainly looked much more like a saucepan.)
‚ÄòWell‚Äîyes‚Äîa little,‚Äô Alice replied gently.
‚ÄòI‚Äôm very brave generally,‚Äô he went on in a low voice: ‚Äòonly to-day I happen to have a headache.‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd I‚Äôve got a toothache!‚Äô said Tweedledee, who had overheard the remark. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm far worse off than you!‚Äô
‚ÄòThen you‚Äôd better not fight to-day,‚Äô said Alice, thinking it a good opportunity to make peace.
‚ÄòWe must have a bit of a fight, but I don‚Äôt care about going on long,‚Äô said Tweedledum. ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs the time now?‚Äô
Tweedledee looked at his watch, and said ‚ÄòHalf-past four.‚Äô
‚ÄòLet‚Äôs fight till six, and then have dinner,‚Äô said Tweedledum.
‚ÄòVery well,‚Äô the other said, rather sadly: ‚Äòand she can watch us‚Äîonly you‚Äôd better not come very close,‚Äô he added: ‚ÄòI generally hit everything I can see‚Äîwhen I get really excited.‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd I hit everything within reach,‚Äô cried Tweedledum, ‚Äòwhether I can see it or not!‚Äô
Alice laughed. ‚ÄòYou must hit the trees pretty often, I should think,‚Äô she said.
Tweedledum looked round him with a satisfied smile. ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt suppose,‚Äô he said, ‚Äòthere‚Äôll be a tree left standing, for ever so far round, by the time we‚Äôve finished!‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd all about a rattle!‚Äô said Alice, still hoping to make them a little ashamed of fighting for such a trifle.
‚ÄòI shouldn‚Äôt have minded it so much,‚Äô said Tweedledum, ‚Äòif it hadn‚Äôt been a new one.‚Äô
‚ÄòI wish the monstrous crow would come!‚Äô thought Alice.
‚ÄòThere‚Äôs only one sword, you know,‚Äô Tweedledum said to his brother: ‚Äòbut you can have the umbrella‚Äîit‚Äôs quite as sharp. Only we must begin quick. It‚Äôs getting as dark as it can.‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd darker,‚Äô said Tweedledee.
It was getting dark so suddenly that Alice thought there must be a thunderstorm coming on. ‚ÄòWhat a thick black cloud that is!‚Äô she said. ‚ÄòAnd how fast it comes! Why, I do believe it‚Äôs got wings!‚Äô
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs the crow!‚Äô Tweedledum cried out in a shrill voice of alarm: and the two brothers took to their heels and were out of sight in a moment.
Alice ran a little way into the wood, and stopped under a large tree. ‚ÄòIt can never get at me here,‚Äô she thought: ‚Äòit‚Äôs far too large to squeeze itself in among the trees. But I wish it wouldn‚Äôt flap its wings so‚Äîit makes quite a hurricane in the wood‚Äîhere‚Äôs somebody‚Äôs shawl being blown away!‚Äô

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter 5 - Wool and Water

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice encounters the White Queen, who lives backwards in time. She then finds herself in a boat with the Sheep, who runs a shop. Alice experiences a series of rapid and confusing changes in setting, from a shop to a river and back.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In the heart of DaSCHland, Alice, guided by RabbitIT, met the White Queen, a character brought to life by the DaSCH repository's detailed programming. In a serene, mirrored glade, the Queen explained the peculiar, backward logic that governed Looking-Glass Land.
As they walked through this inverted world, the White Queen demonstrated how time appeared to flow in reverse, how cause preceded effect, and how logic was delightfully upturned. RabbitIT enhanced Alice's experience by offering additional insights and annotations from literary studies stored in DaSCH, making the conversation not just enlightening but deeply immersive.
This chapter captured Alice's growing understanding of the reverse nature of Looking-Glass Land, framed by the White Queen's whimsical explanations and RabbitIT's knowledgeable interjections, illustrating the fascinating intersection of literature and digital innovation in DaSCHland.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
She caught the shawl as she spoke, and looked about for the owner: in another moment the White Queen came running wildly through the wood, with both arms stretched out wide, as if she were flying, and Alice very civilly went to meet her with the shawl.
‚ÄòI‚Äôm very glad I happened to be in the way,‚Äô Alice said, as she helped her to put on her shawl again.
The White Queen only looked at her in a helpless frightened sort of way, and kept repeating something in a whisper to herself that sounded like ‚Äòbread-and-butter, bread-and-butter,‚Äô and Alice felt that if there was to be any conversation at all, she must manage it herself. So she began rather timidly: ‚ÄòAm I addressing the White Queen?‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, yes, if you call that a-dressing,‚Äô The Queen said. ‚ÄòIt isn‚Äôt my notion of the thing, at all.‚Äô
Alice thought it would never do to have an argument at the very beginning of their conversation, so she smiled and said, ‚ÄòIf your Majesty will only tell me the right way to begin, I‚Äôll do it as well as I can.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut I don‚Äôt want it done at all!‚Äô groaned the poor Queen. ‚ÄòI‚Äôve been a-dressing myself for the last two hours.‚Äô
It would have been all the better, as it seemed to Alice, if she had got some one else to dress her, she was so dreadfully untidy. ‚ÄòEvery single thing‚Äôs crooked,‚Äô Alice thought to herself, ‚Äòand she‚Äôs all over pins!‚Äîmay I put your shawl straight for you?‚Äô she added aloud.
‚ÄòI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs the matter with it!‚Äô the Queen said, in a melancholy voice. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs out of temper, I think. I‚Äôve pinned it here, and I‚Äôve pinned it there, but there‚Äôs no pleasing it!‚Äô
‚ÄòIt can‚Äôt go straight, you know, if you pin it all on one side,‚Äô Alice said, as she gently put it right for her; ‚Äòand, dear me, what a state your hair is in!‚Äô
‚ÄòThe brush has got entangled in it!‚Äô the Queen said with a sigh. ‚ÄòAnd I lost the comb yesterday.‚Äô
Alice carefully released the brush, and did her best to get the hair into order. ‚ÄòCome, you look rather better now!‚Äô she said, after altering most of the pins. ‚ÄòBut really you should have a lady‚Äôs maid!‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll take you with pleasure!‚Äô the Queen said. ‚ÄòTwopence a week, and jam every other day.‚Äô
Alice couldn‚Äôt help laughing, as she said, ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt want you to hire me‚Äîand I don‚Äôt care for jam.‚Äô
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs very good jam,‚Äô said the Queen.
‚ÄòWell, I don‚Äôt want any to-day, at any rate.‚Äô
‚ÄòYou couldn‚Äôt have it if you did want it,‚Äô the Queen said. ‚ÄòThe rule is, jam to-morrow and jam yesterday‚Äîbut never jam to-day.‚Äô
‚ÄòIt must come sometimes to ‚Äújam to-day,‚Äù‚Äô Alice objected.
‚ÄòNo, it can‚Äôt,‚Äô said the Queen. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs jam every other day: to-day isn‚Äôt any other day, you know.‚Äô
‚ÄòI don‚Äôt understand you,‚Äô said Alice. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs dreadfully confusing!‚Äô
‚ÄòThat‚Äôs the effect of living backwards,‚Äô the Queen said kindly: ‚Äòit always makes one a little giddy at first‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòLiving backwards!‚Äô Alice repeated in great astonishment. ‚ÄòI never heard of such a thing!‚Äô
‚Äò‚Äîbut there‚Äôs one great advantage in it, that one‚Äôs memory works both ways.‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôm sure mine only works one way,‚Äô Alice remarked. ‚ÄòI can‚Äôt remember things before they happen.‚Äô
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs a poor sort of memory that only works backwards,‚Äô the Queen remarked.
‚ÄòWhat sort of things do you remember best?‚Äô Alice ventured to ask.
‚ÄòOh, things that happened the week after next,‚Äô the Queen replied in a careless tone. ‚ÄòFor instance, now,‚Äô she went on, sticking a large piece of plaster on her finger as she spoke, ‚Äòthere‚Äôs the King‚Äôs Messenger. He‚Äôs in prison now, being punished: and the trial doesn‚Äôt even begin till next Wednesday: and of course the crime comes last of all.‚Äô
‚ÄòSuppose he never commits the crime?‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòThat would be all the better, wouldn‚Äôt it?‚Äô the Queen said, as she bound the plaster round her finger with a bit of ribbon.
Alice felt there was no denying that. ‚ÄòOf course it would be all the better,‚Äô she said: ‚Äòbut it wouldn‚Äôt be all the better his being punished.‚Äô
‚ÄòYou‚Äôre wrong there, at any rate,‚Äô said the Queen: ‚Äòwere you ever punished?‚Äô
‚ÄòOnly for faults,‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòAnd you were all the better for it, I know!‚Äô the Queen said triumphantly.
‚ÄòYes, but then I had done the things I was punished for,‚Äô said Alice: ‚Äòthat makes all the difference.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut if you hadn‚Äôt done them,‚Äô the Queen said, ‚Äòthat would have been better still; better, and better, and better!‚Äô Her voice went higher with each ‚Äòbetter,‚Äô till it got quite to a squeak at last.
Alice was just beginning to say ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs a mistake somewhere‚Äî,‚Äô when the Queen began screaming so loud that she had to leave the sentence unfinished. ‚ÄòOh, oh, oh!‚Äô shouted the Queen, shaking her hand about as if she wanted to shake it off. ‚ÄòMy finger‚Äôs bleeding! Oh, oh, oh, oh!‚Äô
Her screams were so exactly like the whistle of a steam-engine, that Alice had to hold both her hands over her ears.
‚ÄòWhat is the matter?‚Äô she said, as soon as there was a chance of making herself heard. ‚ÄòHave you pricked your finger?‚Äô
‚ÄòI haven‚Äôt pricked it yet,‚Äô the Queen said, ‚Äòbut I soon shall‚Äîoh, oh, oh!‚Äô
‚ÄòWhen do you expect to do it?‚Äô Alice asked, feeling very much inclined to laugh.
‚ÄòWhen I fasten my shawl again,‚Äô the poor Queen groaned out: ‚Äòthe brooch will come undone directly. Oh, oh!‚Äô As she said the words the brooch flew open, and the Queen clutched wildly at it, and tried to clasp it again.
‚ÄòTake care!‚Äô cried Alice. ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre holding it all crooked!‚Äô And she caught at the brooch; but it was too late: the pin had slipped, and the Queen had pricked her finger.
‚ÄòThat accounts for the bleeding, you see,‚Äô she said to Alice with a smile. ‚ÄòNow you understand the way things happen here.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut why don‚Äôt you scream now?‚Äô Alice asked, holding her hands ready to put over her ears again.
‚ÄòWhy, I‚Äôve done all the screaming already,‚Äô said the Queen. ‚ÄòWhat would be the good of having it all over again?‚Äô
By this time it was getting light. ‚ÄòThe crow must have flown away, I think,‚Äô said Alice: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm so glad it‚Äôs gone. I thought it was the night coming on.‚Äô
‚ÄòI wish I could manage to be glad!‚Äô the Queen said. ‚ÄòOnly I never can remember the rule. You must be very happy, living in this wood, and being glad whenever you like!‚Äô
‚ÄòOnly it is so very lonely here!‚Äô Alice said in a melancholy voice; and at the thought of her loneliness two large tears came rolling down her cheeks.
‚ÄòOh, don‚Äôt go on like that!‚Äô cried the poor Queen, wringing her hands in despair. ‚ÄòConsider what a great girl you are. Consider what a long way you‚Äôve come to-day. Consider what o‚Äôclock it is. Consider anything, only don‚Äôt cry!‚Äô
Alice could not help laughing at this, even in the midst of her tears. ‚ÄòCan you keep from crying by considering things?‚Äô she asked.
‚ÄòThat‚Äôs the way it‚Äôs done,‚Äô the Queen said with great decision: ‚Äònobody can do two things at once, you know. Let‚Äôs consider your age to begin with‚Äîhow old are you?‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôm seven and a half exactly.‚Äô
‚ÄòYou needn‚Äôt say ‚Äúexactually,‚Äù‚Äô the Queen remarked: ‚ÄòI can believe it without that. Now I‚Äôll give you something to believe. I‚Äôm just one hundred and one, five months and a day.‚Äô
‚ÄòI can‚Äôt believe that!‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòCan‚Äôt you?‚Äô the Queen said in a pitying tone. ‚ÄòTry again: draw a long breath, and shut your eyes.‚Äô
Alice laughed. ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs no use trying,‚Äô she said: ‚Äòone can‚Äôt believe impossible things.‚Äô
‚ÄòI daresay you haven‚Äôt had much practice,‚Äô said the Queen. ‚ÄòWhen I was your age, I always did it for half-an-hour a day. Why, sometimes I‚Äôve believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast. There goes the shawl again!‚Äô
The brooch had come undone as she spoke, and a sudden gust of wind blew the Queen‚Äôs shawl across a little brook. The Queen spread out her arms again, and went flying after it, and this time she succeeded in catching it for herself. ‚ÄòI‚Äôve got it!‚Äô she cried in a triumphant tone. ‚ÄòNow you shall see me pin it on again, all by myself!‚Äô
‚ÄòThen I hope your finger is better now?‚Äô Alice said very politely, as she crossed the little brook after the Queen.
* * * *
* * *
* * * *
‚ÄòOh, much better!‚Äô cried the Queen, her voice rising to a squeak as she went on. ‚ÄòMuch be-etter! Be-etter! Be-e-e-etter! Be-e-ehh!‚Äô The last word ended in a long bleat, so like a sheep that Alice quite started.
She looked at the Queen, who seemed to have suddenly wrapped herself up in wool. Alice rubbed her eyes, and looked again. She couldn‚Äôt make out what had happened at all. Was she in a shop? And was that really‚Äîwas it really a sheep that was sitting on the other side of the counter? Rub as she could, she could make nothing more of it: she was in a little dark shop, leaning with her elbows on the counter, and opposite to her was an old Sheep, sitting in an arm-chair knitting, and every now and then leaving off to look at her through a great pair of spectacles.
‚ÄòWhat is it you want to buy?‚Äô the Sheep said at last, looking up for a moment from her knitting.
‚ÄòI don‚Äôt quite know yet,‚Äô Alice said, very gently. ‚ÄòI should like to look all round me first, if I might.‚Äô
‚ÄòYou may look in front of you, and on both sides, if you like,‚Äô said the Sheep: ‚Äòbut you can‚Äôt look all round you‚Äîunless you‚Äôve got eyes at the back of your head.‚Äô
But these, as it happened, Alice had not got: so she contented herself with turning round, looking at the shelves as she came to them.
The shop seemed to be full of all manner of curious things‚Äîbut the oddest part of it all was, that whenever she looked hard at any shelf, to make out exactly what it had on it, that particular shelf was always quite empty: though the others round it were crowded as full as they could hold.
‚ÄòThings flow about so here!‚Äô she said at last in a plaintive tone, after she had spent a minute or so in vainly pursuing a large bright thing, that looked sometimes like a doll and sometimes like a work-box, and was always in the shelf next above the one she was looking at. ‚ÄòAnd this one is the most provoking of all‚Äîbut I‚Äôll tell you what‚Äî‚Äô she added, as a sudden thought struck her, ‚ÄòI‚Äôll follow it up to the very top shelf of all. It‚Äôll puzzle it to go through the ceiling, I expect!‚Äô
But even this plan failed: the ‚Äòthing‚Äô went through the ceiling as quietly as possible, as if it were quite used to it.
‚ÄòAre you a child or a teetotum?‚Äô the Sheep said, as she took up another pair of needles. ‚ÄòYou‚Äôll make me giddy soon, if you go on turning round like that.‚Äô She was now working with fourteen pairs at once, and Alice couldn‚Äôt help looking at her in great astonishment.
‚ÄòHow can she knit with so many?‚Äô the puzzled child thought to herself. ‚ÄòShe gets more and more like a porcupine every minute!‚Äô
‚ÄòCan you row?‚Äô the Sheep asked, handing her a pair of knitting-needles as she spoke.
‚ÄòYes, a little‚Äîbut not on land‚Äîand not with needles‚Äî‚Äô Alice was beginning to say, when suddenly the needles turned into oars in her hands, and she found they were in a little boat, gliding along between banks: so there was nothing for it but to do her best.
‚ÄòFeather!‚Äô cried the Sheep, as she took up another pair of needles.
This didn‚Äôt sound like a remark that needed any answer, so Alice said nothing, but pulled away. There was something very queer about the water, she thought, as every now and then the oars got fast in it, and would hardly come out again.
‚ÄòFeather! Feather!‚Äô the Sheep cried again, taking more needles. ‚ÄòYou‚Äôll be catching a crab directly.‚Äô
‚ÄòA dear little crab!‚Äô thought Alice. ‚ÄòI should like that.‚Äô
‚ÄòDidn‚Äôt you hear me say ‚ÄúFeather‚Äù?‚Äô the Sheep cried angrily, taking up quite a bunch of needles.
‚ÄòIndeed I did,‚Äô said Alice: ‚Äòyou‚Äôve said it very often‚Äîand very loud. Please, where are the crabs?‚Äô
‚ÄòIn the water, of course!‚Äô said the Sheep, sticking some of the needles into her hair, as her hands were full. ‚ÄòFeather, I say!‚Äô
‚ÄòWhy do you say ‚Äúfeather‚Äù so often?‚Äô Alice asked at last, rather vexed. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm not a bird!‚Äô
‚ÄòYou are,‚Äô said the Sheep: ‚Äòyou‚Äôre a little goose.‚Äô
This offended Alice a little, so there was no more conversation for a minute or two, while the boat glided gently on, sometimes among beds of weeds (which made the oars stick fast in the water, worse then ever), and sometimes under trees, but always with the same tall river-banks frowning over their heads.
‚ÄòOh, please! There are some scented rushes!‚Äô Alice cried in a sudden transport of delight. ‚ÄòThere really are‚Äîand such beauties!‚Äô
‚ÄòYou needn‚Äôt say ‚Äúplease‚Äù to me about ‚Äòem,‚Äô the Sheep said, without looking up from her knitting: ‚ÄòI didn‚Äôt put ‚Äòem there, and I‚Äôm not going to take ‚Äòem away.‚Äô
‚ÄòNo, but I meant‚Äîplease, may we wait and pick some?‚Äô Alice pleaded. ‚ÄòIf you don‚Äôt mind stopping the boat for a minute.‚Äô
‚ÄòHow am I to stop it?‚Äô said the Sheep. ‚ÄòIf you leave off rowing, it‚Äôll stop of itself.‚Äô
So the boat was left to drift down the stream as it would, till it glided gently in among the waving rushes. And then the little sleeves were carefully rolled up, and the little arms were plunged in elbow-deep to get the rushes a good long way down before breaking them off‚Äîand for a while Alice forgot all about the Sheep and the knitting, as she bent over the side of the boat, with just the ends of her tangled hair dipping into the water‚Äîwhile with bright eager eyes she caught at one bunch after another of the darling scented rushes.
‚ÄòI only hope the boat won‚Äôt tipple over!‚Äô she said to herself. ‚ÄòOh, what a lovely one! Only I couldn‚Äôt quite reach it.‚Äô ‚ÄòAnd it certainly did seem a little provoking (‚Äòalmost as if it happened on purpose,‚Äô she thought) that, though she managed to pick plenty of beautiful rushes as the boat glided by, there was always a more lovely one that she couldn‚Äôt reach.
‚ÄòThe prettiest are always further!‚Äô she said at last, with a sigh at the obstinacy of the rushes in growing so far off, as, with flushed cheeks and dripping hair and hands, she scrambled back into her place, and began to arrange her new-found treasures.
What mattered it to her just then that the rushes had begun to fade, and to lose all their scent and beauty, from the very moment that she picked them? Even real scented rushes, you know, last only a very little while‚Äîand these, being dream-rushes, melted away almost like snow, as they lay in heaps at her feet‚Äîbut Alice hardly noticed this, there were so many other curious things to think about.
They hadn‚Äôt gone much farther before the blade of one of the oars got fast in the water and wouldn‚Äôt come out again (so Alice explained it afterwards), and the consequence was that the handle of it caught her under the chin, and, in spite of a series of little shrieks of ‚ÄòOh, oh, oh!‚Äô from poor Alice, it swept her straight off the seat, and down among the heap of rushes.
However, she wasn‚Äôt hurt, and was soon up again: the Sheep went on with her knitting all the while, just as if nothing had happened. ‚ÄòThat was a nice crab you caught!‚Äô she remarked, as Alice got back into her place, very much relieved to find herself still in the boat.
‚ÄòWas it? I didn‚Äôt see it,‚Äô Said Alice, peeping cautiously over the side of the boat into the dark water. ‚ÄòI wish it hadn‚Äôt let go‚ÄîI should so like to see a little crab to take home with me!‚Äô But the Sheep only laughed scornfully, and went on with her knitting.
‚ÄòAre there many crabs here?‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòCrabs, and all sorts of things,‚Äô said the Sheep: ‚Äòplenty of choice, only make up your mind. Now, what do you want to buy?‚Äô
‚ÄòTo buy!‚Äô Alice echoed in a tone that was half astonished and half frightened‚Äîfor the oars, and the boat, and the river, had vanished all in a moment, and she was back again in the little dark shop.
‚ÄòI should like to buy an egg, please,‚Äô she said timidly. ‚ÄòHow do you sell them?‚Äô
‚ÄòFivepence farthing for one‚ÄîTwopence for two,‚Äô the Sheep replied.
‚ÄòThen two are cheaper than one?‚Äô Alice said in a surprised tone, taking out her purse.
‚ÄòOnly you must eat them both, if you buy two,‚Äô said the Sheep.
‚ÄòThen I‚Äôll have one, please,‚Äô said Alice, as she put the money down on the counter. For she thought to herself, ‚ÄòThey mightn‚Äôt be at all nice, you know.‚Äô
The Sheep took the money, and put it away in a box: then she said ‚ÄòI never put things into people‚Äôs hands‚Äîthat would never do‚Äîyou must get it for yourself.‚Äô And so saying, she went off to the other end of the shop, and set the egg upright on a shelf.
‚ÄòI wonder why it wouldn‚Äôt do?‚Äô thought Alice, as she groped her way among the tables and chairs, for the shop was very dark towards the end. ‚ÄòThe egg seems to get further away the more I walk towards it. Let me see, is this a chair? Why, it‚Äôs got branches, I declare! How very odd to find trees growing here! And actually here‚Äôs a little brook! Well, this is the very queerest shop I ever saw!‚Äô
* * * *
* * *
* * * *
So she went on, wondering more and more at every step, as everything turned into a tree the moment she came up to it, and she quite expected the egg to do the same.

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter 6 - Humpty Dumpty

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice meets Humpty Dumpty, who sits on a wall. They discuss language and meaning. Humpty Dumpty explains his interpretation of various words and poems before falling off the wall, just as in the nursery rhyme.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, Alice found herself before Humpty Dumpty, seated precariously on a digital wall created by DaSCH. With RabbitIT by her side, she listened intently as Humpty Dumpty embarked on a quirky explanation of words, twisting meanings in his unique, whimsical fashion.
As Humpty expounded on his philosophy‚Äîthat words meant exactly what he chose them to mean, neither more nor less‚ÄîAlice marveled at the eccentricity of his logic, enhanced by RabbitIT's contextual data from literary references stored within DaSCH.
The encounter took a sudden turn as Humpty Dumpty, lost in his exposition, toppled from the wall in a dramatic, yet digitally cushioned fall. Alice and RabbitIT watched as the system simulated the iconic scramble to put Humpty together again, blending the surreal with the educational in a memorable moment of DaSCHland's narrative adventure.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
However, the egg only got larger and larger, and more and more human: when she had come within a few yards of it, she saw that it had eyes and a nose and mouth; and when she had come close to it, she saw clearly that it was HUMPTY DUMPTY himself. ‚ÄòIt can‚Äôt be anybody else!‚Äô she said to herself. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm as certain of it, as if his name were written all over his face.‚Äô
It might have been written a hundred times, easily, on that enormous face. Humpty Dumpty was sitting with his legs crossed, like a Turk, on the top of a high wall‚Äîsuch a narrow one that Alice quite wondered how he could keep his balance‚Äîand, as his eyes were steadily fixed in the opposite direction, and he didn‚Äôt take the least notice of her, she thought he must be a stuffed figure after all.
‚ÄòAnd how exactly like an egg he is!‚Äô she said aloud, standing with her hands ready to catch him, for she was every moment expecting him to fall.
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs very provoking,‚Äô Humpty Dumpty said after a long silence, looking away from Alice as he spoke, ‚Äòto be called an egg‚ÄîVery!‚Äô
‚ÄòI said you looked like an egg, Sir,‚Äô Alice gently explained. ‚ÄòAnd some eggs are very pretty, you know‚Äô she added, hoping to turn her remark into a sort of a compliment.
‚ÄòSome people,‚Äô said Humpty Dumpty, looking away from her as usual, ‚Äòhave no more sense than a baby!‚Äô
Alice didn‚Äôt know what to say to this: it wasn‚Äôt at all like conversation, she thought, as he never said anything to her; in fact, his last remark was evidently addressed to a tree‚Äîso she stood and softly repeated to herself:‚Äî
‚ÄòHumpty Dumpty sat on a wall: Humpty Dumpty had a great fall. All the King‚Äôs horses and all the King‚Äôs men Couldn‚Äôt put Humpty Dumpty in his place again.‚Äô
‚ÄòThat last line is much too long for the poetry,‚Äô she added, almost out loud, forgetting that Humpty Dumpty would hear her.
‚ÄòDon‚Äôt stand there chattering to yourself like that,‚Äô Humpty Dumpty said, looking at her for the first time, ‚Äòbut tell me your name and your business.‚Äô
‚ÄòMy name is Alice, but‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs a stupid enough name!‚Äô Humpty Dumpty interrupted impatiently. ‚ÄòWhat does it mean?‚Äô
‚ÄòMust a name mean something?‚Äô Alice asked doubtfully.
‚ÄòOf course it must,‚Äô Humpty Dumpty said with a short laugh: ‚Äòmy name means the shape I am‚Äîand a good handsome shape it is, too. With a name like yours, you might be any shape, almost.‚Äô
‚ÄòWhy do you sit out here all alone?‚Äô said Alice, not wishing to begin an argument.
‚ÄòWhy, because there‚Äôs nobody with me!‚Äô cried Humpty Dumpty. ‚ÄòDid you think I didn‚Äôt know the answer to that? Ask another.‚Äô
‚ÄòDon‚Äôt you think you‚Äôd be safer down on the ground?‚Äô Alice went on, not with any idea of making another riddle, but simply in her good-natured anxiety for the queer creature. ‚ÄòThat wall is so very narrow!‚Äô
‚ÄòWhat tremendously easy riddles you ask!‚Äô Humpty Dumpty growled out. ‚ÄòOf course I don‚Äôt think so! Why, if ever I did fall off‚Äîwhich there‚Äôs no chance of‚Äîbut if I did‚Äî‚Äô Here he pursed his lips and looked so solemn and grand that Alice could hardly help laughing. ‚ÄòIf I did fall,‚Äô he went on, ‚ÄòThe King has promised me‚Äîwith his very own mouth‚Äîto‚Äîto‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòTo send all his horses and all his men,‚Äô Alice interrupted, rather unwisely.
‚ÄòNow I declare that‚Äôs too bad!‚Äô Humpty Dumpty cried, breaking into a sudden passion. ‚ÄòYou‚Äôve been listening at doors‚Äîand behind trees‚Äîand down chimneys‚Äîor you couldn‚Äôt have known it!‚Äô
‚ÄòI haven‚Äôt, indeed!‚Äô Alice said very gently. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs in a book.‚Äô
‚ÄòAh, well! They may write such things in a book,‚Äô Humpty Dumpty said in a calmer tone. ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs what you call a History of England, that is. Now, take a good look at me! I‚Äôm one that has spoken to a King, I am: mayhap you‚Äôll never see such another: and to show you I‚Äôm not proud, you may shake hands with me!‚Äô And he grinned almost from ear to ear, as he leant forwards (and as nearly as possible fell off the wall in doing so) and offered Alice his hand. She watched him a little anxiously as she took it. ‚ÄòIf he smiled much more, the ends of his mouth might meet behind,‚Äô she thought: ‚Äòand then I don‚Äôt know what would happen to his head! I‚Äôm afraid it would come off!‚Äô
‚ÄòYes, all his horses and all his men,‚Äô Humpty Dumpty went on. ‚ÄòThey‚Äôd pick me up again in a minute, they would! However, this conversation is going on a little too fast: let‚Äôs go back to the last remark but one.‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôm afraid I can‚Äôt quite remember it,‚Äô Alice said very politely.
‚ÄòIn that case we start fresh,‚Äô said Humpty Dumpty, ‚Äòand it‚Äôs my turn to choose a subject‚Äî‚Äô (‚ÄòHe talks about it just as if it was a game!‚Äô thought Alice.) ‚ÄòSo here‚Äôs a question for you. How old did you say you were?‚Äô
Alice made a short calculation, and said ‚ÄòSeven years and six months.‚Äô
‚ÄòWrong!‚Äô Humpty Dumpty exclaimed triumphantly. ‚ÄòYou never said a word like it!‚Äô
‚ÄòI though you meant ‚ÄúHow old are you?‚Äù‚Äô Alice explained.
‚ÄòIf I‚Äôd meant that, I‚Äôd have said it,‚Äô said Humpty Dumpty.
Alice didn‚Äôt want to begin another argument, so she said nothing.
‚ÄòSeven years and six months!‚Äô Humpty Dumpty repeated thoughtfully. ‚ÄòAn uncomfortable sort of age. Now if you‚Äôd asked my advice, I‚Äôd have said ‚ÄúLeave off at seven‚Äù‚Äîbut it‚Äôs too late now.‚Äô
‚ÄòI never ask advice about growing,‚Äô Alice said indignantly.
‚ÄòToo proud?‚Äô the other inquired.
Alice felt even more indignant at this suggestion. ‚ÄòI mean,‚Äô she said, ‚Äòthat one can‚Äôt help growing older.‚Äô
‚ÄòOne can‚Äôt, perhaps,‚Äô said Humpty Dumpty, ‚Äòbut two can. With proper assistance, you might have left off at seven.‚Äô
‚ÄòWhat a beautiful belt you‚Äôve got on!‚Äô Alice suddenly remarked.
(They had had quite enough of the subject of age, she thought: and if they really were to take turns in choosing subjects, it was her turn now.) ‚ÄòAt least,‚Äô she corrected herself on second thoughts, ‚Äòa beautiful cravat, I should have said‚Äîno, a belt, I mean‚ÄîI beg your pardon!‚Äô she added in dismay, for Humpty Dumpty looked thoroughly offended, and she began to wish she hadn‚Äôt chosen that subject. ‚ÄòIf I only knew,‚Äô she thought to herself, ‚Äòwhich was neck and which was waist!‚Äô
Evidently Humpty Dumpty was very angry, though he said nothing for a minute or two. When he did speak again, it was in a deep growl.
‚ÄòIt is a‚Äîmost‚Äîprovoking‚Äîthing,‚Äô he said at last, ‚Äòwhen a person doesn‚Äôt know a cravat from a belt!‚Äô
‚ÄòI know it‚Äôs very ignorant of me,‚Äô Alice said, in so humble a tone that Humpty Dumpty relented.
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs a cravat, child, and a beautiful one, as you say. It‚Äôs a present from the White King and Queen. There now!‚Äô
‚ÄòIs it really?‚Äô said Alice, quite pleased to find that she had chosen a good subject, after all.
‚ÄòThey gave it me,‚Äô Humpty Dumpty continued thoughtfully, as he crossed one knee over the other and clasped his hands round it, ‚Äòthey gave it me‚Äîfor an un-birthday present.‚Äô
‚ÄòI beg your pardon?‚Äô Alice said with a puzzled air.
‚ÄòI‚Äôm not offended,‚Äô said Humpty Dumpty.
‚ÄòI mean, what is an un-birthday present?‚Äô
‚ÄòA present given when it isn‚Äôt your birthday, of course.‚Äô
Alice considered a little. ‚ÄòI like birthday presents best,‚Äô she said at last.
‚ÄòYou don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre talking about!‚Äô cried Humpty Dumpty. ‚ÄòHow many days are there in a year?‚Äô
‚ÄòThree hundred and sixty-five,‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòAnd how many birthdays have you?‚Äô
‚ÄòOne.‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd if you take one from three hundred and sixty-five, what remains?‚Äô
‚ÄòThree hundred and sixty-four, of course.‚Äô
Humpty Dumpty looked doubtful. ‚ÄòI‚Äôd rather see that done on paper,‚Äô he said.
Alice couldn‚Äôt help smiling as she took out her memorandum-book, and worked the sum for him:
365 1 364
Humpty Dumpty took the book, and looked at it carefully. ‚ÄòThat seems to be done right‚Äî‚Äô he began.
‚ÄòYou‚Äôre holding it upside down!‚Äô Alice interrupted.
‚ÄòTo be sure I was!‚Äô Humpty Dumpty said gaily, as she turned it round for him. ‚ÄòI thought it looked a little queer. As I was saying, that seems to be done right‚Äîthough I haven‚Äôt time to look it over thoroughly just now‚Äîand that shows that there are three hundred and sixty-four days when you might get un-birthday presents‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòCertainly,‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòAnd only one for birthday presents, you know. There‚Äôs glory for you!‚Äô
‚ÄòI don‚Äôt know what you mean by ‚Äúglory,‚Äù‚Äô Alice said.
Humpty Dumpty smiled contemptuously. ‚ÄòOf course you don‚Äôt‚Äîtill I tell you. I meant ‚Äúthere‚Äôs a nice knock-down argument for you!‚Äù‚Äô
‚ÄòBut ‚Äúglory‚Äù doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äúa nice knock-down argument,‚Äù‚Äô Alice objected.
‚ÄòWhen I use a word,‚Äô Humpty Dumpty said in rather a scornful tone, ‚Äòit means just what I choose it to mean‚Äîneither more nor less.‚Äô
‚ÄòThe question is,‚Äô said Alice, ‚Äòwhether you can make words mean so many different things.‚Äô
‚ÄòThe question is,‚Äô said Humpty Dumpty, ‚Äòwhich is to be master‚Äîthat‚Äôs all.‚Äô
Alice was too much puzzled to say anything, so after a minute Humpty Dumpty began again. ‚ÄòThey‚Äôve a temper, some of them‚Äîparticularly verbs, they‚Äôre the proudest‚Äîadjectives you can do anything with, but not verbs‚Äîhowever, I can manage the whole lot of them! Impenetrability! That‚Äôs what I say!‚Äô
‚ÄòWould you tell me, please,‚Äô said Alice ‚Äòwhat that means?‚Äô
‚ÄòNow you talk like a reasonable child,‚Äô said Humpty Dumpty, looking very much pleased. ‚ÄòI meant by ‚Äúimpenetrability‚Äù that we‚Äôve had enough of that subject, and it would be just as well if you‚Äôd mention what you mean to do next, as I suppose you don‚Äôt mean to stop here all the rest of your life.‚Äô
‚ÄòThat‚Äôs a great deal to make one word mean,‚Äô Alice said in a thoughtful tone.
‚ÄòWhen I make a word do a lot of work like that,‚Äô said Humpty Dumpty, ‚ÄòI always pay it extra.‚Äô
‚ÄòOh!‚Äô said Alice. She was too much puzzled to make any other remark.
‚ÄòAh, you should see ‚Äòem come round me of a Saturday night,‚Äô Humpty Dumpty went on, wagging his head gravely from side to side: ‚Äòfor to get their wages, you know.‚Äô
(Alice didn‚Äôt venture to ask what he paid them with; and so you see I can‚Äôt tell you.)
‚ÄòYou seem very clever at explaining words, Sir,‚Äô said Alice. ‚ÄòWould you kindly tell me the meaning of the poem called ‚ÄúJabberwocky‚Äù?‚Äô
‚ÄòLet‚Äôs hear it,‚Äô said Humpty Dumpty. ‚ÄòI can explain all the poems that were ever invented‚Äîand a good many that haven‚Äôt been invented just yet.‚Äô
This sounded very hopeful, so Alice repeated the first verse:
‚Äò‚ÄòTwas brillig, and the slithy toves Did gyre and gimble in the wabe; All mimsy were the borogoves, And the mome raths outgrabe.‚Äô
‚ÄòThat‚Äôs enough to begin with,‚Äô Humpty Dumpty interrupted: ‚Äòthere are plenty of hard words there. ‚ÄúBrillig‚Äù means four o‚Äôclock in the afternoon‚Äîthe time when you begin broiling things for dinner.‚Äô
‚ÄòThat‚Äôll do very well,‚Äô said Alice: ‚Äòand ‚Äúslithy‚Äù?‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, ‚Äúslithy‚Äù means ‚Äúlithe and slimy.‚Äù ‚ÄúLithe‚Äù is the same as ‚Äúactive.‚Äù You see it‚Äôs like a portmanteau‚Äîthere are two meanings packed up into one word.‚Äô
‚ÄòI see it now,‚Äô Alice remarked thoughtfully: ‚Äòand what are ‚Äútoves‚Äù?‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, ‚Äútoves‚Äù are something like badgers‚Äîthey‚Äôre something like lizards‚Äîand they‚Äôre something like corkscrews.‚Äô
‚ÄòThey must be very curious looking creatures.‚Äô
‚ÄòThey are that,‚Äô said Humpty Dumpty: ‚Äòalso they make their nests under sun-dials‚Äîalso they live on cheese.‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd what‚Äôs the ‚Äúgyre‚Äù and to ‚Äúgimble‚Äù?‚Äô
‚ÄòTo ‚Äúgyre‚Äù is to go round and round like a gyroscope. To ‚Äúgimble‚Äù is to make holes like a gimlet.‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd ‚Äúthe wabe‚Äù is the grass-plot round a sun-dial, I suppose?‚Äô said Alice, surprised at her own ingenuity.
‚ÄòOf course it is. It‚Äôs called ‚Äúwabe,‚Äù you know, because it goes a long way before it, and a long way behind it‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd a long way beyond it on each side,‚Äô Alice added.
‚ÄòExactly so. Well, then, ‚Äúmimsy‚Äù is ‚Äúflimsy and miserable‚Äù (there‚Äôs another portmanteau for you). And a ‚Äúborogove‚Äù is a thin shabby-looking bird with its feathers sticking out all round‚Äîsomething like a live mop.‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd then ‚Äúmome raths‚Äù?‚Äô said Alice. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm afraid I‚Äôm giving you a great deal of trouble.‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, a ‚Äúrath‚Äù is a sort of green pig: but ‚Äúmome‚Äù I‚Äôm not certain about. I think it‚Äôs short for ‚Äúfrom home‚Äù‚Äîmeaning that they‚Äôd lost their way, you know.‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd what does ‚Äúoutgrabe‚Äù mean?‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, ‚Äúoutgrabing‚Äù is something between bellowing and whistling, with a kind of sneeze in the middle: however, you‚Äôll hear it done, maybe‚Äîdown in the wood yonder‚Äîand when you‚Äôve once heard it you‚Äôll be quite content. Who‚Äôs been repeating all that hard stuff to you?‚Äô
‚ÄòI read it in a book,‚Äô said Alice. ‚ÄòBut I had some poetry repeated to me, much easier than that, by‚ÄîTweedledee, I think it was.‚Äô
‚ÄòAs to poetry, you know,‚Äô said Humpty Dumpty, stretching out one of his great hands, ‚ÄòI can repeat poetry as well as other folk, if it comes to that‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòOh, it needn‚Äôt come to that!‚Äô Alice hastily said, hoping to keep him from beginning.
‚ÄòThe piece I‚Äôm going to repeat,‚Äô he went on without noticing her remark, ‚Äòwas written entirely for your amusement.‚Äô
Alice felt that in that case she really ought to listen to it, so she sat down, and said ‚ÄòThank you‚Äô rather sadly.
‚ÄòIn winter, when the fields are white, I sing this song for your delight‚Äî
only I don‚Äôt sing it,‚Äô he added, as an explanation.
‚ÄòI see you don‚Äôt,‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòIf you can see whether I‚Äôm singing or not, you‚Äôve sharper eyes than most.‚Äô Humpty Dumpty remarked severely. Alice was silent.
‚ÄòIn spring, when woods are getting green, I‚Äôll try and tell you what I mean.‚Äô
‚ÄòThank you very much,‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòIn summer, when the days are long, Perhaps you‚Äôll understand the song: In autumn, when the leaves are brown, Take pen and ink, and write it down.‚Äô
‚ÄòI will, if I can remember it so long,‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòYou needn‚Äôt go on making remarks like that,‚Äô Humpty Dumpty said: ‚Äòthey‚Äôre not sensible, and they put me out.‚Äô
‚ÄòI sent a message to the fish: I told them ‚ÄúThis is what I wish.‚Äù
The little fishes of the sea, They sent an answer back to me.
The little fishes‚Äô answer was ‚ÄúWe cannot do it, Sir, because‚Äî‚Äú‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôm afraid I don‚Äôt quite understand,‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòIt gets easier further on,‚Äô Humpty Dumpty replied.
‚ÄòI sent to them again to say ‚ÄúIt will be better to obey.‚Äù
The fishes answered with a grin, ‚ÄúWhy, what a temper you are in!‚Äù
I told them once, I told them twice: They would not listen to advice.
I took a kettle large and new, Fit for the deed I had to do.
My heart went hop, my heart went thump; I filled the kettle at the pump.
Then some one came to me and said, ‚ÄúThe little fishes are in bed.‚Äù
I said to him, I said it plain, ‚ÄúThen you must wake them up again.‚Äù
I said it very loud and clear; I went and shouted in his ear.‚Äô
Humpty Dumpty raised his voice almost to a scream as he repeated this verse, and Alice thought with a shudder, ‚ÄòI wouldn‚Äôt have been the messenger for anything!‚Äô
‚ÄòBut he was very stiff and proud; He said ‚ÄúYou needn‚Äôt shout so loud!‚Äù
And he was very proud and stiff; He said ‚ÄúI‚Äôd go and wake them, if‚Äî‚Äù
I took a corkscrew from the shelf: I went to wake them up myself.
And when I found the door was locked, I pulled and pushed and kicked and knocked.
And when I found the door was shut, I tried to turn the handle, but‚Äî‚Äô
There was a long pause.
‚ÄòIs that all?‚Äô Alice timidly asked.
‚ÄòThat‚Äôs all,‚Äô said Humpty Dumpty. ‚ÄòGood-bye.‚Äô
This was rather sudden, Alice thought: but, after such a very strong hint that she ought to be going, she felt that it would hardly be civil to stay. So she got up, and held out her hand. ‚ÄòGood-bye, till we meet again!‚Äô she said as cheerfully as she could.
‚ÄòI shouldn‚Äôt know you again if we did meet,‚Äô Humpty Dumpty replied in a discontented tone, giving her one of his fingers to shake; ‚Äòyou‚Äôre so exactly like other people.‚Äô
‚ÄòThe face is what one goes by, generally,‚Äô Alice remarked in a thoughtful tone.
‚ÄòThat‚Äôs just what I complain of,‚Äô said Humpty Dumpty. ‚ÄòYour face is the same as everybody has‚Äîthe two eyes, so‚Äî‚Äô (marking their places in the air with this thumb) ‚Äònose in the middle, mouth under. It‚Äôs always the same. Now if you had the two eyes on the same side of the nose, for instance‚Äîor the mouth at the top‚Äîthat would be some help.‚Äô
‚ÄòIt wouldn‚Äôt look nice,‚Äô Alice objected. But Humpty Dumpty only shut his eyes and said ‚ÄòWait till you‚Äôve tried.‚Äô
Alice waited a minute to see if he would speak again, but as he never opened his eyes or took any further notice of her, she said ‚ÄòGood-bye!‚Äô once more, and, getting no answer to this, she quietly walked away: but she couldn‚Äôt help saying to herself as she went, ‚ÄòOf all the unsatisfactory‚Äî‚Äô (she repeated this aloud, as it was a great comfort to have such a long word to say) ‚Äòof all the unsatisfactory people I ever met‚Äî‚Äô She never finished the sentence, for at this moment a heavy crash shook the forest from end to end.

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter 7 - The Lion and the Unicorn

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice enters a town and witnesses a battle between the Lion and the Unicorn for the crown. The White King is there, and Alice is asked to cut the Lion and Unicorn a cake.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In the virtual landscape of DaSCHland, Alice, guided by RabbitIT, came upon a grand spectacle‚Äîa battle between the Lion and the Unicorn, both majestic creatures rendered from the extensive databases of DaSCH. The conflict was over a digital crown, symbolizing power and rule within this part of the literary world.
The Lion, fierce and proud, and the Unicorn, equally formidable and noble, clashed in a display of strength and agility, their movements choreographed based on descriptions found in ancient texts and legends preserved by DaSCH. RabbitIT provided Alice with background information on the symbolism of both creatures and the historical significance of their rivalry, enhancing her understanding of the scene.
As the battle raged, Alice observed the strategies and tactics of each creature, enthralled by the blend of historical accuracy and creative license that DaSCHland employed to bring this narrative to life. The chapter culminated in a dramatic, yet unresolved conclusion to the battle, leaving the crown hanging tantalizingly in the balance and Alice captivated by the vivid realism of the encounter.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
The next moment soldiers came running through the wood, at first in twos and threes, then ten or twenty together, and at last in such crowds that they seemed to fill the whole forest. Alice got behind a tree, for fear of being run over, and watched them go by.
She thought that in all her life she had never seen soldiers so uncertain on their feet: they were always tripping over something or other, and whenever one went down, several more always fell over him, so that the ground was soon covered with little heaps of men.
Then came the horses. Having four feet, these managed rather better than the foot-soldiers: but even they stumbled now and then; and it seemed to be a regular rule that, whenever a horse stumbled the rider fell off instantly. The confusion got worse every moment, and Alice was very glad to get out of the wood into an open place, where she found the White King seated on the ground, busily writing in his memorandum-book.
‚ÄòI‚Äôve sent them all!‚Äô the King cried in a tone of delight, on seeing Alice. ‚ÄòDid you happen to meet any soldiers, my dear, as you came through the wood?‚Äô
‚ÄòYes, I did,‚Äô said Alice: ‚Äòseveral thousand, I should think.‚Äô
‚ÄòFour thousand two hundred and seven, that‚Äôs the exact number,‚Äô the King said, referring to his book. ‚ÄòI couldn‚Äôt send all the horses, you know, because two of them are wanted in the game. And I haven‚Äôt sent the two Messengers, either. They‚Äôre both gone to the town. Just look along the road, and tell me if you can see either of them.‚Äô
‚ÄòI see nobody on the road,‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòI only wish I had such eyes,‚Äô the King remarked in a fretful tone. ‚ÄòTo be able to see Nobody! And at that distance, too! Why, it‚Äôs as much as I can do to see real people, by this light!‚Äô
All this was lost on Alice, who was still looking intently along the road, shading her eyes with one hand. ‚ÄòI see somebody now!‚Äô she exclaimed at last. ‚ÄòBut he‚Äôs coming very slowly‚Äîand what curious attitudes he goes into!‚Äô (For the messenger kept skipping up and down, and wriggling like an eel, as he came along, with his great hands spread out like fans on each side.)
‚ÄòNot at all,‚Äô said the King. ‚ÄòHe‚Äôs an Anglo-Saxon Messenger‚Äîand those are Anglo-Saxon attitudes. He only does them when he‚Äôs happy. His name is Haigha.‚Äô (He pronounced it so as to rhyme with ‚Äòmayor.‚Äô)
‚ÄòI love my love with an H,‚Äô Alice couldn‚Äôt help beginning, ‚Äòbecause he is Happy. I hate him with an H, because he is Hideous. I fed him with‚Äîwith‚Äîwith Ham-sandwiches and Hay. His name is Haigha, and he lives‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòHe lives on the Hill,‚Äô the King remarked simply, without the least idea that he was joining in the game, while Alice was still hesitating for the name of a town beginning with H. ‚ÄòThe other Messenger‚Äôs called Hatta. I must have two, you know‚Äîto come and go. One to come, and one to go.‚Äô
‚ÄòI beg your pardon?‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòIt isn‚Äôt respectable to beg,‚Äô said the King.
‚ÄòI only meant that I didn‚Äôt understand,‚Äô said Alice. ‚ÄòWhy one to come and one to go?‚Äô
‚ÄòDidn‚Äôt I tell you?‚Äô the King repeated impatiently. ‚ÄòI must have two‚Äîto fetch and carry. One to fetch, and one to carry.‚Äô
At this moment the Messenger arrived: he was far too much out of breath to say a word, and could only wave his hands about, and make the most fearful faces at the poor King.
‚ÄòThis young lady loves you with an H,‚Äô the King said, introducing Alice in the hope of turning off the Messenger‚Äôs attention from himself‚Äîbut it was no use‚Äîthe Anglo-Saxon attitudes only got more extraordinary every moment, while the great eyes rolled wildly from side to side.
‚ÄòYou alarm me!‚Äô said the King. ‚ÄòI feel faint‚ÄîGive me a ham sandwich!‚Äô
On which the Messenger, to Alice‚Äôs great amusement, opened a bag that hung round his neck, and handed a sandwich to the King, who devoured it greedily.
‚ÄòAnother sandwich!‚Äô said the King.
‚ÄòThere‚Äôs nothing but hay left now,‚Äô the Messenger said, peeping into the bag.
‚ÄòHay, then,‚Äô the King murmured in a faint whisper.
Alice was glad to see that it revived him a good deal. ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs nothing like eating hay when you‚Äôre faint,‚Äô he remarked to her, as he munched away.
‚ÄòI should think throwing cold water over you would be better,‚Äô Alice suggested: ‚Äòor some sal-volatile.‚Äô
‚ÄòI didn‚Äôt say there was nothing better,‚Äô the King replied. ‚ÄòI said there was nothing like it.‚Äô Which Alice did not venture to deny.
‚ÄòWho did you pass on the road?‚Äô the King went on, holding out his hand to the Messenger for some more hay.
‚ÄòNobody,‚Äô said the Messenger.
‚ÄòQuite right,‚Äô said the King: ‚Äòthis young lady saw him too. So of course Nobody walks slower than you.‚Äô
‚ÄòI do my best,‚Äô the Messenger said in a sulky tone. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm sure nobody walks much faster than I do!‚Äô
‚ÄòHe can‚Äôt do that,‚Äô said the King, ‚Äòor else he‚Äôd have been here first. However, now you‚Äôve got your breath, you may tell us what‚Äôs happened in the town.‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôll whisper it,‚Äô said the Messenger, putting his hands to his mouth in the shape of a trumpet, and stooping so as to get close to the King‚Äôs ear. Alice was sorry for this, as she wanted to hear the news too. However, instead of whispering, he simply shouted at the top of his voice ‚ÄòThey‚Äôre at it again!‚Äô
‚ÄòDo you call that a whisper?‚Äô cried the poor King, jumping up and shaking himself. ‚ÄòIf you do such a thing again, I‚Äôll have you buttered! It went through and through my head like an earthquake!‚Äô
‚ÄòIt would have to be a very tiny earthquake!‚Äô thought Alice. ‚ÄòWho are at it again?‚Äô she ventured to ask.
‚ÄòWhy the Lion and the Unicorn, of course,‚Äô said the King.
‚ÄòFighting for the crown?‚Äô
‚ÄòYes, to be sure,‚Äô said the King: ‚Äòand the best of the joke is, that it‚Äôs my crown all the while! Let‚Äôs run and see them.‚Äô And they trotted off, Alice repeating to herself, as she ran, the words of the old song:‚Äî
‚ÄòThe Lion and the Unicorn were fighting for the crown: The Lion beat the Unicorn all round the town. Some gave them white bread, some gave them brown; Some gave them plum-cake and drummed them out of town.‚Äô
‚ÄòDoes‚Äîthe one‚Äîthat wins‚Äîget the crown?‚Äô she asked, as well as she could, for the run was putting her quite out of breath.
‚ÄòDear me, no!‚Äô said the King. ‚ÄòWhat an idea!‚Äô
‚ÄòWould you‚Äîbe good enough,‚Äô Alice panted out, after running a little further, ‚Äòto stop a minute‚Äîjust to get‚Äîone‚Äôs breath again?‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôm good enough,‚Äô the King said, ‚Äòonly I‚Äôm not strong enough. You see, a minute goes by so fearfully quick. You might as well try to stop a Bandersnatch!‚Äô
Alice had no more breath for talking, so they trotted on in silence, till they came in sight of a great crowd, in the middle of which the Lion and Unicorn were fighting. They were in such a cloud of dust, that at first Alice could not make out which was which: but she soon managed to distinguish the Unicorn by his horn.
They placed themselves close to where Hatta, the other messenger, was standing watching the fight, with a cup of tea in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other.
‚ÄòHe‚Äôs only just out of prison, and he hadn‚Äôt finished his tea when he was sent in,‚Äô Haigha whispered to Alice: ‚Äòand they only give them oyster-shells in there‚Äîso you see he‚Äôs very hungry and thirsty. How are you, dear child?‚Äô he went on, putting his arm affectionately round Hatta‚Äôs neck.
Hatta looked round and nodded, and went on with his bread and butter.
‚ÄòWere you happy in prison, dear child?‚Äô said Haigha.
Hatta looked round once more, and this time a tear or two trickled down his cheek: but not a word would he say.
‚ÄòSpeak, can‚Äôt you!‚Äô Haigha cried impatiently. But Hatta only munched away, and drank some more tea.
‚ÄòSpeak, won‚Äôt you!‚Äô cried the King. ‚ÄòHow are they getting on with the fight?‚Äô
Hatta made a desperate effort, and swallowed a large piece of bread-and-butter. ‚ÄòThey‚Äôre getting on very well,‚Äô he said in a choking voice: ‚Äòeach of them has been down about eighty-seven times.‚Äô
‚ÄòThen I suppose they‚Äôll soon bring the white bread and the brown?‚Äô Alice ventured to remark.
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs waiting for ‚Äòem now,‚Äô said Hatta: ‚Äòthis is a bit of it as I‚Äôm eating.‚Äô
There was a pause in the fight just then, and the Lion and the Unicorn sat down, panting, while the King called out ‚ÄòTen minutes allowed for refreshments!‚Äô Haigha and Hatta set to work at once, carrying rough trays of white and brown bread. Alice took a piece to taste, but it was very dry.
‚ÄòI don‚Äôt think they‚Äôll fight any more to-day,‚Äô the King said to Hatta: ‚Äògo and order the drums to begin.‚Äô And Hatta went bounding away like a grasshopper.
For a minute or two Alice stood silent, watching him. Suddenly she brightened up. ‚ÄòLook, look!‚Äô she cried, pointing eagerly. ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs the White Queen running across the country! She came flying out of the wood over yonder‚ÄîHow fast those Queens can run!‚Äô
‚ÄòThere‚Äôs some enemy after her, no doubt,‚Äô the King said, without even looking round. ‚ÄòThat wood‚Äôs full of them.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut aren‚Äôt you going to run and help her?‚Äô Alice asked, very much surprised at his taking it so quietly.
‚ÄòNo use, no use!‚Äô said the King. ‚ÄòShe runs so fearfully quick. You might as well try to catch a Bandersnatch! But I‚Äôll make a memorandum about her, if you like‚ÄîShe‚Äôs a dear good creature,‚Äô he repeated softly to himself, as he opened his memorandum-book. ‚ÄòDo you spell ‚Äúcreature‚Äù with a double ‚Äúe‚Äù?‚Äô
At this moment the Unicorn sauntered by them, with his hands in his pockets. ‚ÄòI had the best of it this time?‚Äô he said to the King, just glancing at him as he passed.
‚ÄòA little‚Äîa little,‚Äô the King replied, rather nervously. ‚ÄòYou shouldn‚Äôt have run him through with your horn, you know.‚Äô
‚ÄòIt didn‚Äôt hurt him,‚Äô the Unicorn said carelessly, and he was going on, when his eye happened to fall upon Alice: he turned round rather instantly, and stood for some time looking at her with an air of the deepest disgust.
‚ÄòWhat‚Äîis‚Äîthis?‚Äô he said at last.
‚ÄòThis is a child!‚Äô Haigha replied eagerly, coming in front of Alice to introduce her, and spreading out both his hands towards her in an Anglo-Saxon attitude. ‚ÄòWe only found it to-day. It‚Äôs as large as life, and twice as natural!‚Äô
‚ÄòI always thought they were fabulous monsters!‚Äô said the Unicorn. ‚ÄòIs it alive?‚Äô
‚ÄòIt can talk,‚Äô said Haigha, solemnly.
The Unicorn looked dreamily at Alice, and said ‚ÄòTalk, child.‚Äô
Alice could not help her lips curling up into a smile as she began: ‚ÄòDo you know, I always thought Unicorns were fabulous monsters, too! I never saw one alive before!‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, now that we have seen each other,‚Äô said the Unicorn, ‚Äòif you‚Äôll believe in me, I‚Äôll believe in you. Is that a bargain?‚Äô
‚ÄòYes, if you like,‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòCome, fetch out the plum-cake, old man!‚Äô the Unicorn went on, turning from her to the King. ‚ÄòNone of your brown bread for me!‚Äô
‚ÄòCertainly‚Äîcertainly!‚Äô the King muttered, and beckoned to Haigha. ‚ÄòOpen the bag!‚Äô he whispered. ‚ÄòQuick! Not that one‚Äîthat‚Äôs full of hay!‚Äô
Haigha took a large cake out of the bag, and gave it to Alice to hold, while he got out a dish and carving-knife. How they all came out of it Alice couldn‚Äôt guess. It was just like a conjuring-trick, she thought.
The Lion had joined them while this was going on: he looked very tired and sleepy, and his eyes were half shut. ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs this!‚Äô he said, blinking lazily at Alice, and speaking in a deep hollow tone that sounded like the tolling of a great bell.
‚ÄòAh, what is it, now?‚Äô the Unicorn cried eagerly. ‚ÄòYou‚Äôll never guess! I couldn‚Äôt.‚Äô
The Lion looked at Alice wearily. ‚ÄòAre you animal‚Äîvegetable‚Äîor mineral?‚Äô he said, yawning at every other word.
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs a fabulous monster!‚Äô the Unicorn cried out, before Alice could reply.
‚ÄòThen hand round the plum-cake, Monster,‚Äô the Lion said, lying down and putting his chin on his paws. ‚ÄòAnd sit down, both of you,‚Äô (to the King and the Unicorn): ‚Äòfair play with the cake, you know!‚Äô
The King was evidently very uncomfortable at having to sit down between the two great creatures; but there was no other place for him.
‚ÄòWhat a fight we might have for the crown, now!‚Äô the Unicorn said, looking slyly up at the crown, which the poor King was nearly shaking off his head, he trembled so much.
‚ÄòI should win easy,‚Äô said the Lion.
‚ÄòI‚Äôm not so sure of that,‚Äô said the Unicorn.
‚ÄòWhy, I beat you all round the town, you chicken!‚Äô the Lion replied angrily, half getting up as he spoke.
Here the King interrupted, to prevent the quarrel going on: he was very nervous, and his voice quite quivered. ‚ÄòAll round the town?‚Äô he said. ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs a good long way. Did you go by the old bridge, or the market-place? You get the best view by the old bridge.‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôm sure I don‚Äôt know,‚Äô the Lion growled out as he lay down again. ‚ÄòThere was too much dust to see anything. What a time the Monster is, cutting up that cake!‚Äô
Alice had seated herself on the bank of a little brook, with the great dish on her knees, and was sawing away diligently with the knife. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs very provoking!‚Äô she said, in reply to the Lion (she was getting quite used to being called ‚Äòthe Monster‚Äô). ‚ÄòI‚Äôve cut several slices already, but they always join on again!‚Äô
‚ÄòYou don‚Äôt know how to manage Looking-glass cakes,‚Äô the Unicorn remarked. ‚ÄòHand it round first, and cut it afterwards.‚Äô
This sounded nonsense, but Alice very obediently got up, and carried the dish round, and the cake divided itself into three pieces as she did so. ‚ÄòNow cut it up,‚Äô said the Lion, as she returned to her place with the empty dish.
‚ÄòI say, this isn‚Äôt fair!‚Äô cried the Unicorn, as Alice sat with the knife in her hand, very much puzzled how to begin. ‚ÄòThe Monster has given the Lion twice as much as me!‚Äô
‚ÄòShe‚Äôs kept none for herself, anyhow,‚Äô said the Lion. ‚ÄòDo you like plum-cake, Monster?‚Äô
But before Alice could answer him, the drums began.
Where the noise came from, she couldn‚Äôt make out: the air seemed full of it, and it rang through and through her head till she felt quite deafened. She started to her feet and sprang across the little brook in her terror,
* * * *
* * *
* * * *
and had just time to see the Lion and the Unicorn rise to their feet, with angry looks at being interrupted in their feast, before she dropped to her knees, and put her hands over her ears, vainly trying to shut out the dreadful uproar.
‚ÄòIf that doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúdrum them out of town,‚Äù‚Äô she thought to herself, ‚Äònothing ever will!‚Äô

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter 8 - ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my own Invention‚Äù

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice meets the White Knight, who helps her cross a brook into the eighth square, where she becomes a queen. The White Knight shares his various inventions with Alice before they part ways.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, Alice was escorted by the White Knight, a creation animated from DaSCH's vast repository. As they journeyed together, the Knight shared stories of his quirky inventions, each displayed vividly by RabbitIT through interactive simulations.
The White Knight also sang a heartfelt song about his adventures and dreams, his voice echoing through the digital landscape, enhanced by the historical ballads from DaSCH. Alice was captivated by his inventive spirit and the poignant melody, which added a layer of emotional depth to their encounter in this synthesized world.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
After a while the noise seemed gradually to die away, till all was dead silence, and Alice lifted up her head in some alarm. There was no one to be seen, and her first thought was that she must have been dreaming about the Lion and the Unicorn and those queer Anglo-Saxon Messengers. However, there was the great dish still lying at her feet, on which she had tried to cut the plum-cake, ‚ÄòSo I wasn‚Äôt dreaming, after all,‚Äô she said to herself, ‚Äòunless‚Äîunless we‚Äôre all part of the same dream. Only I do hope it‚Äôs my dream, and not the Red King‚Äôs! I don‚Äôt like belonging to another person‚Äôs dream,‚Äô she went on in a rather complaining tone: ‚ÄòI‚Äôve a great mind to go and wake him, and see what happens!‚Äô
At this moment her thoughts were interrupted by a loud shouting of ‚ÄòAhoy! Ahoy! Check!‚Äô and a Knight dressed in crimson armour came galloping down upon her, brandishing a great club. Just as he reached her, the horse stopped suddenly: ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre my prisoner!‚Äô the Knight cried, as he tumbled off his horse.
Startled as she was, Alice was more frightened for him than for herself at the moment, and watched him with some anxiety as he mounted again. As soon as he was comfortably in the saddle, he began once more ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre my‚Äî‚Äô but here another voice broke in ‚ÄòAhoy! Ahoy! Check!‚Äô and Alice looked round in some surprise for the new enemy.
This time it was a White Knight. He drew up at Alice‚Äôs side, and tumbled off his horse just as the Red Knight had done: then he got on again, and the two Knights sat and looked at each other for some time without speaking. Alice looked from one to the other in some bewilderment.
‚ÄòShe‚Äôs my prisoner, you know!‚Äô the Red Knight said at last.
‚ÄòYes, but then I came and rescued her!‚Äô the White Knight replied.
‚ÄòWell, we must fight for her, then,‚Äô said the Red Knight, as he took up his helmet (which hung from the saddle, and was something the shape of a horse‚Äôs head), and put it on.
‚ÄòYou will observe the Rules of Battle, of course?‚Äô the White Knight remarked, putting on his helmet too.
‚ÄòI always do,‚Äô said the Red Knight, and they began banging away at each other with such fury that Alice got behind a tree to be out of the way of the blows.
‚ÄòI wonder, now, what the Rules of Battle are,‚Äô she said to herself, as she watched the fight, timidly peeping out from her hiding-place: ‚Äòone Rule seems to be, that if one Knight hits the other, he knocks him off his horse, and if he misses, he tumbles off himself‚Äîand another Rule seems to be that they hold their clubs with their arms, as if they were Punch and Judy‚ÄîWhat a noise they make when they tumble! Just like a whole set of fire-irons falling into the fender! And how quiet the horses are! They let them get on and off them just as if they were tables!‚Äô
Another Rule of Battle, that Alice had not noticed, seemed to be that they always fell on their heads, and the battle ended with their both falling off in this way, side by side: when they got up again, they shook hands, and then the Red Knight mounted and galloped off.
‚ÄòIt was a glorious victory, wasn‚Äôt it?‚Äô said the White Knight, as he came up panting.
‚ÄòI don‚Äôt know,‚Äô Alice said doubtfully. ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt want to be anybody‚Äôs prisoner. I want to be a Queen.‚Äô
‚ÄòSo you will, when you‚Äôve crossed the next brook,‚Äô said the White Knight. ‚ÄòI‚Äôll see you safe to the end of the wood‚Äîand then I must go back, you know. That‚Äôs the end of my move.‚Äô
‚ÄòThank you very much,‚Äô said Alice. ‚ÄòMay I help you off with your helmet?‚Äô It was evidently more than he could manage by himself; however, she managed to shake him out of it at last.
‚ÄòNow one can breathe more easily,‚Äô said the Knight, putting back his shaggy hair with both hands, and turning his gentle face and large mild eyes to Alice. She thought she had never seen such a strange-looking soldier in all her life.
He was dressed in tin armour, which seemed to fit him very badly, and he had a queer-shaped little deal box fastened across his shoulder, upside-down, and with the lid hanging open. Alice looked at it with great curiosity.
‚ÄòI see you‚Äôre admiring my little box.‚Äô the Knight said in a friendly tone. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs my own invention‚Äîto keep clothes and sandwiches in. You see I carry it upside-down, so that the rain can‚Äôt get in.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut the things can get out,‚Äô Alice gently remarked. ‚ÄòDo you know the lid‚Äôs open?‚Äô
‚ÄòI didn‚Äôt know it,‚Äô the Knight said, a shade of vexation passing over his face. ‚ÄòThen all the things must have fallen out! And the box is no use without them.‚Äô He unfastened it as he spoke, and was just going to throw it into the bushes, when a sudden thought seemed to strike him, and he hung it carefully on a tree. ‚ÄòCan you guess why I did that?‚Äô he said to Alice.
Alice shook her head.
‚ÄòIn hopes some bees may make a nest in it‚Äîthen I should get the honey.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut you‚Äôve got a bee-hive‚Äîor something like one‚Äîfastened to the saddle,‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòYes, it‚Äôs a very good bee-hive,‚Äô the Knight said in a discontented tone, ‚Äòone of the best kind. But not a single bee has come near it yet. And the other thing is a mouse-trap. I suppose the mice keep the bees out‚Äîor the bees keep the mice out, I don‚Äôt know which.‚Äô
‚ÄòI was wondering what the mouse-trap was for,‚Äô said Alice. ‚ÄòIt isn‚Äôt very likely there would be any mice on the horse‚Äôs back.‚Äô
‚ÄòNot very likely, perhaps,‚Äô said the Knight: ‚Äòbut if they do come, I don‚Äôt choose to have them running all about.‚Äô
‚ÄòYou see,‚Äô he went on after a pause, ‚Äòit‚Äôs as well to be provided for everything. That‚Äôs the reason the horse has all those anklets round his feet.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut what are they for?‚Äô Alice asked in a tone of great curiosity.
‚ÄòTo guard against the bites of sharks,‚Äô the Knight replied. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs an invention of my own. And now help me on. I‚Äôll go with you to the end of the wood‚ÄîWhat‚Äôs the dish for?‚Äô
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs meant for plum-cake,‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòWe‚Äôd better take it with us,‚Äô the Knight said. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôll come in handy if we find any plum-cake. Help me to get it into this bag.‚Äô
This took a very long time to manage, though Alice held the bag open very carefully, because the Knight was so very awkward in putting in the dish: the first two or three times that he tried he fell in himself instead. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs rather a tight fit, you see,‚Äô he said, as they got it in a last; ‚ÄòThere are so many candlesticks in the bag.‚Äô And he hung it to the saddle, which was already loaded with bunches of carrots, and fire-irons, and many other things.
‚ÄòI hope you‚Äôve got your hair well fastened on?‚Äô he continued, as they set off.
‚ÄòOnly in the usual way,‚Äô Alice said, smiling.
‚ÄòThat‚Äôs hardly enough,‚Äô he said, anxiously. ‚ÄòYou see the wind is so very strong here. It‚Äôs as strong as soup.‚Äô
‚ÄòHave you invented a plan for keeping the hair from being blown off?‚Äô Alice enquired.
‚ÄòNot yet,‚Äô said the Knight. ‚ÄòBut I‚Äôve got a plan for keeping it from falling off.‚Äô
‚ÄòI should like to hear it, very much.‚Äô
‚ÄòFirst you take an upright stick,‚Äô said the Knight. ‚ÄòThen you make your hair creep up it, like a fruit-tree. Now the reason hair falls off is because it hangs down‚Äîthings never fall upwards, you know. It‚Äôs a plan of my own invention. You may try it if you like.‚Äô
It didn‚Äôt sound a comfortable plan, Alice thought, and for a few minutes she walked on in silence, puzzling over the idea, and every now and then stopping to help the poor Knight, who certainly was not a good rider.
Whenever the horse stopped (which it did very often), he fell off in front; and whenever it went on again (which it generally did rather suddenly), he fell off behind. Otherwise he kept on pretty well, except that he had a habit of now and then falling off sideways; and as he generally did this on the side on which Alice was walking, she soon found that it was the best plan not to walk quite close to the horse.
‚ÄòI‚Äôm afraid you‚Äôve not had much practice in riding,‚Äô she ventured to say, as she was helping him up from his fifth tumble.
The Knight looked very much surprised, and a little offended at the remark. ‚ÄòWhat makes you say that?‚Äô he asked, as he scrambled back into the saddle, keeping hold of Alice‚Äôs hair with one hand, to save himself from falling over on the other side.
‚ÄòBecause people don‚Äôt fall off quite so often, when they‚Äôve had much practice.‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôve had plenty of practice,‚Äô the Knight said very gravely: ‚Äòplenty of practice!‚Äô
Alice could think of nothing better to say than ‚ÄòIndeed?‚Äô but she said it as heartily as she could. They went on a little way in silence after this, the Knight with his eyes shut, muttering to himself, and Alice watching anxiously for the next tumble.
‚ÄòThe great art of riding,‚Äô the Knight suddenly began in a loud voice, waving his right arm as he spoke, ‚Äòis to keep‚Äî‚Äô Here the sentence ended as suddenly as it had begun, as the Knight fell heavily on the top of his head exactly in the path where Alice was walking. She was quite frightened this time, and said in an anxious tone, as she picked him up, ‚ÄòI hope no bones are broken?‚Äô
‚ÄòNone to speak of,‚Äô the Knight said, as if he didn‚Äôt mind breaking two or three of them. ‚ÄòThe great art of riding, as I was saying, is‚Äîto keep your balance properly. Like this, you know‚Äî‚Äô
He let go the bridle, and stretched out both his arms to show Alice what he meant, and this time he fell flat on his back, right under the horse‚Äôs feet.
‚ÄòPlenty of practice!‚Äô he went on repeating, all the time that Alice was getting him on his feet again. ‚ÄòPlenty of practice!‚Äô
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs too ridiculous!‚Äô cried Alice, losing all her patience this time. ‚ÄòYou ought to have a wooden horse on wheels, that you ought!‚Äô
‚ÄòDoes that kind go smoothly?‚Äô the Knight asked in a tone of great interest, clasping his arms round the horse‚Äôs neck as he spoke, just in time to save himself from tumbling off again.
‚ÄòMuch more smoothly than a live horse,‚Äô Alice said, with a little scream of laughter, in spite of all she could do to prevent it.
‚ÄòI‚Äôll get one,‚Äô the Knight said thoughtfully to himself. ‚ÄòOne or two‚Äîseveral.‚Äô
There was a short silence after this, and then the Knight went on again. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm a great hand at inventing things. Now, I daresay you noticed, that last time you picked me up, that I was looking rather thoughtful?‚Äô
‚ÄòYou were a little grave,‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòWell, just then I was inventing a new way of getting over a gate‚Äîwould you like to hear it?‚Äô
‚ÄòVery much indeed,‚Äô Alice said politely.
‚ÄòI‚Äôll tell you how I came to think of it,‚Äô said the Knight. ‚ÄòYou see, I said to myself, ‚ÄúThe only difficulty is with the feet: the head is high enough already.‚Äù Now, first I put my head on the top of the gate‚Äîthen I stand on my head‚Äîthen the feet are high enough, you see‚Äîthen I‚Äôm over, you see.‚Äô
‚ÄòYes, I suppose you‚Äôd be over when that was done,‚Äô Alice said thoughtfully: ‚Äòbut don‚Äôt you think it would be rather hard?‚Äô
‚ÄòI haven‚Äôt tried it yet,‚Äô the Knight said, gravely: ‚Äòso I can‚Äôt tell for certain‚Äîbut I‚Äôm afraid it would be a little hard.‚Äô
He looked so vexed at the idea, that Alice changed the subject hastily. ‚ÄòWhat a curious helmet you‚Äôve got!‚Äô she said cheerfully. ‚ÄòIs that your invention too?‚Äô
The Knight looked down proudly at his helmet, which hung from the saddle. ‚ÄòYes,‚Äô he said, ‚Äòbut I‚Äôve invented a better one than that‚Äîlike a sugar loaf. When I used to wear it, if I fell off the horse, it always touched the ground directly. So I had a very little way to fall, you see‚ÄîBut there was the danger of falling into it, to be sure. That happened to me once‚Äîand the worst of it was, before I could get out again, the other White Knight came and put it on. He thought it was his own helmet.‚Äô
The knight looked so solemn about it that Alice did not dare to laugh. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm afraid you must have hurt him,‚Äô she said in a trembling voice, ‚Äòbeing on the top of his head.‚Äô
‚ÄòI had to kick him, of course,‚Äô the Knight said, very seriously. ‚ÄòAnd then he took the helmet off again‚Äîbut it took hours and hours to get me out. I was as fast as‚Äîas lightning, you know.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut that‚Äôs a different kind of fastness,‚Äô Alice objected.
The Knight shook his head. ‚ÄòIt was all kinds of fastness with me, I can assure you!‚Äô he said. He raised his hands in some excitement as he said this, and instantly rolled out of the saddle, and fell headlong into a deep ditch.
Alice ran to the side of the ditch to look for him. She was rather startled by the fall, as for some time he had kept on very well, and she was afraid that he really was hurt this time. However, though she could see nothing but the soles of his feet, she was much relieved to hear that he was talking on in his usual tone. ‚ÄòAll kinds of fastness,‚Äô he repeated: ‚Äòbut it was careless of him to put another man‚Äôs helmet on‚Äîwith the man in it, too.‚Äô
‚ÄòHow can you go on talking so quietly, head downwards?‚Äô Alice asked, as she dragged him out by the feet, and laid him in a heap on the bank.
The Knight looked surprised at the question. ‚ÄòWhat does it matter where my body happens to be?‚Äô he said. ‚ÄòMy mind goes on working all the same. In fact, the more head downwards I am, the more I keep inventing new things.‚Äô
‚ÄòNow the cleverest thing of the sort that I ever did,‚Äô he went on after a pause, ‚Äòwas inventing a new pudding during the meat-course.‚Äô
‚ÄòIn time to have it cooked for the next course?‚Äô said Alice. ‚ÄòWell, not the next course,‚Äô the Knight said in a slow thoughtful tone: ‚Äòno, certainly not the next course.‚Äô
‚ÄòThen it would have to be the next day. I suppose you wouldn‚Äôt have two pudding-courses in one dinner?‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, not the next day,‚Äô the Knight repeated as before: ‚Äònot the next day. In fact,‚Äô he went on, holding his head down, and his voice getting lower and lower, ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt believe that pudding ever was cooked! In fact, I don‚Äôt believe that pudding ever will be cooked! And yet it was a very clever pudding to invent.‚Äô
‚ÄòWhat did you mean it to be made of?‚Äô Alice asked, hoping to cheer him up, for the poor Knight seemed quite low-spirited about it.
‚ÄòIt began with blotting paper,‚Äô the Knight answered with a groan.
‚ÄòThat wouldn‚Äôt be very nice, I‚Äôm afraid‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòNot very nice alone,‚Äô he interrupted, quite eagerly: ‚Äòbut you‚Äôve no idea what a difference it makes mixing it with other things‚Äîsuch as gunpowder and sealing-wax. And here I must leave you.‚Äô They had just come to the end of the wood.
Alice could only look puzzled: she was thinking of the pudding.
‚ÄòYou are sad,‚Äô the Knight said in an anxious tone: ‚Äòlet me sing you a song to comfort you.‚Äô
‚ÄòIs it very long?‚Äô Alice asked, for she had heard a good deal of poetry that day.
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs long,‚Äô said the Knight, ‚Äòbut very, very beautiful. Everybody that hears me sing it‚Äîeither it brings the tears into their eyes, or else‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòOr else what?‚Äô said Alice, for the Knight had made a sudden pause.
‚ÄòOr else it doesn‚Äôt, you know. The name of the song is called ‚ÄúHaddocks‚Äô Eyes.‚Äù‚Äô
‚ÄòOh, that‚Äôs the name of the song, is it?‚Äô Alice said, trying to feel interested.
‚ÄòNo, you don‚Äôt understand,‚Äô the Knight said, looking a little vexed. ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs what the name is called. The name really is ‚ÄúThe Aged Aged Man.‚Äù‚Äô
‚ÄòThen I ought to have said ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what the song is called‚Äù?‚Äô Alice corrected herself.
‚ÄòNo, you oughtn‚Äôt: that‚Äôs quite another thing! The song is called ‚ÄúWays and Means‚Äù: but that‚Äôs only what it‚Äôs called, you know!‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, what is the song, then?‚Äô said Alice, who was by this time completely bewildered.
‚ÄòI was coming to that,‚Äô the Knight said. ‚ÄòThe song really is ‚ÄúA-sitting On A Gate‚Äù: and the tune‚Äôs my own invention.‚Äô
So saying, he stopped his horse and let the reins fall on its neck: then, slowly beating time with one hand, and with a faint smile lighting up his gentle foolish face, as if he enjoyed the music of his song, he began.
Of all the strange things that Alice saw in her journey Through The Looking-Glass, this was the one that she always remembered most clearly. Years afterwards she could bring the whole scene back again, as if it had been only yesterday‚Äîthe mild blue eyes and kindly smile of the Knight‚Äîthe setting sun gleaming through his hair, and shining on his armour in a blaze of light that quite dazzled her‚Äîthe horse quietly moving about, with the reins hanging loose on his neck, cropping the grass at her feet‚Äîand the black shadows of the forest behind‚Äîall this she took in like a picture, as, with one hand shading her eyes, she leant against a tree, watching the strange pair, and listening, in a half dream, to the melancholy music of the song.
‚ÄòBut the tune isn‚Äôt his own invention,‚Äô she said to herself: ‚Äòit‚Äôs ‚ÄúI give thee all, I can no more.‚Äù‚Äô She stood and listened very attentively, but no tears came into her eyes.
‚ÄòI‚Äôll tell thee everything I can; There‚Äôs little to relate. I saw an aged aged man, A-sitting on a gate. ‚ÄúWho are you, aged man?‚Äù I said, ‚Äúand how is it you live?‚Äù And his answer trickled through my head Like water through a sieve.
He said ‚ÄúI look for butterflies That sleep among the wheat: I make them into mutton-pies, And sell them in the street. I sell them unto men,‚Äù he said, ‚ÄúWho sail on stormy seas; And that‚Äôs the way I get my bread‚Äî A trifle, if you please.‚Äù
But I was thinking of a plan To dye one‚Äôs whiskers green, And always use so large a fan That they could not be seen. So, having no reply to give To what the old man said, I cried, ‚ÄúCome, tell me how you live!‚Äù And thumped him on the head.
His accents mild took up the tale: He said ‚ÄúI go my ways, And when I find a mountain-rill, I set it in a blaze; And thence they make a stuff they call Rolands‚Äô Macassar Oil‚Äî Yet twopence-halfpenny is all They give me for my toil.‚Äù
But I was thinking of a way To feed oneself on batter, And so go on from day to day Getting a little fatter. I shook him well from side to side, Until his face was blue: ‚ÄúCome, tell me how you live,‚Äù I cried, ‚ÄúAnd what it is you do!‚Äù
He said ‚ÄúI hunt for haddocks‚Äô eyes Among the heather bright, And work them into waistcoat-buttons In the silent night. And these I do not sell for gold Or coin of silvery shine But for a copper halfpenny, And that will purchase nine.
‚ÄúI sometimes dig for buttered rolls, Or set limed twigs for crabs; I sometimes search the grassy knolls For wheels of Hansom-cabs. And that‚Äôs the way‚Äù (he gave a wink) ‚ÄúBy which I get my wealth‚Äî And very gladly will I drink Your Honour‚Äôs noble health.‚Äù
