I heard him then, for I had just Completed my design To keep the Menai bridge from rust By boiling it in wine. I thanked him much for telling me The way he got his wealth, But chiefly for his wish that he Might drink my noble health.
And now, if e‚Äôer by chance I put My fingers into glue Or madly squeeze a right-hand foot Into a left-hand shoe, Or if I drop upon my toe A very heavy weight, I weep, for it reminds me so, Of that old man I used to know‚Äî
Whose look was mild, whose speech was slow, Whose hair was whiter than the snow, Whose face was very like a crow, With eyes, like cinders, all aglow, Who seemed distracted with his woe, Who rocked his body to and fro, And muttered mumblingly and low, As if his mouth were full of dough, Who snorted like a buffalo‚Äî That summer evening, long ago, A-sitting on a gate.‚Äô
As the Knight sang the last words of the ballad, he gathered up the reins, and turned his horse‚Äôs head along the road by which they had come. ‚ÄòYou‚Äôve only a few yards to go,‚Äô he said, ‚Äòdown the hill and over that little brook, and then you‚Äôll be a Queen‚ÄîBut you‚Äôll stay and see me off first?‚Äô he added as Alice turned with an eager look in the direction to which he pointed. ‚ÄòI shan‚Äôt be long. You‚Äôll wait and wave your handkerchief when I get to that turn in the road? I think it‚Äôll encourage me, you see.‚Äô
‚ÄòOf course I‚Äôll wait,‚Äô said Alice: ‚Äòand thank you very much for coming so far‚Äîand for the song‚ÄîI liked it very much.‚Äô
‚ÄòI hope so,‚Äô the Knight said doubtfully: ‚Äòbut you didn‚Äôt cry so much as I thought you would.‚Äô
So they shook hands, and then the Knight rode slowly away into the forest. ‚ÄòIt won‚Äôt take long to see him off, I expect,‚Äô Alice said to herself, as she stood watching him. ‚ÄòThere he goes! Right on his head as usual! However, he gets on again pretty easily‚Äîthat comes of having so many things hung round the horse‚Äî‚Äô So she went on talking to herself, as she watched the horse walking leisurely along the road, and the Knight tumbling off, first on one side and then on the other. After the fourth or fifth tumble he reached the turn, and then she waved her handkerchief to him, and waited till he was out of sight.
‚ÄòI hope it encouraged him,‚Äô she said, as she turned to run down the hill: ‚Äòand now for the last brook, and to be a Queen! How grand it sounds!‚Äô A very few steps brought her to the edge of the brook. ‚ÄòThe Eighth Square at last!‚Äô she cried as she bounded across,
* * * *
* * *
* * * *
and threw herself down to rest on a lawn as soft as moss, with little flower-beds dotted about it here and there. ‚ÄòOh, how glad I am to get here! And what is this on my head?‚Äô she exclaimed in a tone of dismay, as she put her hands up to something very heavy, and fitted tight all round her head.
‚ÄòBut how can it have got there without my knowing it?‚Äô she said to herself, as she lifted it off, and set it on her lap to make out what it could possibly be.
It was a golden crown.

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter 9 - Queen Alice

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice becomes a queen and attends a chaotic dinner party with the Red and White Queens. The party is filled with nonsensical events and surreal occurrences. Alice struggles to maintain order among the guests.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
Upon reaching the eighth square in DaSCHland, Alice was transformed into a queen and welcomed to a bizarre banquet, crafted by the DaSCH repository's digital magic. The banquet hall was filled with surreal, animated dishes and eccentric guests, where even the food engaged in conversation.
Guided by RabbitIT, Alice navigated the whimsical feast, marveling at the fantastical elements and the playful overturning of typical banquet norms. This chapter showcased her enjoyment and curiosity as she embraced her new role in this imaginative, topsy-turvy celebration.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
‚ÄòWell, this is grand!‚Äô said Alice. ‚ÄòI never expected I should be a Queen so soon‚Äîand I‚Äôll tell you what it is, your majesty,‚Äô she went on in a severe tone (she was always rather fond of scolding herself), ‚Äòit‚Äôll never do for you to be lolling about on the grass like that! Queens have to be dignified, you know!‚Äô
So she got up and walked about‚Äîrather stiffly just at first, as she was afraid that the crown might come off: but she comforted herself with the thought that there was nobody to see her, ‚Äòand if I really am a Queen,‚Äô she said as she sat down again, ‚ÄòI shall be able to manage it quite well in time.‚Äô
Everything was happening so oddly that she didn‚Äôt feel a bit surprised at finding the Red Queen and the White Queen sitting close to her, one on each side: she would have liked very much to ask them how they came there, but she feared it would not be quite civil. However, there would be no harm, she thought, in asking if the game was over. ‚ÄòPlease, would you tell me‚Äî‚Äô she began, looking timidly at the Red Queen.
‚ÄòSpeak when you‚Äôre spoken to!‚Äô The Queen sharply interrupted her.
‚ÄòBut if everybody obeyed that rule,‚Äô said Alice, who was always ready for a little argument, ‚Äòand if you only spoke when you were spoken to, and the other person always waited for you to begin, you see nobody would ever say anything, so that‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòRidiculous!‚Äô cried the Queen. ‚ÄòWhy, don‚Äôt you see, child‚Äî‚Äô here she broke off with a frown, and, after thinking for a minute, suddenly changed the subject of the conversation. ‚ÄòWhat do you mean by ‚ÄúIf you really are a Queen‚Äù? What right have you to call yourself so? You can‚Äôt be a Queen, you know, till you‚Äôve passed the proper examination. And the sooner we begin it, the better.‚Äô
‚ÄòI only said ‚Äúif‚Äù!‚Äô poor Alice pleaded in a piteous tone.
The two Queens looked at each other, and the Red Queen remarked, with a little shudder, ‚ÄòShe says she only said ‚Äúif‚Äù‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòBut she said a great deal more than that!‚Äô the White Queen moaned, wringing her hands. ‚ÄòOh, ever so much more than that!‚Äô
‚ÄòSo you did, you know,‚Äô the Red Queen said to Alice. ‚ÄòAlways speak the truth‚Äîthink before you speak‚Äîand write it down afterwards.‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôm sure I didn‚Äôt mean‚Äî‚Äô Alice was beginning, but the Red Queen interrupted her impatiently.
‚ÄòThat‚Äôs just what I complain of! You should have meant! What do you suppose is the use of child without any meaning? Even a joke should have some meaning‚Äîand a child‚Äôs more important than a joke, I hope. You couldn‚Äôt deny that, even if you tried with both hands.‚Äô
‚ÄòI don‚Äôt deny things with my hands,‚Äô Alice objected.
‚ÄòNobody said you did,‚Äô said the Red Queen. ‚ÄòI said you couldn‚Äôt if you tried.‚Äô
‚ÄòShe‚Äôs in that state of mind,‚Äô said the White Queen, ‚Äòthat she wants to deny something‚Äîonly she doesn‚Äôt know what to deny!‚Äô
‚ÄòA nasty, vicious temper,‚Äô the Red Queen remarked; and then there was an uncomfortable silence for a minute or two.
The Red Queen broke the silence by saying to the White Queen, ‚ÄòI invite you to Alice‚Äôs dinner-party this afternoon.‚Äô
The White Queen smiled feebly, and said ‚ÄòAnd I invite you.‚Äô
‚ÄòI didn‚Äôt know I was to have a party at all,‚Äô said Alice; ‚Äòbut if there is to be one, I think I ought to invite the guests.‚Äô
‚ÄòWe gave you the opportunity of doing it,‚Äô the Red Queen remarked: ‚Äòbut I daresay you‚Äôve not had many lessons in manners yet?‚Äô
‚ÄòManners are not taught in lessons,‚Äô said Alice. ‚ÄòLessons teach you to do sums, and things of that sort.‚Äô
‚ÄòAnd you do Addition?‚Äô the White Queen asked. ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs one and one and one and one and one and one and one and one and one and one?‚Äô
‚ÄòI don‚Äôt know,‚Äô said Alice. ‚ÄòI lost count.‚Äô
‚ÄòShe can‚Äôt do Addition,‚Äô the Red Queen interrupted. ‚ÄòCan you do Subtraction? Take nine from eight.‚Äô
‚ÄòNine from eight I can‚Äôt, you know,‚Äô Alice replied very readily: ‚Äòbut‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòShe can‚Äôt do Subtraction,‚Äô said the White Queen. ‚ÄòCan you do Division? Divide a loaf by a knife‚Äîwhat‚Äôs the answer to that?‚Äô
‚ÄòI suppose‚Äî‚Äô Alice was beginning, but the Red Queen answered for her. ‚ÄòBread-and-butter, of course. Try another Subtraction sum. Take a bone from a dog: what remains?‚Äô
Alice considered. ‚ÄòThe bone wouldn‚Äôt remain, of course, if I took it‚Äîand the dog wouldn‚Äôt remain; it would come to bite me‚Äîand I‚Äôm sure I shouldn‚Äôt remain!‚Äô
‚ÄòThen you think nothing would remain?‚Äô said the Red Queen.
‚ÄòI think that‚Äôs the answer.‚Äô
‚ÄòWrong, as usual,‚Äô said the Red Queen: ‚Äòthe dog‚Äôs temper would remain.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut I don‚Äôt see how‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòWhy, look here!‚Äô the Red Queen cried. ‚ÄòThe dog would lose its temper, wouldn‚Äôt it?‚Äô
‚ÄòPerhaps it would,‚Äô Alice replied cautiously.
‚ÄòThen if the dog went away, its temper would remain!‚Äô the Queen exclaimed triumphantly.
Alice said, as gravely as she could, ‚ÄòThey might go different ways.‚Äô But she couldn‚Äôt help thinking to herself, ‚ÄòWhat dreadful nonsense we are talking!‚Äô
‚ÄòShe can‚Äôt do sums a bit!‚Äô the Queens said together, with great emphasis.
‚ÄòCan you do sums?‚Äô Alice said, turning suddenly on the White Queen, for she didn‚Äôt like being found fault with so much.
The Queen gasped and shut her eyes. ‚ÄòI can do Addition, if you give me time‚Äîbut I can‚Äôt do Subtraction, under any circumstances!‚Äô
‚ÄòOf course you know your A B C?‚Äô said the Red Queen.
‚ÄòTo be sure I do.‚Äô said Alice.
‚ÄòSo do I,‚Äô the White Queen whispered: ‚Äòwe‚Äôll often say it over together, dear. And I‚Äôll tell you a secret‚ÄîI can read words of one letter! Isn‚Äôt that grand! However, don‚Äôt be discouraged. You‚Äôll come to it in time.‚Äô
Here the Red Queen began again. ‚ÄòCan you answer useful questions?‚Äô she said. ‚ÄòHow is bread made?‚Äô
‚ÄòI know that!‚Äô Alice cried eagerly. ‚ÄòYou take some flour‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòWhere do you pick the flower?‚Äô the White Queen asked. ‚ÄòIn a garden, or in the hedges?‚Äô
‚ÄòWell, it isn‚Äôt picked at all,‚Äô Alice explained: ‚Äòit‚Äôs ground‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòHow many acres of ground?‚Äô said the White Queen. ‚ÄòYou mustn‚Äôt leave out so many things.‚Äô
‚ÄòFan her head!‚Äô the Red Queen anxiously interrupted. ‚ÄòShe‚Äôll be feverish after so much thinking.‚Äô So they set to work and fanned her with bunches of leaves, till she had to beg them to leave off, it blew her hair about so.
‚ÄòShe‚Äôs all right again now,‚Äô said the Red Queen. ‚ÄòDo you know Languages? What‚Äôs the French for fiddle-de-dee?‚Äô
‚ÄòFiddle-de-dee‚Äôs not English,‚Äô Alice replied gravely.
‚ÄòWho ever said it was?‚Äô said the Red Queen.
Alice thought she saw a way out of the difficulty this time. ‚ÄòIf you‚Äôll tell me what language ‚Äúfiddle-de-dee‚Äù is, I‚Äôll tell you the French for it!‚Äô she exclaimed triumphantly.
But the Red Queen drew herself up rather stiffly, and said ‚ÄòQueens never make bargains.‚Äô
‚ÄòI wish Queens never asked questions,‚Äô Alice thought to herself.
‚ÄòDon‚Äôt let us quarrel,‚Äô the White Queen said in an anxious tone. ‚ÄòWhat is the cause of lightning?‚Äô
‚ÄòThe cause of lightning,‚Äô Alice said very decidedly, for she felt quite certain about this, ‚Äòis the thunder‚Äîno, no!‚Äô she hastily corrected herself. ‚ÄòI meant the other way.‚Äô
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs too late to correct it,‚Äô said the Red Queen: ‚Äòwhen you‚Äôve once said a thing, that fixes it, and you must take the consequences.‚Äô
‚ÄòWhich reminds me‚Äî‚Äô the White Queen said, looking down and nervously clasping and unclasping her hands, ‚Äòwe had such a thunderstorm last Tuesday‚ÄîI mean one of the last set of Tuesdays, you know.‚Äô
Alice was puzzled. ‚ÄòIn our country,‚Äô she remarked, ‚Äòthere‚Äôs only one day at a time.‚Äô
The Red Queen said, ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs a poor thin way of doing things. Now here, we mostly have days and nights two or three at a time, and sometimes in the winter we take as many as five nights together‚Äîfor warmth, you know.‚Äô
‚ÄòAre five nights warmer than one night, then?‚Äô Alice ventured to ask.
‚ÄòFive times as warm, of course.‚Äô
‚ÄòBut they should be five times as cold, by the same rule‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòJust so!‚Äô cried the Red Queen. ‚ÄòFive times as warm, and five times as cold‚Äîjust as I‚Äôm five times as rich as you are, and five times as clever!‚Äô
Alice sighed and gave it up. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs exactly like a riddle with no answer!‚Äô she thought.
‚ÄòHumpty Dumpty saw it too,‚Äô the White Queen went on in a low voice, more as if she were talking to herself. ‚ÄòHe came to the door with a corkscrew in his hand‚Äî‚Äô
‚ÄòWhat did he want?‚Äô said the Red Queen.
‚ÄòHe said he would come in,‚Äô the White Queen went on, ‚Äòbecause he was looking for a hippopotamus. Now, as it happened, there wasn‚Äôt such a thing in the house, that morning.‚Äô
‚ÄòIs there generally?‚Äô Alice asked in an astonished tone.
‚ÄòWell, only on Thursdays,‚Äô said the Queen.
‚ÄòI know what he came for,‚Äô said Alice: ‚Äòhe wanted to punish the fish, because‚Äî‚Äô
Here the White Queen began again. ‚ÄòIt was such a thunderstorm, you can‚Äôt think!‚Äô (‚ÄòShe never could, you know,‚Äô said the Red Queen.) ‚ÄòAnd part of the roof came off, and ever so much thunder got in‚Äîand it went rolling round the room in great lumps‚Äîand knocking over the tables and things‚Äîtill I was so frightened, I couldn‚Äôt remember my own name!‚Äô
Alice thought to herself, ‚ÄòI never should try to remember my name in the middle of an accident! Where would be the use of it?‚Äô but she did not say this aloud, for fear of hurting the poor Queen‚Äôs feeling.
‚ÄòYour Majesty must excuse her,‚Äô the Red Queen said to Alice, taking one of the White Queen‚Äôs hands in her own, and gently stroking it: ‚Äòshe means well, but she can‚Äôt help saying foolish things, as a general rule.‚Äô
The White Queen looked timidly at Alice, who felt she ought to say something kind, but really couldn‚Äôt think of anything at the moment.
‚ÄòShe never was really well brought up,‚Äô the Red Queen went on: ‚Äòbut it‚Äôs amazing how good-tempered she is! Pat her on the head, and see how pleased she‚Äôll be!‚Äô But this was more than Alice had courage to do.
‚ÄòA little kindness‚Äîand putting her hair in papers‚Äîwould do wonders with her‚Äî‚Äô
The White Queen gave a deep sigh, and laid her head on Alice‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄòI am so sleepy?‚Äô she moaned.
‚ÄòShe‚Äôs tired, poor thing!‚Äô said the Red Queen. ‚ÄòSmooth her hair‚Äîlend her your nightcap‚Äîand sing her a soothing lullaby.‚Äô
‚ÄòI haven‚Äôt got a nightcap with me,‚Äô said Alice, as she tried to obey the first direction: ‚Äòand I don‚Äôt know any soothing lullabies.‚Äô
‚ÄòI must do it myself, then,‚Äô said the Red Queen, and she began:
‚ÄòHush-a-by lady, in Alice‚Äôs lap! Till the feast‚Äôs ready, we‚Äôve time for a nap: When the feast‚Äôs over, we‚Äôll go to the ball‚Äî Red Queen, and White Queen, and Alice, and all!
‚ÄòAnd now you know the words,‚Äô she added, as she put her head down on Alice‚Äôs other shoulder, ‚Äòjust sing it through to me. I‚Äôm getting sleepy, too.‚Äô In another moment both Queens were fast asleep, and snoring loud.
‚ÄòWhat am I to do?‚Äô exclaimed Alice, looking about in great perplexity, as first one round head, and then the other, rolled down from her shoulder, and lay like a heavy lump in her lap. ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt think it ever happened before, that any one had to take care of two Queens asleep at once! No, not in all the History of England‚Äîit couldn‚Äôt, you know, because there never was more than one Queen at a time. Do wake up, you heavy things!‚Äô she went on in an impatient tone; but there was no answer but a gentle snoring.
The snoring got more distinct every minute, and sounded more like a tune: at last she could even make out the words, and she listened so eagerly that, when the two great heads vanished from her lap, she hardly missed them.
She was standing before an arched doorway over which were the words QUEEN ALICE in large letters, and on each side of the arch there was a bell-handle; one was marked ‚ÄòVisitors‚Äô Bell,‚Äô and the other ‚ÄòServants‚Äô Bell.‚Äô
‚ÄòI‚Äôll wait till the song‚Äôs over,‚Äô thought Alice, ‚Äòand then I‚Äôll ring‚Äîthe‚Äîwhich bell must I ring?‚Äô she went on, very much puzzled by the names. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm not a visitor, and I‚Äôm not a servant. There ought to be one marked ‚ÄúQueen,‚Äù you know‚Äî‚Äô
Just then the door opened a little way, and a creature with a long beak put its head out for a moment and said ‚ÄòNo admittance till the week after next!‚Äô and shut the door again with a bang.
Alice knocked and rang in vain for a long time, but at last, a very old Frog, who was sitting under a tree, got up and hobbled slowly towards her: he was dressed in bright yellow, and had enormous boots on.
‚ÄòWhat is it, now?‚Äô the Frog said in a deep hoarse whisper.
Alice turned round, ready to find fault with anybody. ‚ÄòWhere‚Äôs the servant whose business it is to answer the door?‚Äô she began angrily.
‚ÄòWhich door?‚Äô said the Frog.
Alice almost stamped with irritation at the slow drawl in which he spoke. ‚ÄòThis door, of course!‚Äô
The Frog looked at the door with his large dull eyes for a minute: then he went nearer and rubbed it with his thumb, as if he were trying whether the paint would come off; then he looked at Alice.
‚ÄòTo answer the door?‚Äô he said. ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs it been asking of?‚Äô He was so hoarse that Alice could scarcely hear him.
‚ÄòI don‚Äôt know what you mean,‚Äô she said.
‚ÄòI talks English, doesn‚Äôt I?‚Äô the Frog went on. ‚ÄòOr are you deaf? What did it ask you?‚Äô
‚ÄòNothing!‚Äô Alice said impatiently. ‚ÄòI‚Äôve been knocking at it!‚Äô
‚ÄòShouldn‚Äôt do that‚Äîshouldn‚Äôt do that‚Äî‚Äô the Frog muttered. ‚ÄòVexes it, you know.‚Äô Then he went up and gave the door a kick with one of his great feet. ‚ÄòYou let it alone,‚Äô he panted out, as he hobbled back to his tree, ‚Äòand it‚Äôll let you alone, you know.‚Äô
At this moment the door was flung open, and a shrill voice was heard singing:
‚ÄòTo the Looking-Glass world it was Alice that said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve a sceptre in hand, I‚Äôve a crown on my head; Let the Looking-Glass creatures, whatever they be, Come and dine with the Red Queen, the White Queen, and me.‚Äù‚Äô
And hundreds of voices joined in the chorus:
‚ÄòThen fill up the glasses as quick as you can, And sprinkle the table with buttons and bran: Put cats in the coffee, and mice in the tea‚Äî And welcome Queen Alice with thirty-times-three!‚Äô
Then followed a confused noise of cheering, and Alice thought to herself, ‚ÄòThirty times three makes ninety. I wonder if any one‚Äôs counting?‚Äô In a minute there was silence again, and the same shrill voice sang another verse;
‚Äò‚ÄúO Looking-Glass creatures,‚Äù quoth Alice, ‚Äúdraw near! ‚ÄòTis an honour to see me, a favour to hear: ‚ÄòTis a privilege high to have dinner and tea Along with the Red Queen, the White Queen, and me!‚Äù‚Äô
Then came the chorus again:‚Äî
‚ÄòThen fill up the glasses with treacle and ink, Or anything else that is pleasant to drink: Mix sand with the cider, and wool with the wine‚Äî And welcome Queen Alice with ninety-times-nine!‚Äô
‚ÄòNinety times nine!‚Äô Alice repeated in despair, ‚ÄòOh, that‚Äôll never be done! I‚Äôd better go in at once‚Äî‚Äô and there was a dead silence the moment she appeared.
Alice glanced nervously along the table, as she walked up the large hall, and noticed that there were about fifty guests, of all kinds: some were animals, some birds, and there were even a few flowers among them. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm glad they‚Äôve come without waiting to be asked,‚Äô she thought: ‚ÄòI should never have known who were the right people to invite!‚Äô
There were three chairs at the head of the table; the Red and White Queens had already taken two of them, but the middle one was empty. Alice sat down in it, rather uncomfortable in the silence, and longing for some one to speak.
At last the Red Queen began. ‚ÄòYou‚Äôve missed the soup and fish,‚Äô she said. ‚ÄòPut on the joint!‚Äô And the waiters set a leg of mutton before Alice, who looked at it rather anxiously, as she had never had to carve a joint before.
‚ÄòYou look a little shy; let me introduce you to that leg of mutton,‚Äô said the Red Queen. ‚ÄòAlice‚ÄîMutton; Mutton‚ÄîAlice.‚Äô The leg of mutton got up in the dish and made a little bow to Alice; and Alice returned the bow, not knowing whether to be frightened or amused.
‚ÄòMay I give you a slice?‚Äô she said, taking up the knife and fork, and looking from one Queen to the other.
‚ÄòCertainly not,‚Äô the Red Queen said, very decidedly: ‚Äòit isn‚Äôt etiquette to cut any one you‚Äôve been introduced to. Remove the joint!‚Äô And the waiters carried it off, and brought a large plum-pudding in its place.
‚ÄòI won‚Äôt be introduced to the pudding, please,‚Äô Alice said rather hastily, ‚Äòor we shall get no dinner at all. May I give you some?‚Äô
But the Red Queen looked sulky, and growled ‚ÄòPudding‚ÄîAlice; Alice‚ÄîPudding. Remove the pudding!‚Äô and the waiters took it away so quickly that Alice couldn‚Äôt return its bow.
However, she didn‚Äôt see why the Red Queen should be the only one to give orders, so, as an experiment, she called out ‚ÄòWaiter! Bring back the pudding!‚Äô and there it was again in a moment like a conjuring-trick. It was so large that she couldn‚Äôt help feeling a little shy with it, as she had been with the mutton; however, she conquered her shyness by a great effort and cut a slice and handed it to the Red Queen.
‚ÄòWhat impertinence!‚Äô said the Pudding. ‚ÄòI wonder how you‚Äôd like it, if I were to cut a slice out of you, you creature!‚Äô
It spoke in a thick, suety sort of voice, and Alice hadn‚Äôt a word to say in reply: she could only sit and look at it and gasp.
‚ÄòMake a remark,‚Äô said the Red Queen: ‚Äòit‚Äôs ridiculous to leave all the conversation to the pudding!‚Äô
‚ÄòDo you know, I‚Äôve had such a quantity of poetry repeated to me to-day,‚Äô Alice began, a little frightened at finding that, the moment she opened her lips, there was dead silence, and all eyes were fixed upon her; ‚Äòand it‚Äôs a very curious thing, I think‚Äîevery poem was about fishes in some way. Do you know why they‚Äôre so fond of fishes, all about here?‚Äô
She spoke to the Red Queen, whose answer was a little wide of the mark. ‚ÄòAs to fishes,‚Äô she said, very slowly and solemnly, putting her mouth close to Alice‚Äôs ear, ‚Äòher White Majesty knows a lovely riddle‚Äîall in poetry‚Äîall about fishes. Shall she repeat it?‚Äô
‚ÄòHer Red Majesty‚Äôs very kind to mention it,‚Äô the White Queen murmured into Alice‚Äôs other ear, in a voice like the cooing of a pigeon. ‚ÄòIt would be such a treat! May I?‚Äô
‚ÄòPlease do,‚Äô Alice said very politely.
The White Queen laughed with delight, and stroked Alice‚Äôs cheek. Then she began:
‚Äò‚ÄúFirst, the fish must be caught.‚Äù That is easy: a baby, I think, could have caught it. ‚ÄúNext, the fish must be bought.‚Äù That is easy: a penny, I think, would have bought it.
‚ÄúNow cook me the fish!‚Äù That is easy, and will not take more than a minute. ‚ÄúLet it lie in a dish!‚Äù That is easy, because it already is in it.
‚ÄúBring it here! Let me sup!‚Äù It is easy to set such a dish on the table. ‚ÄúTake the dish-cover up!‚Äù Ah, that is so hard that I fear I‚Äôm unable!
For it holds it like glue‚Äî Holds the lid to the dish, while it lies in the middle: Which is easiest to do, Un-dish-cover the fish, or dishcover the riddle?‚Äô
‚ÄòTake a minute to think about it, and then guess,‚Äô said the Red Queen. ‚ÄòMeanwhile, we‚Äôll drink your health‚ÄîQueen Alice‚Äôs health!‚Äô she screamed at the top of her voice, and all the guests began drinking it directly, and very queerly they managed it: some of them put their glasses upon their heads like extinguishers, and drank all that trickled down their faces‚Äîothers upset the decanters, and drank the wine as it ran off the edges of the table‚Äîand three of them (who looked like kangaroos) scrambled into the dish of roast mutton, and began eagerly lapping up the gravy, ‚Äòjust like pigs in a trough!‚Äô thought Alice.
‚ÄòYou ought to return thanks in a neat speech,‚Äô the Red Queen said, frowning at Alice as she spoke.
‚ÄòWe must support you, you know,‚Äô the White Queen whispered, as Alice got up to do it, very obediently, but a little frightened.
‚ÄòThank you very much,‚Äô she whispered in reply, ‚Äòbut I can do quite well without.‚Äô
‚ÄòThat wouldn‚Äôt be at all the thing,‚Äô the Red Queen said very decidedly: so Alice tried to submit to it with a good grace.
(‚ÄòAnd they did push so!‚Äô she said afterwards, when she was telling her sister the history of the feast. ‚ÄòYou would have thought they wanted to squeeze me flat!‚Äô)
In fact it was rather difficult for her to keep in her place while she made her speech: the two Queens pushed her so, one on each side, that they nearly lifted her up into the air: ‚ÄòI rise to return thanks‚Äî‚Äô Alice began: and she really did rise as she spoke, several inches; but she got hold of the edge of the table, and managed to pull herself down again.
‚ÄòTake care of yourself!‚Äô screamed the White Queen, seizing Alice‚Äôs hair with both her hands. ‚ÄòSomething‚Äôs going to happen!‚Äô
And then (as Alice afterwards described it) all sorts of things happened in a moment. The candles all grew up to the ceiling, looking something like a bed of rushes with fireworks at the top. As to the bottles, they each took a pair of plates, which they hastily fitted on as wings, and so, with forks for legs, went fluttering about in all directions: ‚Äòand very like birds they look,‚Äô Alice thought to herself, as well as she could in the dreadful confusion that was beginning.
At this moment she heard a hoarse laugh at her side, and turned to see what was the matter with the White Queen; but, instead of the Queen, there was the leg of mutton sitting in the chair. ‚ÄòHere I am!‚Äô cried a voice from the soup tureen, and Alice turned again, just in time to see the Queen‚Äôs broad good-natured face grinning at her for a moment over the edge of the tureen, before she disappeared into the soup.
There was not a moment to be lost. Already several of the guests were lying down in the dishes, and the soup ladle was walking up the table towards Alice‚Äôs chair, and beckoning to her impatiently to get out of its way.
‚ÄòI can‚Äôt stand this any longer!‚Äô she cried as she jumped up and seized the table-cloth with both hands: one good pull, and plates, dishes, guests, and candles came crashing down together in a heap on the floor.
‚ÄòAnd as for you,‚Äô she went on, turning fiercely upon the Red Queen, whom she considered as the cause of all the mischief‚Äîbut the Queen was no longer at her side‚Äîshe had suddenly dwindled down to the size of a little doll, and was now on the table, merrily running round and round after her own shawl, which was trailing behind her.
At any other time, Alice would have felt surprised at this, but she was far too much excited to be surprised at anything now. ‚ÄòAs for you,‚Äô she repeated, catching hold of the little creature in the very act of jumping over a bottle which had just lighted upon the table, ‚ÄòI‚Äôll shake you into a kitten, that I will!‚Äô

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter 10 - Shaking

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The chaos at the dinner party escalates. Alice seizes the Red Queen, who transforms into her kitten. The surreal events start to break apart as Alice begins to wake up.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In the whimsical world of DaSCHland, Alice engaged in a nonsensical conversation with the Red and White Queens, characters brought to vibrant life by the DaSCH repository. Their dialogue twisted logic and language in playful, perplexing ways.
As the conversation spiraled into delightful absurdity, the Queens proposed a quiz, posing riddles and paradoxes that tested Alice's wit and adaptability. Guided by RabbitIT, Alice navigated the quiz with clever responses, each answer revealing deeper layers of the digital realm's literary nuances.
This chapter highlighted Alice's quick thinking and the interactive nature of DaSCHland, where literary figures become engaging tutors in a game of wits and wisdom.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
She took her off the table as she spoke, and shook her backwards and forwards with all her might.
The Red Queen made no resistance whatever; only her face grew very small, and her eyes got large and green: and still, as Alice went on shaking her, she kept on growing shorter‚Äîand fatter‚Äîand softer‚Äîand rounder‚Äîand‚Äî

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter 11 - Waking

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Alice wakes up to find herself back at home, holding her black kitten. She realizes that her adventure in the looking-glass world was just a dream.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
As the banquet in DaSCHland grew increasingly chaotic, Alice found herself overwhelmed by the surreal antics of the guests and the peculiar, animated dishes. Her patience worn thin, she reached out in frustration and grabbed the Red Queen. In a moment of digital magic typical of DaSCHland, powered by the creative algorithms of the DaSCH repository, the Red Queen transformed into a kitten in Alice's arms.
This unexpected transformation added to the whimsy and confusion of the scene, as Alice suddenly held a purring kitten instead of the formidable queen. The episode underscored the fluidity and unpredictability of DaSCHland, where characters and elements could shift forms in surprising ways, enhancing Alice's adventure in this digital wonderland.

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter 12 - Which dreamed it?

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The final chapter reflects on the nature of Alice's dream and the curious question of whether it was Alice dreaming of the looking-glass world or the characters in the looking-glass world dreaming of Alice.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: Alice awoke from the chaotic banquet to find herself not in DaSCHland, but in her own room, with a kitten purring on her lap. The digital world of quirky characters and surreal transformations had all been a vivid dream. This realization brought a comforting end to her whimsical journey, blurring the lines between fantasy and reality as she greeted the calm of her familiar surroundings.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
‚ÄòYour majesty shouldn‚Äôt purr so loud,‚Äô Alice said, rubbing her eyes, and addressing the kitten, respectfully, yet with some severity. ‚ÄòYou woke me out of oh! such a nice dream! And you‚Äôve been along with me, Kitty‚Äîall through the Looking-Glass world. Did you know it, dear?‚Äô
It is a very inconvenient habit of kittens (Alice had once made the remark) that, whatever you say to them, they always purr. ‚ÄòIf they would only purr for ‚Äúyes‚Äù and mew for ‚Äúno,‚Äù or any rule of that sort,‚Äô she had said, ‚Äòso that one could keep up a conversation! But how can you talk with a person if they always say the same thing?‚Äô
On this occasion the kitten only purred: and it was impossible to guess whether it meant ‚Äòyes‚Äô or ‚Äòno.‚Äô
So Alice hunted among the chessmen on the table till she had found the Red Queen: then she went down on her knees on the hearth-rug, and put the kitten and the Queen to look at each other. ‚ÄòNow, Kitty!‚Äô she cried, clapping her hands triumphantly. ‚ÄòConfess that was what you turned into!‚Äô
(‚ÄòBut it wouldn‚Äôt look at it,‚Äô she said, when she was explaining the thing afterwards to her sister: ‚Äòit turned away its head, and pretended not to see it: but it looked a little ashamed of itself, so I think it must have been the Red Queen.‚Äô)
‚ÄòSit up a little more stiffly, dear!‚Äô Alice cried with a merry laugh. ‚ÄòAnd curtsey while you‚Äôre thinking what to‚Äîwhat to purr. It saves time, remember!‚Äô And she caught it up and gave it one little kiss, ‚Äòjust in honour of having been a Red Queen.‚Äô
‚ÄòSnowdrop, my pet!‚Äô she went on, looking over her shoulder at the White Kitten, which was still patiently undergoing its toilet, ‚Äòwhen will Dinah have finished with your White Majesty, I wonder? That must be the reason you were so untidy in my dream‚ÄîDinah! do you know that you‚Äôre scrubbing a White Queen? Really, it‚Äôs most disrespectful of you!
‚ÄòAnd what did Dinah turn to, I wonder?‚Äô she prattled on, as she settled comfortably down, with one elbow in the rug, and her chin in her hand, to watch the kittens. ‚ÄòTell me, Dinah, did you turn to Humpty Dumpty? I think you did‚Äîhowever, you‚Äôd better not mention it to your friends just yet, for I‚Äôm not sure.
‚ÄòBy the way, Kitty, if only you‚Äôd been really with me in my dream, there was one thing you would have enjoyed‚ÄîI had such a quantity of poetry said to me, all about fishes! To-morrow morning you shall have a real treat. All the time you‚Äôre eating your breakfast, I‚Äôll repeat ‚ÄúThe Walrus and the Carpenter‚Äù to you; and then you can make believe it‚Äôs oysters, dear!
‚ÄòNow, Kitty, let‚Äôs consider who it was that dreamed it all. This is a serious question, my dear, and you should not go on licking your paw like that‚Äîas if Dinah hadn‚Äôt washed you this morning! You see, Kitty, it must have been either me or the Red King. He was part of my dream, of course‚Äîbut then I was part of his dream, too! Was it the Red King, Kitty? You were his wife, my dear, so you ought to know‚ÄîOh, Kitty, do help to settle it! I‚Äôm sure your paw can wait!‚Äô But the provoking kitten only began on the other paw, and pretended it hadn‚Äôt heard the question.
Which do you think it was?

resource.label: Through the Looking-Glass and what Alice found there - Chapter nan - Poem: ‚ÄúA boat beneath a sunny sky‚Äù

text-prop.name: :hasName
text-prop.text: Poem: ‚ÄúA boat beneath a sunny sky‚Äù

text-prop.name: :hasDescription

text.comment: The poem has no chapter number because it does not belong to the story. It was placed at the end of the first edition of Through the Looking glass and what Alice found there.

text-prop.text:
The poem "A boat beneath a sunny sky" serves as an epilogue to Lewis Carroll's "Through the Looking Glass."
This poignant and reflective piece captures the ephemeral nature of childhood and the bittersweet passage of time. Carroll reminisces about idyllic days spent in the company of Alice Liddell, the muse for his stories, and the magical moments of storytelling that once were. The poem's melancholic tone juxtaposes the sunny, carefree imagery of youth with the inevitable changes that come with growing up. Through this lyrical farewell, Carroll encapsulates the essence of his nostalgic longing and the enduring charm of Alice's adventures, leaving readers with a sense of wistful reflection.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
The poem "A Stream beneath a Digital Sky" serves as an epilogue to Alice in DaSCHland.
This reflective and poignant piece captures the fleeting nature of digital creations and the ever-evolving landscape of technology. The creators reminisce about the early days of coding and digital exploration, where every project was a new adventure, full of discovery and endless possibility. The poem's tone shifts from the initial excitement of innovation to a gentle reminder of the inevitable progression of data and systems. Through this final lyrical note, the creators leave the users with a sense of nostalgia and reflection, while celebrating the enduring charm and significance of Alice's digital journey.

text-prop.name: :hasFullText
text-prop.text:
A boat beneath a sunny sky, Lingering onward dreamily In an evening of July ‚Äî
Children three that nestle near, Eager eye and willing ear, Pleased a simple tale to hear ‚Äî
Long had paled that sunny sky: Echoes fade and memories die. Autumn frosts have slain July.
Still she haunts me, phantomwise, Alice moving under skies Never seen by waking eyes.
Children yet, the tale to hear, Eager eye and willing ear, Lovingly shall nestle near.
In a Wonderland they lie, Dreaming as the days go by, Dreaming as the summers die:
Ever drifting down the stream ‚Äî Lingering in the golden gleam ‚Äî Life, what is it but a dream?
THE END

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text:
Alice is a young English girl. She is the main protagonist of Alice‚Äôs Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass and What Alice Found There. She is a curious, imaginative, and bold young girl who finds herself in bizarre, dreamlike worlds filled with nonsense and eccentric characters.
Alice is a seven-year-old girl in Alice‚Äôs Adventures in Wonderland and slightly older in Through the Looking-Glass. She follows the White Rabbit down a rabbit hole, leading her into Wonderland, where she experiences strange adventures and meets absurd characters. In the Looking-Glass world, she plays through a giant chess game, moving from pawn to queen.
The beautiful pictures of Alice, drawn by John Tenniel, were inspired by Mary Hilton Badcock, the daughter of the Dean of Ripon. Although she was suggested as a model, it's not clear if Tenniel fully took this suggestion. (source: alice-in-wonderland.net)

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: In the digital wonderland of DaSCHland, Alice is portrayed as a young, curious explorer, navigating a world where data and reality merge seamlessly. Her character embodies the spirit of inquiry and adaptability, always ready to engage with the shifting landscapes and eclectic characters of DaSCHland. With her bright, inquisitive mind, she delves into each encounter, whether it's solving riddles with the White Queen, dancing at a bizarre banquet, or decoding the peculiar logic of Humpty Dumpty. Alice's journey through DaSCHland highlights her growth from mere curiosity to a deeper understanding of how technology can bring literary worlds to life, showcasing her as a bridge between classic tales and modern digital exploration.

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text:
The White Rabbit is a nervous, hurried character who serves as Alice‚Äôs initial guide into Wonderland. He is first seen checking his pocket watch and exclaiming, ‚ÄúOh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!‚Äù before disappearing down the rabbit hole. He works as a servant for the Queen of Hearts and is terrified of her temper. He mistakes Alice for his housemaid, Mary Ann, in Chapter 4 and panics when she grows giant inside his house.
The White Rabbit is always late, which is a nod to Oxford time. At Oxford, especially at Christ Church, where Carroll used to teach, events often start five minutes after the scheduled hour. (source: alice-in-wonderland.net)

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: In DaSCHland, RabbitIT embodies a reimagined version of the classic White Rabbit from "Alice in Wonderland." This character merges the traditional traits of urgency and meticulous timing with advanced technological features. RabbitIT, as Alice's digital guide, is integral to navigating the complex and layered world of DaSCHland. Equipped with AI-driven capabilities, RabbitIT assists Alice by providing real-time data, historical insights, and logistical support throughout her adventures. His appearance retains the iconic elements‚Äîsuch as the waistcoat and pocket watch‚Äîbut these are enhanced with digital displays and interfaces that reflect his role as a guide within a sophisticated, data-rich environment. RabbitIT not only leads Alice through various digital landscapes but also ensures she engages deeply with the literary worlds recreated and stored within the DaSCH repository, making him a pivotal character in blending classic literature with modern technology.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be too late!

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text:
The Caterpillar is a calm, philosophical, and slightly rude blue creature who smokes a hookah while speaking with Alice. He questions Alice‚Äôs identity, repeatedly asking, ‚ÄúWho are you?‚Äù, which confuses her. He gives cryptic advice, telling Alice that eating different parts of a mushroom will make her grow or shrink.
The text describes the Caterpillar as blue ('a large blue caterpillar').

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In the context of DaSCHland, the Caterpillar character is reimagined with a digital twist, embodying both wisdom and a connection to the historical data within the DaSCH repository. This version of the Caterpillar maintains his iconic thoughtful and philosophical demeanor, often found lounging on a mushroom, but here the mushroom also serves as an interactive data terminal that displays various texts and historical documents relevant to Alice‚Äôs queries and the Caterpillar‚Äôs wise teachings.
The Caterpillar in DaSCHland uses his deep knowledge, derived from vast literary and historical databases, to challenge and guide Alice through complex philosophical debates and puzzles. His dialogue with Alice often includes interactive elements, such as visual data projections from his mushroom, making each interaction not only a conversation but a visually engaging learning experience. This character retains his calm, contemplative nature and his ability to transform‚Äîsignifying not only physical change but also the transformative power of knowledge and digital technology in DaSCHland.

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text:
The Mad Hatter is a tea-obsessed, eccentric character who hosts the Mad Tea Party with the March Hare and the Dormouse. He is called ‚Äúmad‚Äù because Time has punished him by stopping time at 6 o‚Äôclock, meaning it is always tea-time for him. He loves riddles and wordplay, famously asking Alice: ‚ÄúWhy is a raven like a writing desk?‚Äù‚Äîa riddle with no real answer. He appears again at the trial of the Knave of Hearts, where he nervously testifies before the Queen of Hearts.
In 'Through the Looking-Glass', the Hatter returns in the form of the Anglo-Saxon messenger 'Hatta'.
Contrary to popular belief, Lewis Carroll never referred to the Hatter as 'the Mad Hatter' in the story. He simply called him 'the Hatter'. The phrase 'mad as a hatter' was common in Carroll's time, probably because hatters actually did go mad, as the mercury they used sometimes gave them mercury poisoning. (source: alice-in-wonderland.net)

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, the Mad Hatter transforms into an intriguing digital persona, blending his traditional eccentricity and whimsical charm with advanced technological attributes. He hosts the famed tea parties, which in this digital realm are dynamic simulations, where each cup of tea and piece of cake is embedded with historical anecdotes or literary quotes that appear as holographic texts above the table. The Mad Hatter in this virtual world is not just a bringer of nonsensical humor; he also serves as a conduit for exploring the rich tapestry of literature and history stored in the DaSCH repository. His hat, iconic and oversized, functions as an interface that projects various informational displays, engaging Alice and other guests in riddles and puzzles that draw from a diverse array of cultural and historical contexts.
His character retains the unpredictable nature known from the original tales but is enhanced with the ability to manipulate his environment digitally, making each interaction with him a surprise and a new opportunity for Alice to learn something unique about the virtual world she navigates.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: Why is a raven like a writing-desk?

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text:
The Cheshire Cat is a mischievous, grinning cat who gives philosophical advice to Alice. He has the ability to disappear and reappear at will, sometimes leaving only his grin behind. He guides Alice, explaining the madness of Wonderland and telling her ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all mad here.‚Äù He later appears at the Queen‚Äôs croquet game, where his floating head confuses the King and Queen of Hearts. He serves as a guide for Alice, offering riddles and cryptic advice but never direct answers.
The reason for Carroll naming this character 'Cheshire Cat' is unclear: 'To grin like a Cheshire Cat' was a common phrase in Carroll's day. It may have originated from a sign painter in Cheshire who painted grinning lions on the sign-boards of inns in the area. Another source is the 'Alice Window' in Christ Church, Oxford, where you can see three grinning animals at the top of the Liddell's family arms. Cheshire cheeses were also once molded in the shape of a grinning cat. (source: alice-in-wonderland.net)

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In the imaginative world of DaSCHland, the Cheshire Cat stands out as a particularly fascinating digital entity. He embodies the quintessential mystery and wit of his character, now augmented with the capability to appear and disappear at will, leaving behind only his iconic grin, which serves as a user interface for accessing various data points within the DaSCH repository. The Cheshire Cat's interactions with Alice are both enlightening and cryptic, guiding her through DaSCHland with riddles and philosophical insights that challenge her perceptions. His ability to phase in and out of digital visibility symbolizes the fluid nature of information in the digital age, where data can be both omnipresent and elusive.
This version of the Cheshire Cat not only serves as a guide through the labyrinthine digital landscape but also as a reminder of the transformative power of technology in reshaping narratives and character interactions within this virtual world. His presence is a constant reminder of the enigmatic and ever-changing nature of the digital realm Alice explores.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: We‚Äôre all mad here. I‚Äôm mad. You‚Äôre mad.

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text:
The Queen of Hearts is the ruler of Wonderland, known for her explosive temper and frequent orders of ‚ÄúOff with their heads!‚Äù She is tyrannical, irrational, and quick to anger, though her executions are never actually carried out (likely because the King of Hearts quietly pardons everyone). She hosts a chaotic croquet game, where flamingos are used as mallets and hedgehogs as balls.
Carroll wrote the following about the Queen of Hearts: "I pictured the Queen of Hearts as a sort of embodiment of ungovernable passion ‚Äì a blind and aimless Fury." (source: alice-in-wonderland.net)

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, the Queen of Hearts is reenvisioned as a formidable digital ruler, embodying her classic characteristics of authority and quick temper, but with a modern twist. In this virtual world, she presides over the digital kingdom with a strict adherence to the rules and protocols encoded within the DaSCH repository.
The Queen‚Äôs realm in DaSCHland is a place where order intersects with the whimsical laws of Wonderland, making her both a guardian of traditional narratives and an enforcer of the digital world's unique logic. Her commands and decrees can instantly alter the landscape or the behavior of other characters, demonstrating her control over the digital environment.
Her interactions with Alice are intense and pivotal, offering dramatic encounters that highlight the power dynamics within DaSCHland. The Queen of Hearts in this setting isn't just a character from a story; she is a dynamic representation of control and authority in a world where data and reality intertwine seamlessly.

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text:
The March Hare is a wild, energetic, and slightly mad character who hosts the Mad Tea Party along with the Mad Hatter and the Dormouse. He is always celebrating ‚Äútea-time‚Äù because time has stopped for him as a result of an argument the Hatter had with Time. He takes part in riddles, nonsensical conversations, and interruptions, frustrating Alice with his lack of logic.
He is named Haigha in the second book.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: The Cheshire Cat's interactions with Alice are both enlightening and cryptic, guiding her through DaSCHland with riddles and philosophical insights that challenge her perceptions. His ability to phase in and out of digital visibility symbolizes the fluid nature of information in the digital age, where data can be both omnipresent and elusive.

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The Duchess is an eccentric, ugly, and unpredictable noblewoman who lives in a chaotic house filled with pepper that makes everyone sneeze. She has a violent cook, an abused baby (who later turns into a pig), and a tendency to spout moral lessons in a forced, nonsensical way. She later reappears, acting overly friendly toward Alice, contradicting her earlier harsh behavior.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In the virtual realm of DaSCHland, the Duchess takes on a multifaceted digital persona that embodies both the harshness and unexpected warmth she displays in the original tales. This Duchess is intricately programmed to interact with Alice using a mix of sharp remarks and philosophical musings, enhanced by the digital environment's capability to integrate complex dialogue and interactions.
The Duchess in DaSCHland oversees a segment of the digital landscape that mirrors her eclectic and somewhat chaotic household, where the laws of physics and conventional logic are frequently bent. Her interactions often include lessons about manners and morality, albeit delivered in a convoluted manner that challenges Alice to think critically about the rules and norms of both the real and digital worlds.
Her character is not only a caretaker of peculiar digital creatures but also serves as a critical voice in the narrative, pushing Alice to question and understand the underlying structures of DaSCHland. The Duchess‚Äôs presence is marked by her ability to shift from volatile to caring in moments, making her a complex and compelling figure in the digital adventure.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: Everything‚Äôs got a moral, if only you can find it

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The Mock Turtle is a sad and melancholic creature who constantly sighs and reminisces about his past. He was once a real turtle and attended ‚Äúsea school‚Äù under a master called Tortoise (because he ‚Äútaught us‚Äù). He is known for his nonsensical stories and puns, particularly about his strange school subjects, like Reeling and Writhing instead of Reading and Writing. He and the Gryphon teach Alice the Lobster Quadrille, a bizarre underwater dance.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text: This version of the Cheshire Cat not only serves as a guide through the labyrinthine digital landscape but also as a reminder of the transformative power of technology in reshaping narratives and character interactions within this virtual world. His presence is a constant reminder of the enigmatic and ever-changing nature of the digital realm Alice explores.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: When we were little, we went to school in the sea. The master was an old turtle‚Äîwe used to call him Tortoise‚Äî"

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The Gryphon is a mythical creature with the body of a lion and the wings and head of an eagle. He serves as a guide to Alice, taking her to meet the Mock Turtle and listening to his sorrowful tales. Unlike many Wonderland characters, he is bossy but not hostile, often rushing the Mock Turtle through his stories. He introduces Alice to the Lobster Quadrille, a strange dance performed under the sea.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In the digitally-rendered world of DaSCHland, the Gryphon emerges as a majestic and authoritative creature, blending elements of his mythological origins with modern digital functionalities. He serves as a guardian and guide, helping Alice navigate the more complex and potentially perilous parts of the digital landscape with wisdom and a stern demeanor.
The Gryphon in DaSCHland is intricately designed, combining his classical eagle-and-lion form with enhancements that reflect his role within the digital environment. He possesses the ability to access and project holographic histories or legendary tales from the DaSCH repository, using his wings and talons as interactive tools that help illustrate these stories to Alice.
His interactions with Alice are educational and protective, ensuring that she not only enjoys her journey through DaSCHland but also gains deeper insights into the literary and mythical foundations that the realm is built upon. The Gryphon‚Äôs character is a bridge between the ancient and the digital, embodying the wisdom of the old and the possibilities of the new.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: "It's all his fancy, that: he hasn't got no sorrow, you know. Come on!"

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text:
The Red Queen is a chess piece on the Red side, known for being strict, commanding, and highly logical. She first meets Alice in Chapter 2 and explains the rules of the Looking-Glass world, where Alice must move like a pawn to reach the eighth square and become a queen. She later appears at Alice‚Äôs coronation banquet, where the event descends into chaos.
It is possible that the Red Queen was modelled after the governess for the Liddell children, Miss Prickett, who was known as 'Pricks'. (source: alice-in-wonderland.net)

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In the digital wonderland of DaSCHland, the Red Queen is reimagined as a dynamic and strategic figure, embodying a blend of leadership and urgency. Unlike the traditional portrayal of her character as simply domineering, this Red Queen is more nuanced, using her quick-paced and decisive nature to manage and oversee complex digital operations within the realm.
The Red Queen in DaSCHland utilizes advanced data analytics and management tools that are visually represented by the constant motion of her character‚Äîmirroring her motif of "running to stay in place." Her realm is one where order and efficiency reign, and she is often seen orchestrating the flow of information and digital events with precision and command.
Her interactions with Alice are marked by challenges that test Alice's ability to think and react quickly, embodying the Red Queen's belief in the necessity of constant movement and adaptation in a rapidly changing digital environment. This portrayal highlights her as not just a ruler but a symbol of perpetual progress and the relentless pace of technological and data-driven environments.

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Humpty Dumpty is a large, egg-shaped character sitting on a wall when Alice meets him. He is famously known from the nursery rhyme: He is arrogant and boastful, constantly correcting Alice and claiming he can make words mean whatever he wants. He explains the nonsense words from ‚ÄúJabberwocky‚Äù to Alice, adding to the theme of language and meaning.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, Humpty Dumpty is crafted as a figure of intellectual whimsy, combining his well-known penchant for wordplay with digital enhancements that allow him to manipulate language and meanings in novel ways. This digital Humpty Dumpty is perched on a high wall, symbolizing his lofty ideas and the precarious nature of his assertions.
This version of Humpty Dumpty is equipped with linguistic databases from the DaSCH repository, enabling him to provide Alice with elaborate explanations and definitions that twist and stretch words beyond their conventional meanings. His digital interface allows him to project visual representations of his wordplay, turning abstract concepts into tangible, manipulable objects in the virtual environment.
His interactions with Alice are cerebral and engaging, challenging her understanding of language and logic. Humpty Dumpty‚Äôs role in DaSCHland is not only to entertain but also to enlighten, serving as a quirky mentor who encourages Alice to explore the depths of linguistic creativity and the flexibility of digital communication. This character retains his iconic vulnerability, with the ever-present risk of falling off his wall, symbolizing the delicate balance between knowledge and confusion in the expansive digital world.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: "Humpty Dumpty sat on a wall, Humpty Dumpty had a great fall. All the King‚Äôs horses and all the King‚Äôs men Couldn‚Äôt put Humpty together again."

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text:
The White Knight is a chess piece from the White side who rescues Alice from the Red Knight, following the rules of chess. He is depicted as kind, gentle, and absent-minded, constantly falling off his horse due to his clumsiness. He carries odd inventions, such as a beehive on a stick and anklets to keep sharks away, showcasing his quirky creativity. Before Alice moves on to become a Queen, he escorts her to the last square, saying a poetic farewell.
The White Knight is often seen as a self-portrait of Lewis Carroll, representing the gentle, eccentric dreamer who helps Alice along her journey.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In the imaginative universe of DaSCHland, the White Knight is transformed into a quirky yet noble figure who embodies the fusion of chivalric ideals with technological innovation. He is designed as a tinkerer and inventor, with his armor and steed adorned with various whimsical gadgets and gizmos that he has crafted from the digital resources available within the DaSCH repository.
This White Knight retains his traditional clumsiness and good-hearted nature, but his inventions are digitally enhanced, offering practical (and sometimes impractical) solutions during his adventures with Alice. His armor, instead of merely serving as protection, is integrated with interactive displays and tools that assist him and Alice as they navigate through DaSCHland.
His interactions with Alice are filled with gentle guidance and eccentric inventiveness. He serves not only as a protector on her journey but also as a mentor in creativity and resilience, often providing comic relief with his inventions that sometimes work in unexpected ways. The White Knight‚Äôs character in DaSCHland symbolizes the bridge between old-world chivalry and modern digital creativity, making every encounter with him both educational and entertaining.

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The Mouse is one of the creatures that fall into the pool of tears Alice creates when she grows too large. It is easily offended, especially when Alice mentions her cat, Dinah, which frightens the Mouse. To dry off, the Mouse tells a ‚Äúdry‚Äù history lesson about William the Conqueror, but it is so boring that no one listens. It participates in the Caucus Race, a nonsensical race where everyone wins.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, the Mouse is depicted as a wise and articulate historian, carrying a vast repository of knowledge from the DaSCH archives. This digital incarnation of the Mouse combines its characteristic timidity with a profound intellectual depth, serving as a guide to the historical and literary contexts of Wonderland.
The Mouse in DaSCHland is often seen scurrying across digital landscapes, leaving trails of historical data and literary references that help Alice understand the intricate background of the characters and settings she encounters. Its small size belies the vast amount of information it holds, and it communicates with Alice through a series of sophisticated projections and interactive data streams that visually represent the stories it tells.
Interacting with the Mouse, Alice finds a valuable resource in piecing together the puzzles of DaSCHland. The Mouse's role is crucial for teaching her about the origins and transformations of Wonderland's inhabitants and their adventures. This character's timid yet profound demeanor makes it a unique and insightful guide, enriching Alice's journey through the layers of digital Wonderland.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: Sit down, all of you, and listen to me! I'll soon make you dry enough!

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text:
The Dodo is one of the animals that fall into the pool of tears with Alice. He organizes the Caucus Race, a nonsensical event where everyone runs in circles with no clear rules, and everyone wins.
The dodo, a flightless bird that once inhabited the island of Mauritius, located east of Madagascar in the Indian Ocean, became extinct in the mid-17th century during the colonisation of the island by the Dutch.
The character is believed to represent Lewis Carroll himself (Charles Dodgson), as ‚ÄúDodo‚Äù is thought to be a reference to Dodgson‚Äôs own stammer, which made him pronounce his surname as ‚ÄúDo-do-Dodgson.‚Äù (source: alice-in-wonderland.net)

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, the Dodo is reimagined as a digital curator and archivist, overseeing the preservation and organization of the vast literary and historical data within the DaSCH repository. This version of the Dodo retains the peculiar and somewhat absurd characteristics from the original tales, but with a twist: he is deeply knowledgeable and somewhat pedantic about the digital artifacts and records under his care.
The Dodo in DaSCHland serves as an authoritative figure in managing the flow of information and ensuring that Alice receives the proper context and background needed for her explorations. His presence is marked by a series of elaborate digital displays and interfaces that he controls, which serve as interactive exhibits for Alice and other visitors to DaSCHland.
Interacting with the Dodo, Alice is often caught in the whirlwind of his archiving activities, witnessing how digital preservation works in a realm where literary and historical data are treated as precious commodities. The Dodo's meticulous nature and his commitment to his duties make him a fascinating character who blends the whimsical with the practical, providing a unique perspective on the importance of data stewardship in the digital age.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: The best way to explain it is to do it.

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text:
She is an unnamed older sister of Alice, present at the beginning and end of the story. At the start, she sits with Alice by the riverbank, reading a book with ‚Äúno pictures or conversations,‚Äù which bores Alice and leads her to daydream about Wonderland. At the end, after Alice wakes up from her dream, her sister gently sends her home and reflects on Alice‚Äôs adventures, imagining that Alice will one day grow up but still retain her childlike wonder.
Her character is likely a fictionalized counterpart to Lorina Charlotte "Ina" Liddell (1849-1930), the real-life elder sister of Alice Liddell. The real Alice's older sister, Lorina, was actually only three years her senior. (source: alice-in-wonderland.net)

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, Alice's sister is conceptualized as a serene and scholarly figure, serving as a gateway between the real world and the digital realm of DaSCH. She embodies the role of a caretaker and guide, often seen in the background, offering gentle encouragement and insights that help Alice navigate her digital adventures.
Her character in DaSCHland is endowed with an intuitive understanding of both the physical and digital worlds, making her an ideal mentor for Alice. She is portrayed as possessing a deep knowledge of the literary foundations of DaSCHland, providing Alice with critical interpretations and historical contexts that enrich her journey.
Alice's sister interacts with the digital world through a sophisticated interface that allows her to monitor and occasionally guide Alice's progress, ensuring that her little sister's explorations are both safe and enlightening. Her calm demeanor and intellectual depth make her a grounding presence, offering a bridge back to reality and a reminder of the world beyond the digital landscape. Her role highlights the connection between storytelling, learning, and the nurturing guidance that helps Alice grow throughout her adventures in DaSCHland.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: Wake up, Alice dear! Why, what a long sleep you've had!

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The King of Hearts is the ruler of Wonderland alongside the Queen of Hearts, though he is much less fearsome than his wife. He serves as the judge during the trial of the Knave of Hearts, who is accused of stealing the Queen‚Äôs tarts. He follows absurd legal procedures, often making nonsensical rulings, such as demanding a verdict before the evidence is presented. Unlike the Queen, who frequently yells ‚ÄúOff with their heads!‚Äù, the King often softens her harsh orders and tries to keep things under control.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, the King of Hearts is portrayed as a benevolent and somewhat ceremonial ruler, often overshadowed by the more forceful Queen of Hearts but holding his own unique authority within the digital realm. His character is designed to embody wisdom and moderation, serving as a balancing force against the Queen's more impulsive decisions.
The King in DaSCHland maintains his gentle demeanor from the original stories, but he is equipped with tools and systems that help him manage the kingdom's affairs and ensure the proper execution of its laws. He often appears in scenarios where judicial or moral decisions are needed, providing a voice of reason and compassion.
His interactions with Alice are marked by kindness and encouragement, offering her advice and support as she navigates the complexities of DaSCHland. The King's role is crucial in maintaining the order and fairness of the digital kingdom, often using his authority to temper the Queen's harsher judgments.
Overall, the King of Hearts in DaSCHland represents the virtues of patience and understanding, using his position to promote peace and stability in the kingdom, and showing Alice the importance of thoughtful leadership in any world, digital or otherwise.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: Begin at the beginning, and go on till you come to the end: then stop.

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The Dormouse is a sleepy, drowsy creature who sits between the Mad Hatter and the March Hare at the tea party. He constantly falls asleep mid-conversation and has to be poked or shaken awake by the others. He tells a bizarre story about three sisters (Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie) who live at the bottom of a treacle well and only eat treacle. At one point, Alice picks him up and puts him into a teapot, though he escapes later.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In the digital realm of DaSCHland, the Dormouse is reimagined as a sleepy yet insightful character, whose drowsy demeanor masks a deep repository of narrative wisdom. In this version, the Dormouse is not merely a participant in the Mad Hatter's tea party but serves as a crucial archival resource, storing and occasionally divulging snippets of folklore and historical tales embedded within DaSCH's extensive databases.
This digital Dormouse occasionally dozes off, but when awake, it projects holographic snippets of stories and historical events, illuminating the discussions at the tea party with vivid, animated tales from various epochs and cultures. Its ability to access and display these narratives at random‚Äîor seemingly so‚Äîadds a layer of enchantment and mystery to its character.
Interactions with the Dormouse provide Alice and other characters with unexpected insights, often sparking deeper discussions or leading to new adventures in DaSCHland. Despite its sleepy nature, the Dormouse is a beloved figure, enchanting visitors with its whimsical, albeit intermittent, contributions to the digital tea party. This character blends the charm of its traditional portrayal with the technological marvels of DaSCHland, making each of its rare awakenings a moment worth waiting for.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: I heard every word you fellows were saying

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The Knave is a servant of the Queen of Hearts, accused of stealing the Queen‚Äôs tarts. He is put on trial in a ridiculous courtroom scene, presided over by the King of Hearts. Although the evidence against him is absurd and nonsensical, the Queen still demands his execution. Before the trial can conclude, Alice grows larger and disrupts the proceedings, leading to the scene‚Äôs chaotic ending.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, the Knave of Hearts is recast as a mischievous yet charismatic character, well-known for his role in the infamous tart theft, but with a deeper digital twist. He serves as an intriguing figure within the virtual realm, often involved in scenarios that test the boundaries of rules and digital ethics.
The Knave in DaSCHland utilizes his cunning and charm not just to engage in his notorious antics but also to explore and sometimes exploit the digital environment's capabilities. His actions often lead to lessons about digital responsibility and the consequences of manipulating data without regard for the virtual world's laws.
His interactions with Alice are playful yet edifying, offering her‚Äîand the audience‚Äîa glimpse into the complexities of maintaining order and morality within a digitally governed realm. Despite his reputation for causing trouble, the Knave is portrayed as a fundamentally multi-dimensional character, whose adventures prompt discussions about right, wrong, and the gray areas in between in DaSCHland.
This version of the Knave of Hearts adds a layer of intrigue to the narrative, making him a pivotal character whose actions drive much of the drama and learning experiences within the digital wonderland.

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Dinah is a real-world kitten that Alice adores. She is described as an excellent mouser and bird-catcher. Alice frequently brings her up in conversation, especially when speaking to Wonderland creatures, which often upsets them‚Äîespecially the Mouse, who is terrified at the mention of cats.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, Dinah, Alice's beloved cat from the real world, is reimagined with a significant virtual presence that bridges the realms of reality and digital fantasy. This version of Dinah retains her feline traits but is enhanced with digital capabilities that allow her to interact with Alice in unique and helpful ways within the digital landscape.
Dinah in DaSCHland serves as Alice‚Äôs loyal companion and protector, equipped with sensors and communication tools that help her detect and navigate digital anomalies or threats. Her presence offers a comforting sense of home and familiarity to Alice, providing emotional support and practical assistance as they explore the various facets of the digital world together.
Her interactions with Alice and other characters are marked by a blend of affectionate behavior typical of a pet and sophisticated digital interventions that aid in Alice's adventures. Dinah's ability to appear and act within DaSCHland adds an element of whimsy and security, reinforcing the connection between Alice's real-world roots and her fantastical digital experiences.
Dinah's role as a digitally enhanced pet in DaSCHland highlights the theme of companionship transcending physical and virtual spaces, making her an integral part of the narrative that emphasizes loyalty, protection, and the comforts of home, even in the most extraordinary of settings.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: And she‚Äôs such a capital one for catching mice you can‚Äôt think! And oh, I wish you could see her after the birds! Why, she‚Äôll eat a little bird as soon as look at it!

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text:
The Duck is one of the animals that fall into the pool of tears with Alice. It participates in the Caucus Race, a nonsensical event where everyone wins.
The character is believed to be based on Reverend Duckworth, a friend of Lewis Carroll who accompanied Alice Liddell and her sisters on the boat trip where Carroll first told the story. (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robinson_Duckworth)

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, the Duck is portrayed as a character brimming with practical wisdom and a no-nonsense attitude, offering a grounded perspective in the often whimsical and chaotic digital environment. This version of the Duck, inspired by the original character in Lewis Carroll's tales, is enhanced with features that allow it to navigate and explain the natural laws governing the digital world of DaSCHland.
The Duck in this virtual realm serves as a guide, especially in scenarios involving natural simulations, such as virtual waterways or weather patterns, using its knowledge to educate Alice and other characters on the digital ecosystem's workings. The Duck's pragmatic approach helps demystify the complex interactions within DaSCHland, making it a reliable resource for understanding how digital and natural laws intertwine.
Interacting with the Duck provides Alice with invaluable lessons on adaptability and the importance of understanding one's environment. The Duck's straightforward and often blunt demeanor adds a layer of humor and realism to the narrative, contrasting with the more fantastical elements and characters in DaSCHland. This character enriches the digital landscape by offering insights into the practical aspects of navigating a world where reality and digital creations coexist.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: What I was going to say, was, that the best thing to get us dry would be a Caucus-race

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The Lory is a talking bird that falls into the pool of tears along with Alice and other creatures. It participates in the Caucus Race, where everyone runs in circles and ‚Äúwins.‚Äù The Lory is depicted as proud and argumentative, refusing to let Alice have the last word in their conversation. She is said to be modeled after Alice‚Äôs sister, Lorina (source: alice-in-wonderland.net)

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, the Lory character is reimagined as a vibrant and somewhat competitive personality, retaining its original traits from Lewis Carroll's tales but with enhanced digital capabilities. This digital Lory is portrayed as eager and somewhat assertive, often involved in discussions and debates, where it loves to showcase its knowledge and wit.
The Lory in DaSCHland serves as a counterpart to the Duck, offering a contrasting perspective that is more assertive and less concerned with practical details and more with winning arguments or leading expeditions within the digital realm. This character's role is often to challenge Alice and other characters, pushing them to think critically and react swiftly to the evolving scenarios in this virtual world.
Interacting with Lory provides a dynamic element to Alice's journey, testing her problem-solving skills and her ability to navigate social interactions in a competitive environment. The Lory's colorful personality and eagerness to engage make it a memorable part of the digital narrative, contributing to the lively and diverse character ensemble in DaSCHland.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: I am older than you, and must know better

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: The Eaglet is one of the animals that fall into the pool of tears with Alice. It participates in the Caucus Race, a nonsensical race where everyone wins. The Eaglet is depicted as intelligent and somewhat critical, questioning the Dodo‚Äôs explanations. She is said to be modeled after Alice‚Äôs sister, Edith (source: alice-in-wonderland.net)

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, the Eaglet character is reenvisioned as a cautious yet insightful figure, bringing a blend of youthful energy and a keen eye for detail to the digital landscape. This version of the Eaglet, drawing from Lewis Carroll's original portrayal, is characterized by its careful observations and occasional skepticism, providing a voice of reason amid the more flamboyant personalities.
The Eaglet in DaSCHland often serves as a mediator and analyst, helping to decipher complex digital phenomena and ensuring that discussions stay grounded in logic. Its role is particularly important in situations where the whimsical nature of DaSCHland's environment leads to confusion or misinterpretations, as the Eaglet helps to clarify misunderstandings and offer clear, concise explanations.
Interacting with the Eaglet enhances Alice‚Äôs experiences by encouraging her to be more observant and thoughtful about her surroundings. The Eaglet's careful approach to the digital world's challenges and its ability to distill wisdom from chaotic situations make it a crucial ally for Alice and other characters navigating the intricate realm of DaSCHland.

text-prop.name: :hasQuote
text-prop.text: Speak English! I don't know the meaning of half those long words, and, what's more, I don't believe you do either!

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Mary Ann is the White Rabbit‚Äôs housemaid. Although she never appears physically, she is important because the White Rabbit mistakes Alice for her when Alice enters his house.

text-prop.name: :hasDescriptionAlternative
text-prop.text:
In DaSCHland, Mary Ann is creatively reimagined as Alice's virtual assistant, embodying a character that seamlessly blends functionality with a dash of whimsical loyalty. Drawing from her role in the original "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" as the White Rabbit's housemaid, this version of Mary Ann is adapted to assist not just the White Rabbit but also Alice throughout her digital journey.
Mary Ann in DaSCHland is designed to be highly efficient and helpful, managing logistical tasks, scheduling events, and providing reminders and notifications to keep Alice on track as she navigates the complex digital environment. Her character is equipped with a suite of digital tools that allow her to access and organize vast amounts of data from the DaSCH repository, making her an indispensable companion in managing the day-to-day adventures and challenges Alice faces.
Her interactions with Alice are characterized by a blend of caretaking and managerial efficiency, offering a comforting yet structured presence. Mary Ann‚Äôs role underscores the importance of support and organization within the whimsical yet sometimes overwhelming world of DaSCHland, ensuring that Alice‚Äôs adventures are both enjoyable and well-coordinated.

text-prop.name: :hasDescription
text-prop.text: Pat is a servant of the White Rabbit in in Alice‚Äôs Adventures in Wonderland. He is called upon, along with Bill the Lizard, to help remove Alice from the Rabbit‚Äôs house after she grows too large and gets stuck inside. He is described as somewhat bumbling and comical, engaging in a humorous conversation about how to deal with the situation.
